	– Suecica rediviva, no. 67, Bokförlaget Rediviva, Stockholm 1976, ISBN 91-7120-083-5.

PAGE: 93
HEADING: LINNAEUS (1753)

4769. Caroli Linnaei ... <em>Species plantarum</em>, exhibentes plantas rite cognitas, ad genera
relatas, cum differentiis specificis, nominibus trivialibus, synonymis selectis, locis natalibus,
secundum systema sexuale digestas. Tomus I[II].... Holmiae [Stockholm] (Impensis
Laurentii Salvii) 1753, 2 vols. Oct. (<em>Sp. pl.</em>). (SO 480, KR 6, STR 5898). 

1. <em>Orig. ed</em>.: 1 Mai 1753 (Conventional date established by the International Code of
	Botanical Nomenclature, art. 13.1). The two volumes of the <em>Species plantarum</em> are regard-
	ed as having been published simultaneously on this day). <em>Copies</em>: G, HU(5), MO, US(2);
	IDC 158.
	<em>1</em>: [i-xii], 1-560.
	<em>2</em>: [i], 561-1200, [1-30, index], [1, err.].
	Actual dates of publication were 24 May and 16 August 1753. The <em>Species plantarum</em> (ed.
	1) is the starting-point work for the nomenclature of Spermatophyta, Pteridophyta,
	Sphagnaceae, Hepaticae, Lichenes, Algae (except Nostocaceae, Desmidiaceae, Oedo-
	goniaceae), Myxomycetes and Bacteria, all of Recent plants only. It is agreed to
	associate generic names which first appear in Linnaeus's <em>Species plantarum</em> ed. 1 (1753)
	and ed. 2 (1762-1763) with the first subsequent description given under those names in
	Linnaeus's <em>Genera plantarum</em> ed. 5 (1754) and ed. 6 (1764). This means that all generic
	names accepted and published by Linnaeus in the <em>Species plantarum</em>, even if not accompa-
	nied by a description, are treated as having been validly published on 1 May 1753. All
	these names date then from 1753 (arts. 13.4 and 41. note 1). For a detailed and
	elucidating study of the <em>Species plantarum</em> see Stearn's introduction to the Ray Society
	reprint (vol. 1, 1957). For indexes, lists of explanations of abbreviations etc., see volume 2
	of that edition (1959) (especially Heller 1959). No taxonomist should nowadays use the
	<em>Species plantarum</em> without having a thorough knowledge of Stearn's Introduction. – See
	also HU 548.
2. <em>Variant</em>: 1753, vol. 1 only, with p. 75, 89-90, and 259-260 in their original state and not, as
	in the accepted original edition, the cancels. These pages contained several errors and
	were replaced by new text soon after publication. This took place before the publication
	of volume 2 and since both volumes have to be treated as having been published
	simultaneously on 1 May 1753, it is necessary (and desirable) to treat the cancelled pages
	as non-existent. They have no nomenclatural standing because Linnaeus did not accept
	them (cf. ICBN Art. 33). For further details see Bryk (1953) and Steam (1957, pp. 136-
	142, with a reprint of the cancelled pages). The copies of the first state are so rare that
	they would have had little effect except for the circumstance that Junk used one of them
	for his facsimile. The Junk facsimile has now also become a rarity. (Bryk no. 3, SO 481).
	We have seen no orginal copy of this variant. First descriptions of this variant: Flatt, Bot.
	Centralbl. 66: 216-222. 1896, Jackson, J. Bot. 34: 359-362. 1896. Two copies with slightly
	different composition are at HU (see STR 5898).
3. <em>Facsimile ed</em>. [<em>A</em>]: 1907, ed. W. Junk, Berlin. <em>Copies</em>: FH, U, USDA. – SO 481, STR 5901. –
	This facsimile was made of one of the extremely rare copies of the <em>Species plantarum</em> which
	still contained the original pages (and not the cancels) for pp. 75/76, 89/90 and 259/260.
	<em>Cover</em>: Facsimile-Edition. Ed. W. Junk. No. 11. C. Linnaeus <em>Species plantarum</em>... W. Junk
	(Berlin W., ...) 1907.
3. <em>Facsimile ed</em>. [<em>B</em>]: 1907, ed. W. Junk, with the replaced pages 75/76, 89/90 and 259/260.
	This "corrected" facsimile by Junk is mentioned only by Bryk (no. 9). Soulsby does not
	mention it. We have seen no copy of it.
4. <em>Facsimile ed</em>. [<em>C</em>]: 1934, ed. Shokobutsu-Bunken-Kankôkwa, Tokyo, 2 vols., facsimile in 2
	vols., only addition, vol. 2, end: [1]-20, [1, colo.], all in Japanese. – <em>Copy</em>: FAS. – Bryk no.
	10, STR 5903. – Published under the guidance of T. Nakai. Facsimile of orig. ed. (1).
5. <em>Facsimile ed</em>. [<em>D</em>]: 1957-1959, ed. Ray Society, London. <em>Copies</em>: FAS, U, US.
	<em>1</em>: 1957, p. [1], col. frontisp., [iii]-xiv, 1-176, [1-2], new preface matter and introduction
	by W. T. Stearn; <em>facsimile</em>: [i-xii], 1 -560; new index to genera and classes [1-6]. – STR
	5904.
	<em>2</em>: 1959, p. [i], portr. Linnaeus, [iii]-xv [xvi-xviii], new preface matter and additional
	remarks by W. T. Stearn; <em>facsimile</em>: [i], 561-1200, [1-30], index, [1, err.]; new: "An
	appendix to the Species plantarum of Carl Linnaeus by John Lewis Heller and
	William Thomas Stearn, The Ray Society, London 1958: [1]-148, with e.g. a new
	index to volumes 1 and 2. This index (p. 103-148) contains references to choices of
	lectotypes and should always be consulted for such purposes.

PAGE: 94
HEADING: LINNAEUS (1753)

<em>Further editions</em> of the <em>Species plantation</em> are treated individually below under their TL-/2
	numbers, or under the authors quoted which arc to be treated in the remaining volumes.
	For a bibliography see Bryk 1953.
6. <em>Second edition</em>. Species plantarum ... Editio secunda, aucta, Stockholm 1762-1763, 2 vols.,
	published Sep 1762 and Aug 1763 (see TL-2/4817, STR 5905).
7. <em>Third edition</em>. Species plantarum ... Editio tertia. Wien 1764, 2 vols. A reprint of the
	second edition with the errata incorporated in the text (see TL-2/4826, STR 5906).
8. <em>Fourth edition</em>. Systema plantarum ... Editio novissima ... curante D. J. J. Reichard.
	Frankfurt a.M. 1779-1780, 4 parts. This consists of the <em>Systema vegetabilium</em> of 1774, the
	<em>Species plantarum</em> (1753) and the <em>Mantissa</em> (1767-1771) combined, and can be counted as
	the fourth edition of the Species plantarum [SO 11] (see under J. J. Reichard, STR
	7508).
9. <em>Fifth edition</em> [c.q. <em>fourth</em>] <em>Species plantarum</em>... Editio quarta, post Reichardianum quinta
	adjectis vegetabilibus hucusque cognitis curante Carolo Ludovico Willdenow. Berlin
	1797-1830, 6 volumes. Oct. This is the Willdenow edition of the <em>Species</em>; an independent
	work which should be attributed to Willdenow (Bryk no. 18, SO 512, STR 10097; see
	below under C. L. Willdenow).
10. <em>Sixth edition</em>. Species plantarum ... olim curante Carolo Ludovico Willdenow. Editio
	sexta ... auctore Dr. Alberto Dietrich. Berlin 1831-1833, 2 vols. Oct. [half-title: editio
	sexta, aucta et continuata ab H. F. Link, A. Fr. Schwaegrichen et A. Dietrich]. This is
	the Dietrich edition; an independent work (Bryk 19, SO 529, STR 1666; see TL-2/1456).

Some <em>Indexes</em> and <em>Special studies</em> of the <em>Species plantarum</em>:
11. <em>Variants</em>: Wilhelm Junk, Linné's Species plantarum editio princeps, und ihre Varianten,
	mit Beschreibung einer neuen. Mit 12 Facsimile-Tafeln, Ein Jubilaeums- Epilog. Berlin
	W., 1907. Verlag von W. Junk, cover, p. [i], [1]-12, 12 p. fasc. of pages from orig. ed. (1)
	and variant (2). Extensive description of variant (2). – <em>Copies</em>: MO, NY. – SO 482, STR
	5902.
12. <em>Index perfectus</em> ad Caroli Linnaci <em>Species plantarum</em>, nempe earum primam editionem,
	(anno 1753). Collatore Ferdinando de Mueller [Ferdinand Jacob Heinrich von Mueller,
	1825-1896]. Melbourne (M'Carron, Bird &amp; Socii impresserunt) 1880. Oct., p. [i, iii],
	[1]-40. <em>Copies</em>: G, KNAW, MO(2), TL-2/6418, SO 483, STR 6799.
13. <em>Index abecedarius</em>: an alphabetical index to the first edition of the "Species plantarum" of
	Linnaeus. Compiled by William Philip Hiern [1839-1925, see TL-2/2: 191-192], ...
	Issued as a supplement to the "Journal of Botany", [July] 1906. London (West, Newman
	&amp; Co., ...) 1906. Oct., p. [i], [1]-44. <em>Copy</em>: MO. – SO 484, STR 3275.
14. <em>Indices nominum trivialium</em> ad: Linnaei <em>Species plantarum</em>, ed. I. Berlin (W. Junk ...) 1907.
	Oct., p. [i-iii], 1-92. <em>Copies</em>: MO, NY. – SO 485, STR 3807.
15. <em>Special studies</em> 1791-1929, see SO 485a-499c.
16. <em>Bibliography</em>: Th. O. B. N. Krok, Bibliotheca botanica suecana 432-433. 1925 (KR 6).
17. <em>Bibliography</em> and general studies: F. Bryk: Bibliographia Linnaeana ad Species planta-
	rum pertinens, Taxon 2: 74-84. 1953 (STR 1067); see also other papers on the <em>Species
	plantarum</em> in Taxon 2: 37-73. 1953 (STR 6871).
18. <em>General study</em>: Th. Sprague et al., Proc. Linn. Soc. London 165: 151-166. 1955.
19. W. T. Stearn, <em>An introduction to the Species plantarum</em> and cognate botanical works of Carl
	Linnaeus. London 1957, <em>in</em> facsimile edition of Species plantarum, published by the Ray
	Society, vol. 1, London 1957 (STR 8572).
20. J. J. Heller, <em>Index auctorum et librorum a Linnaeo</em> (Species plantarum, 1753) <em>citatorum</em>,
	London 1959, <em>in</em> facsimile edition of Species plantarum published by the Ray Society,
	vol. 2. London 1959 (STR 3203).
21. Du Rietz, Tryckningen av Species plantarum 1753, Svenska Linné-Sällsk. Årsskr. 48:
	60-87. 1966 (Analytical bibliographical studies; collation), (STR 1745).
22. <em>Typification of genera</em> in Sp. pl. ed. 1: see under Gen. pl., ed. 5, 1754 (STR 5380).
23. <em>Osbeck and Sp. pl</em>.: Hansen, B. &amp; A. F. Fox Maule, Bot. J. Linn. Soc. 67(3): 189-212. 1973
	(STR 3067).
24. <em>International Code of Botanical Nomenclature</em> (Leningrad Code) 1978, entries on <em>Species
	plantarum</em>:
	<em>Art. 13.1, Starting point</em> for Spermatophyta, Pteridophyta, Lichcnes, Algae (in general),
	Myxomycetes.
	<em>Art. 13.4, Generic names</em> associated with Gen. Pl. eds. 5 and 6.

PAGE: 95
HEADING: LINNAEUS (1753)

	<em>Art. 33.1</em>, Examples of combinations definitely indicated.
	<em>Art. 41.1</em>, See Art. 13.1
	<em>Art. 74.1</em>, regulation correct spelling generic names if different in Gen. pl. ed. 5. – see also
	B. R. Baum, Taxon 17: 642-644. 1968.

<em>Note</em>: It is obviously impracticable to enumerate here even the main literature on the <em>Species
plantarum</em>. The above-mentioned works and papers provide a guide to it. – See Taxon 2: 37-
84. 1953 and Proc. Linn. Soc. London 165. 1955 for series of studies; see STR for the most
recent listing of this literature.

4771. D. D. <em>Incrementa botanices</em> proxime praeterlapsi semiseculi, quae, cum consensus

4772. S. C. A. <em>Demonstrationes plantarum</em> in horto Upsaliensi mdccliii. Quas consentiente

1758, KR 124, STR 4975). 

<em>Publ</em>.: 3 Oct 1753, p. [i-viii], [1]-27, [28]. <em>Copy</em>: MO. – Further eds.: SO 1758-1762, e.g.

	1450 species grown in the Uppsala bot. gard. all provided with binary names.
<em>Ref</em>.: Rickett, H. W., Lloydia 18(2): 50, 53-55. 1955.
	Rothmaler, W., Repert. Sp. nov. 49: 279-280. 1940, 52: 177. 1943 (argues that author-

4773. D. D. <em>Herbationes upsalienses</em>, quas consent, experient. Facult. medica in Regia

<em>Publ</em>.: 13 Oct 1753, p. [1]-20. <em>Copies</em>: MO, US, USDA. – Other eds. SO 1764-1769a; <em>Amoen</em>.
	<em>acad. 3(49</em>): <em>425-445. 1756, Amoen. acad., Schreber ed.</em> 3(49): 425-445. 1787. – List of the
	plants around Uppsala on L's field trips with students.

4774. D. A. G. Dissertatio medico-botanica, exhibens <em>Plantas officinales</em>, quam, consens.

<em>Author</em>: (see KR; internal evidence on last page) Nils Gahn (1733-1820).
<em>Publ</em>.: 15 Dec 1753, p. [i-iv], [1]-31, [32]. <em>Copy</em>: MO. – Other eds.: SO 1780-1785; e.g.

PAGE: 96
HEADING: LINNAEUS (1753)

	<em>Amoen. acad.</em> 4(51): 1-25. 1759. <em>Amoen. acad. Schreber ed.</em> 4(51): 1-25. 1788. – List of
	medicinal plants.
<em>Swedish translation</em>: 1950, Valda Avh. C. v. Linné, Sv. Linné-Sällsk., Uppsala, no. 10. (STR
	5129).
<em>Ref</em>.: Drake, G., Sv. farmac. Tidskr. 18, 1921 (fide SO 1785).

4775. D. D. Dissertatio botanica, sistens <em>Stationes plantarum</em>, quam, consensu ampliss.
Facult. medicae in Almo Upsal. Lyceo, sub praesidio, ... Caroli Linnaci, ... publice
ventilandam sistit, Andres Hedenberg, Stockholmiensis. In Audit. carolin. major. d. iii
Aprilís, anni mdccliv. H. A. M. S. Upsaliac (Exc. L. M. Höjer, Reg. Acad. Typ.) [1754].	Qu.
(<em>Stat. pl.</em>). (SO 1799, KR 95, STR 5230). 

<em>Publ</em>.: 3 Apr 1754, p. [i-iv], [1]-23, [24]. <em>Copies</em>: MO (2), US, USDA. – Other ed. SO 1800-

4776. D. D. <em>Flora anglica</em>, quam cum consens, experient. Fac. medicae in Regia Academia
Upsaliensi, sub praesidio ... Caroli Linnaei, ... specimini academici loco, publicae ventila-
tioni offert Isaacus Olai Grufberg, Stockholmensis. In Auditorio carolino majori d. iii April
anno mdccliv. H. A. [changed by hand to "P."] M. C. Upsaliae (Exc. Laur. Magnus Höjer,
Rec. Acad. Typogr.) [1754] Qu. (<em>Fl. angl.</em>). (SO 1805, KR 26, STR 4997). 

<em>Publ</em>.: 3 Apr 1754, p. [i-viii], [1]-29, [30-32]. <em>Copies</em>: MO (2), US. – Other eds. SO 1806-
	1812, e.g. <em>Amoen. acad.</em> 4(55): 88-111. 1759, <em>Amoen. acad. Schreber ed.</em> 4(55): 88-111. 1788.
	"The first Linnaean arrangement of English plants, about 1000 in number, of which
	about 300 were not found in Sweden." (SO).
<em>Combined reprint</em> of Dissertation and Amoen. acad. version:
	J. Bot. 47 Suppl. (1): 3: 23. 1909 (transcription by W. R. Clarke; introd. by J. Britten on
	p. 1-2), (STR 1393). The Introduction outlines the differences between the original and
	the Amoenitates version. – Also published separately: "<em>Linnaeus's Flora anglica</em>..."
	London (West. Newman &amp; Co., ... ) 1909, p. [1]-23. SO 1809a, STR 1394. <em>Copy</em>: G.
<em>Facsimile ed</em>. (of 1754 orig.): 1973, <em>in</em> W. T. Stearn, ed., John Ray, Synopsis ... 1724, Carl
	Linnaeus, Flora anglica 1754 &amp; 1759. Facsimiles with an introduction by William T.
	Stearn, London (The Ray Society) 1973. The introduction provides a detailed discus-
	sion of the Flora anglica and updated nomenclature. – STR 7490.
Facsimile ed. (of 1759 ed. in Amoen. acad. ed. 4): 1973, <em>in</em> W. T. Stearn, .... see above.
<em>Ref</em>.: Britten, J., J. Bot. 47 (Suppl. (1): 1-2. 1909, 50: 312-314. 1912.
	Druce, G. C., Scottish bot. Rev. 1: 154-161. 1912, J. Bot. 51: 18-21. 1913.
	Rothmaler, W., Repert. Sp. nov. 49: 280-281. 1940, 52: 177. 1943 (attributes authorship
	to Grufberg).

4777. D. D. <em>Herbarium amboinenese</em>, quod consens, experient. Facult. medicae in Regia
Academia Upsaliensi, sub praesidio ... Caroli Linnaei, ... publico examini submittit, ...
Olavus Stickman, Smolandus. In Auditorio car. majori d. xi. Maji, anno mdccliv. H. A. M.
S. Upsaliae (Exc. L. M. Höjer, Reg. Acad. Typ.) [1754]. Qu. (<em>Herb. amb.</em>) (SO 1813, KR
27, STR 5034). 

<em>Publ</em>.: 11 Mai 1754, p. [i-iv], [1]-28. Copy: MO. – Other eds.: SO 1814-1816; <em>Amoen acad</em>.
	4(56): 112-143. 1759, <em>Amoen. acad., Schreber ed.</em> 4(56): 112-143. 1788. – A commentary on
	Rumphius, <em>Herbarium amboinense</em>, q.v. (no. 1126), giving Linnaean synonymy; see DA
	(1967, p. 15) and Rickett (1955) for further details; the version in the Amoenitates (Vol.
	4) is revised and extended.
<em>Ref</em>.: Rickett, H. W., Lloydia 18: 55-57. 1955.
	Rothmaler, W., Repert. Sp. nov. 50: 68-69. 1941, 52: 178. 1943 (attributes authorship to
	Stickman).

4778. Caroli Linnaei ... <em>Genera plantarum</em> eorumque characteres naturales secundum
numerum, figuram, situm, et proportionem omnium fructificationes partium ... Editio
quinta ab auctore reformata et aucta ... Holmiae [Stockholm], (impensis Laurentii Salvii)
1754. Oct. 

(<em>Gen. pl. ed. 5</em>). (SO 301, KR 2, STR 5380).
<em>Publ</em>.: Aug 1754, p. [i*-iii*], [i]-xxxii, [1]-500, [1-21, index, 22 err.]. <em>Copies</em>: G, MO, US (3),
	USDA; IDC 167. – The third US copy has the Ehret plate of the sex. syst. bound in. The
	errata on p. [22] are to the <em>Species plantarum</em> (1753). – It is agreed (ICBN Art. 13 note 1) to
	associate generic names which first appear in Linnaeus's <em>Species plantarum</em> ed. 1 (1753)

PAGE: 97
HEADING: LINNAEUS (1754)

	and ed. 2 (1762-1763) with the first subsequent description given under those names in
	Linnaeus's <em>Genera plantarum</em> ed. 5 (1754) and ed. 6 (1764) (cf. also Art. 41). For more
	detailed information on this edition of the Genera plantarum and for an explanation of
	the abbreviations see Stearn's introduction to the 1960 facsimile.
<em>Facsimile ed</em>. (<em>1</em>): 1939, as above with a loose leaf containing a colophon text in Japanese.
	<em>Copy</em>: FAS. – Published by Shokonutsu-Bunken-Kankôkwa, Tokyo 1939. Oct. – This
	edition was prepared by T. Nakai, who is also the author of an accompanying booklet in
	Japanese "on the Japanese facsimile reprint of Linnaeus's Genera plantarum (ed. 5)"
	which contains a short biography of Linnaeus and explanatory notes. The edition of the
	facsimile and of Nakai's text numbered 400 copies (Bryk no. 9).
<em>Facsimile ed. (2</em>): 1960, p. [i]-xxiv and repr. of Ehret plate, introduction by W. T. Stearn,
	followed by facsimile of ed. 5 as above. <em>Copy</em>: FAS. – STR 5381. – "Carl Linnaeus Genera
	plantarum fifth edition 1754 with an introduction by William T. Stearn. 1960 facsimile
	by H. R. Engelmann (J. Cramer) and Wheldon &amp; Wesley, Ltd., Weinheim/Bergstr.
	Codicote/Herts., Historiae naturalis classica, tomus iii. – The introduction by W. T.
	Stearn is of importance for the understanding of all editions of the <em>Genera plantarum</em>; it has
	e.g. an explanation of L's references; a list of secondary literature; and a chapter on the
	typification of Linnaean genera. – ISBN 3-7682-0014-0.
<em>Further secondary refs</em>.: In addition to Stearn's introduction see SO 302-304b; F. Bryk, Taxon
	3: 165-183. 1954, Dandy (1967), Stafleu (1971, p. 101-103), and van Eeghen (1979).
<em>Typification</em>: (1) Standard-species of Linnaean genera of phanerogamae (1753-54), by A. S.
	Hitchcock and M. L. Green, <em>in</em> J. Ramsbottom et al., Proposals by British botanists, Int.
	Bot. Congr., Cambridge 1930, p. 110-199. 1929. – These choices were never accepted as
	an integral part of the International Code of Botanical Nomenclature. They were
	published choices of lectotype-species which have to be followed if they are the first and
	as long as they are not shown to be erroneous (ICBN Art. 8.1).
	(2) W. T. Stearn provides references to choices of lectotype-species of Linnaean genera in
	the index, p. 103-148 appended to part 2 of the Ray Society facsimile of the <em>Species
	plantarum</em> (1959) (see Linnaeus, Sp. pl., 1753, no. 5). This index is now the most
	important list to be consulted when establishing the types of Linnaean generic names.
	(3) E. R. Farr, J. A. Leussink and F. A. Stafleu, <em>Index nominum genericorum</em>, 3 vols.,
	Utrecht/The Hague 1979, provides choices of lectotype-species based on the data
	provided by Stearn and others.
<em>Ref</em>.: Stearn, W. T., Notes on Linnaeus's "Genera Plantarum," in Gen. pl., ed. 5, facs. ed.
	1960, p. v-xxiv.
	Bryk, F., Taxon 3: 178-179. 1954 (collation).
	Eeghen, I. H. van, Holland 11(2): 112-117. 1979 (the Genera plantarum in Holland).

<em>Publ</em>.: 28 Sep 1757, p. [i-vi], [1]-16, [1-2]. <em>Copy</em>: MO. – Other eds. and studies: SO 1975-
	1982; <em>Amoen. acad.</em> 5(83): 106-119. 1760, <em>Amoen. acad., Schreber ed.</em> 5(83): 106-119. 1788. –
	On "change "of wheat into rye, denied by L. (ergot).

4794. Caroli Linnaei ... <em>Syslema naturae</em> per regna tria naturae, secundum classes, ordines,
genera, species, cum characteribus, differentiis, synonymis, locis. Tomus I[II]. Editio
decima, reformata ... Holmiae [Stockholm] (Impensis direct. Laurentii Salvii) 1758 [-
1759]. Oct. (<em>Syst. nat. ed. 10</em>). (SO 58, STR 5935). 

<em>Orig. ed</em>.: 1758-1759, 2 vols. <em>Copies</em>: G, MO, U, US, USDA; IDC 740.
	<em>1</em> (<em>Animalia</em>): 1 Jan 1758, p. [i-iv], [1]-823, [824, err.]. Starting point for zoological
	nomenclature. Binomial nomenclature used throughout.
	2 (<em>Vegetabilia</em>): Mai-Jun 1759 (Lärda Tidn. 7 Jun 1759), p. [i-iv], 825-1384.<em>
	3</em> (<em>Mineralia</em>): not published, mss. at LINN.<em>
	Reviews</em>: See SO 58.
<em>Reprint</em> [actually <em>ed. 11.</em>] ("<em>pirated</em>"): 1760, 1: [i-viii], [1]-823, [824, err.], 2: [i-iv], [825]-
	1380. <em>Copies</em>: G, MO. – SO 60. – "Tomus I. Praefectus est Joannes Joachim Langius [see
	above, ed. 3] ... ad editionem decimam reformatam holmiensem. [Tomus II. Ad
	editionem ...] Halae magdeburgicae [Halle a.S.] (typis et sumtibus Jo. Jac. Curt.) 1760.
	Oct. Reprinted literally up to p. 1352, p. 1353-1380 with changed setting. This edition,
	however, has Tomus III, Regnum lapidem, 1770, apparently based on ed. 12. – Called
	ed. 11 by Krok (p. 425) and Tournay (1953). – STR 5940.
<em>Facsimile ed</em>. (of <em>Tomus II</em>): 1964, p. [i*-iv* new t.p.'s], [i-iv], 825-1384. <em>Copy</em>: FAS. – STR
	5939. – "Carl Linnaeus <em>Systema naturae</em> editio decima 1759 tomus ii: Vegetabilia 1964
	facsimile by J. Cramer. Weinheim ... Codicote, Herts. New York, N.Y.", Historiae
	naturalis classica ... tomus xxxiv. ISBN 3-7682-0219-4.
<em>Secondary literature and indexes</em>: See SO 66-81, of which botanical:
	66. <em>Namenclator extemporaneus</em>, 1759. See below.
	67. <em>Index plantarum</em>... 1761, by G. C. Oeder, q.v.
	73. <em>Natuurlijke historie</em>... 1773-1783, by M. Houttuyn, see TL-2/3080, 3081; plants only
	partly based on ed. 12 (not 10).
	74. <em>Vademecum botanico</em>, by C. Bianchi, 1763, n.v.
	75. <em>Sistema der natuurlijke historie</em>, Hagae-Comitum, 1765, n.v.
	<em>See also</em>: Baum, B. R., Taxon 17: 507-513. 1968 (typification).

4795. D. F. G. Dissertatio medica, de <em>Spigelia anthelmia</em>, quam consens, experient. Facult.
medic. in illustri Lycaeo Upsaliensi sub praesidio ... Caroli Linnaei, ad publicum examen
defert Joh. Georg. Colliander, ... Smolandus. In Audit. carol. maj. d. xxii [mss. changed to
xxx] Martii, anni mdcclviii. H. A. &amp; P. M. S. Upsaliae (Excud. L. M. Höjer, Reg. Acad.
Typog.) [1758]. Qu. (<em>Spigelia</em>). (SO 1987, KR p. 130, no. 1, STR 4966). 

<em>Author</em> (fide KR): Johan Georg Colliander (1728-1796).
<em>Publ</em>.: 30 Mar 1758, p. [1]-16, <em>1 pl</em>. (uncol. copp.). <em>Copies</em>: MO(2), US, USDA. – Further
	eds. SO 1988-1990; <em>Amoen. acad.</em> 5(85): 133-147. 1760, <em>Amoen. acad., Schreber ed.</em> 5(85): 133-
	147. 1788.

medica in Regia Academia Upsaliensi praeside, ... Carolo Linnaeo, ... publicae ventila-

Maji anni mdcclviii. H. A. M. S. Upsaliae. Excud. L. M. Höjer, Reg. Acad. Typogr.)
[1758]. Qu. (<em>Cort. peruv.</em>). (SO 1991, KR p. 572, no. 1, STR 4924). 

<em>Author</em> (fide KR): Johan Christian Petersen (1739-1774).
<em>First issue</em>: 10 Mai 1758, p. [i-ii], [1]-38. <em>Copy</em>: MO.

4797. Q.F.F.Q.S. <em>Frutetum svecicum</em>, quod consens. experient. Facult. medicae in illustri
Lycaeo Upsal. praeside ... Carolo Linnaeo, ... publico erudit. exam. modeste subjicit
David Magn. Virgander, Smolandus. In Audit. carol. majori die xxiii. maji anni mdcclviii.
H. A. M. S. Upsaliae (Excud. L. M. Höjer, Reg. Acad. Typogr.) [1758]. Qu. (<em>Frut. svec.</em>).
(SO 1994, KR 18, STR 5013). 

<em>Publ</em>.: 23 Mai 1758, p. [i-ii], [1]-28. <em>Copies</em>: MO(2), US, USDA. – Other editions: SO 1995-
	2000; <em>Amoen. acad.</em> 5(88): 204-231. 1760, <em>Amoen. acad., Schreber ed.</em> 5(88): 204-231. 1788.

4798. Caroli Linnaei ... <em>Opera varia</em> in quibus continentur Fundamenta botanica, sponsa-
lia plantarum, et Systema naturae, in quo proponuntur naturae regna tria secundum
classes, ordines, genera &amp; species. Lucae [Lucca] (ex Typographia Juntiniana) 1758. Oct.
(<em>Opera var</em>.). (SO 6, STR 5600). 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1758, p. [i, iii], [1]-376, <em>1 pl</em>. (uncol. copp. engr.). <em>Copies</em>: MO, USDA; IDC 7297. –
	The <em>Fundamenta botanica</em> is a reprint of the second edition (1740), the <em>Sponsalia plantarum</em> of
	the 1746 edition. The <em>Systema naturae</em> is a reprint with slight alterations of the fourth
	edition, Paris 1744 (see also p. 154); the new genera present in ed. 4 (and not in ed. 2) are
	contained in the <em>Opera varia</em>. – The part on <em>Regnum vegetabile</em> (p. 195-274) contains
	references by means of single letters (explained on p. 198) to previous authors such as
	Tournefort (T.). These references are easily traceable and several pre-linnaean names
	(see Dandy 1967) are first validated by this procedure in this publication. – Counted as
	the ninth edition of the Systema by Krok (p. 425).
<em>Ref</em>.: Barneby, R. C., Taxon 14: 163. 1965.
	Dandy, J. E., Regn. veg. 51: 15. 1967.
	Skog, L. E., in litt. 13 Aug 1975 (comparison with Syst. nat. ed. 4).

4799. C. Linnaei, Eqv. <em>Delinealio plantae</em>, in usum auditorum. [on p. 8: Upsaliae, Apud
Christ. Erh. Steinert, 1758]. Oct. (<em>Delin. pl.</em>). (SO 550, KR 141, STR 4834). 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1758 (date on p. 1758; the HH copy has a note in ink above the colophon "die 19.
	aprilis 1759"), p. [1]-8. <em>Copy</em>: HH. – An elaboration of aphorisms 78-87 of the <em>Fundamenta
	botanica</em>, later incorporated in the regnum vegetabile sections of Syst. nat. ed. 10 and
	following. A further, much enlarged, version was published as <em>Termini botanici</em> 1781. SO
	mentions another copy of this at Leiden (University Library), not seen by us. For other
	editions see SO 551-556.
<em>Latin and dutch version</em>: in D. de Gorter, <em>Leer der plantkunde</em> 1: 33-76. 1782.
<em>English version</em>: in C. Darwin, <em>A system of vegetables</em> 1: 13-21. 1783. – STR 4837.
<em>German version</em>: X. J. Lippert, <em>Des Ritters Carl von Linné Pflanzensystem</em> 1: xvii, xli. 1786. STR
	5976, TL-2/4864.

4800. D.F.G. <em>Auctores botanici</em> in dissertatione propositi, quam consens. experient. Facult.
medic. in illustri Lycaeo Upsaliensi, sub praesidio ... Caroli Linnaei ... ad publicum
examen defert ... Augustinus Loo, Ostrogothus. In Audit. carol. maj. die xiv. mart. anni
mdcclix. H. A. M. S. Upsaliae [1759]. Qu. (<em>Auct. bot.</em>). (SO 2017, KR 150, STR 4867). 

<em>Publ</em>.: 14 Mar 1759, p. [i-ii], [1]-20. <em>Copies</em>: MO, US, USDA. – Further eds. SO 2018-2021;
	<em>Amoen. acad.</em> 5(91): 273-297. 1760, <em>Amoen. acad., Schreber ed.</em> 5(91): 273-297. 1788.

4805. D. D. <em>Plantarum jamaicensium pugillus</em>, quem consens, experient. Fac. medicae in Regia

4806. D.F.G. <em>Flora jamaicensis</em>, quam indultu nobil. nec non exper. ord. med. in supremo ad
Salam Athenaeo, praeside ... Carolo Linnaeo, ... publicae erudit censurae submittit
Carolus Gust. Sandmark, Vermelandus. In audit. car. maj. ad diem [mss.: xxii] Decembr.
Anni mdcclix. H.A.M.S. Upsaliae [1759]. Qu. (<em>Fl. jamaic.</em>). (SO 2087, KR 32, STR 5002). 

<em>Publ</em>.: 22 Dec 1759, p. [1]-27, [28]. <em>Copy</em>: MO. – Other eds. 2088-2090; <em>Amoen. acad.</em> 5(96):
	371-388. 1760, <em>Amoen. acad., Schreber ed.</em> 5(96): 371-388. 1788 (dated 13 Dec). – Mainly
	based on P. Browne, <em>Civ. nat. hist. Jamaica</em>, 1756 (TL-2/842) and H. Sloane, <em>Voy. Madera
	Jamaica</em> 1707-1725. Browne gave his material to Linnaeus; the Sloane material is at BM.
	The version in the <em>Amoen. acad.</em> is revised. See also DA 1967.

	generic names in Dutch, English, French, German, and Italian, mainly of European and
	garden taxa.

4813. D.F.G. <em>Termini botanici</em>, quos consensu experient. Fac. medicae in Reg. Acad.

(<em>Term. bot.</em>). (SO 2174, KR 142, STR 5240). 

<em>Publ</em>.: 22 Jun 1762, p. [1]-32. <em>Copies</em>: MO(2). – Other eds. and studies: SO 2175-2201;
	<em>Amoen. acad.</em> 6(113): 217-246. 1763, <em>Amoen. acad., Schreber ed.</em> 6(113): 217-246. 1789. For
	English translations in James Lee, <em>Intr. bot.</em> see TL-2/4289, in J. Berkenhout see TL-
	2/466. See also KR p. 453-454 (lists nine eds.).
<em>German ed</em>. 1: 1781, p. [i-xiv], [1]-219, [220-221, err.]. <em>Copies</em>: M, MO, U. – "Caroli a Linné
	... <em>Termini botanici</em> classium methodi sexualis generumque plantarum characteres com-
	pendiosi. Recudi curavit primos cum suis definitionibus interpretatione germanica
	donatos Paulus Dietericus Giseke [1747-1796; see Tl-2/1: 949-950] ... Hamburgi (sum-
	tibus B. Chr. Heroldi viduae excudit Car. Wilh. Meyn) 1781. Oct. – Actually a new
	work, a compendium of the Linnaean system and method to be attributed to Giseke. –
	SO 2194, STR 5961.
<em>German ed</em>. 2: 1787, p. [i-xx], [1]-396, 2 charts. <em>Copies</em>: MO, US. – "... compendiosi. Recudi
	cum interpretatione germanica definitionum terminorum curavit Paulus Dietericus
	Giseke ... Editioni huic alteri accesserunt fragmenta ordinum naturalium Linnaei,
	nomina germanica Planeri generum, gallica et anglica terminorum, et indices. Hambur-
	gi (id.) 1787. Oct. – To be attributed to Giseke. – STR 5962.

4815. Q.F.F.S. Dissertatio botanica, sistens de <em>Nectaria florum</em>, quam, consensu nob. atque
exper. Fac. med. in almo Upsal. lycaeo sub praesidio, ... Caroli Linnaei, ... publico
examini offert, Birgerus Martinus Hall, Vestrogothus. In Audit. carol. maj. die xxv Junii,
mdcclxii. Horis ante meridiem consuetis. Upsaliae [1762] Qu. (<em>Nect. fl.</em>). (SO 2206, KR
162, STR 5097). 

<em>Publ</em>.: 25 Jun 1762, p. [i-ii], [1]-16. <em>Copies</em>: MO(2), US, USDA. – Further eds. SO 2207-
	2213; <em>Amoen. acad.</em> 6(115): 263-278. 1763, <em>Amoen. acad., Schreber ed.</em> 6(115): 263-278. 1789.

4816. Q.F.F.Q.S. <em>Fundamentum fructificationis</em>, quod, consens, nobil. et exper. Facult. med.
in illustri ad Salam Svionum, Athenaeo sub praesidio ... Caroli Linnaei, ... publico
eruditorum examini submittit, ... Johannes Mart. Gråberg, Gothoburgensis. In Audit.
carol. maj. die xvi. October. anni mdcclxii. Horis ante meridiem consuetis. Upsaliae
[1762]. Qu. (<em>Fund. fruct.</em>) (SO 2214, KR 167, STR 5021). 

<em>Publ</em>.: 16 Oct 1762, p. [i-iv], [1]-24. <em>Copies</em>: MO(2), USDA. – Further eds. SO 2215-2218;
	<em>Amoen. acad.</em> 6(116): 279-304. 1763, <em>Amoen. acad., Schreber ed.</em> 6(116): 279-304. 1789.

4817. Caroli Linnaei ... <em>Species plantarum</em>, exhibentes plantas rite cognitas, ad genera
relatas, cum differentiis specificis, nominibus trivialibus, synonymis selectis, locis natalibus,
secundum systema sexuale digestas. Tomus I.[II.] ... Editio secunda, aucta ... Holmiae
[Stockholm] (Impensis Direct. Laurentii Salvii) 1762. Oct. (<em>Sp. pl. ed.</em> 2) (SO 500, KR 6,
Bryk 13, STR 5905). 

<em>1</em>: Sep 1762 (Lärda Tidn. 20 Sep 1762), portr., p. [i-xvi], 1-784.
<em>2</em>: Jul-Aug 1763 (Lärda Tidn. 1 Aug 1763), p. [i], 785-1684, [1-64, indexes].
<em>Copies</em>: G, MO, US(2); IDC 175. – The portrait is not always present.– "Generic names
	which first appear in Linnaeus "<em>Species plantarum</em> ed. 1 (1753) and ed. 2 (1762-63) are
	associated with the first subsequent description given under those names in Linnaeus'
	<em>Genera plantarum</em> ed. 5 (1754) and ed. 6(1764). (See Art. 41)". (ICBN Art. 13.4). This
	means that new generic names published in the <em>Species plantarum</em> ed. 2, even if not
	provided with a generic description are validly published in the <em>Species plantarum</em> and date
	from 1762 or 1763.
<em>Supplements</em> by Linnaeus: see <em>Mantissa plantarum</em>, 1767-1770, TL-2/4831.
<em>Supplement</em> by Linnaeus fil.: see C. Linnaeus fil., <em>Supplementum plantarum</em>, 1781, TL-2/4854.
<em>Indexes</em>: by A. J. Retzius, <em>Nomenclator botanicus</em>, Lipsiae [Leipzig] 1772, editio nova, 1782,
	editio tertia by E. A. Räuschel, 1797, see under Räuschel and Retzius (SO 504-506).
<em>Supplementary studies</em>: see SO 507-509; and the Bryk, Heller and Stearn publications listed
	under <em>Sp. pl.</em> ed. 1.

4818. D.F.G. <em>Reformatio botanices</em>, quam cons. nobil. et exper. Facult. med. in illustri Athen.
upsaliensi, praeside ... Carolo Linnaeo, ... publico examini modeste submittit, ...Joannes
Mart. Reftelius, Uplandus. In Audit. Gustav. die xviii. Decembr. anni mdcclxii. H.A.M.S.
Upsaliae [1762]. Qu. (<em>Reform. bot.</em>) (SO 2223, KR 146, STR 5204). 

<em>Publ</em>.: 17 Dec 1762, p. [i-iv], [1]-21, [22-23]. <em>Copies</em>: MO, USDA. – Other eds. SO 2224-
	2227; <em>Amoen. acad.</em> 6(117): 305-323. 1763, <em>Amoen. acad., Schreber ed.</em> 6(117): 305-323. 1789.
	– SO: "Three epochs: I. Under the founders of botany, after the Renaissance. 2. Under
	the Systematics. 3. Under Linnaeus. In (3) are given the pupils of Linnaeus, who
	travelled abroad, and the writers, who followed the Linnaean system."

PAGE: 105
HEADING: LINNAEUS (1764)

4823. Caroli v. Linné ... <em>Genera plantarum</em> eorumque characteres naturales secundum
numerum, figuram, situm, et proportionem omnium fructificationis partium. Editio sexta
ab auctore reformata et aucta ... Holmiae [Stockholm], (impensis direct. Laurentii Salvii)
1764. Oct. (<em>Gen. pl. ed. 6</em>) (SO 305, KR 2, STR 5382). 

<em>Publ</em>.: Jun 1764 ("autoreferat" Lärda Tidn. 14 Jun 1764), portr., p. [i*-iv*], [i]-xx, [1]-
	580, [1-44, index, err.]. <em>Copies</em>: G, HU, MO(2), US(3), USDA; IDC 166. – Some copies
	have a portrait of L. by P. Tanjé (e.g. Sandberg 49, 50). – The generic names published
	here are associated with those in the <em>Species plantarum</em> ed. 2; new generic names occurring
	in these two works therefore date from their first appearance in the <em>Species plantarum</em> ed. 2.
<em>Secondary references and reprints</em>: See SO 306-310 and 315-319b., Bryk, Taxon 3: 179-180.
	1954, and Steam's introd. to the 1960 facs. of ed. 5.
<em>Additions</em>: see <em>Mant. pl.</em> 2, 1764 and Linnaeus f, <em>Suppl. pl.</em> 1781 (TL-2/4854).
<em>Further editions</em>: The <em>editio novissima</em>, Wien 1767, treated below (TL-2/4833, STR 5383) is a
	straightforward reprint of ed. 6; for eds. 7-9 see under J. J. Reichard, J. C. D. Schreber,
	Th. Haenke, Mouton-Fontenille and K. J. P. Sprengel. Partial reprints will be found
	under C. Milne and J. J. Planer.

4825. <em>Opobalsamum declaratum</em> in dissertatione medica, cum consensu exper. Facultat.

	ma</em>, on p. 17 (Urticaceae).

4826. Caroli Linnaei ... <em>Species plantarum</em>, exhibentes plantas rite cognitas ad genera
relatas, cum differentiis specificis, nominibus trivialibus, synonymis selectis, locis natalibus,
secundum systema sexuale digestas Tomus I [II]. Editio tertia. Vindobonae [Wien].

<em>Copies</em>: G, MO, US(2). – For references see under <em>Sp. pl.</em> eds. 1 and 2, above. This is a
	straightforward reprint of the second edition except for the insertion of the errata in the
	main text. This edition was published by J. T. von Trattner, but probably edited
	by N. J.
	Jacquin who brought about a few minor changes.
<em>Ref</em>.: Bryk, F., Taxon 2: 80. 1953.

	Published separately and as an independent appendix to vol. 2 of Syst. nat. ed. 12.
<em>Mantissa</em> [<em>1</em>], <em>reprint</em>: 1770, p. [1]-142, [1-2]. <em>Copies</em>: G, HH, MO, US(2). – Issued with <em>Syst</em>.
	<em>nat. ed. 13</em>, see below (SO 311b, STR 5535, TL-2/4832).

	naturalis classica tomus vii. ISBN 3-7682-0037-x; STR 5536.
<em>Commentaries and secondary literature</em>: For a detailed discussion of the Mantissa, its position
	with respect to contemporary publications and for lists of abbreviations and main
	literature see Stearn's <em>Introduction</em> to the Weinheim facsimile of 1961. It should be noted
	that a certain number of copies of this facsimile have as title-page a facsimile of the title-
	page of the Mantissa altera of 1771. For further details see J. E. Dandy (1967), HU 596,
	SO 62, 116, 311-314; Th. A. Sprague (Bull. misc. Inf. Kew 1929: 88), F. Bryk, Taxon 2:
	83-84. 1953; and H. W. Rickett and F. A. Stafleu, Taxon 10: 115. 1961.

genera, species cum characteribus, dilferentiis, synonymis, locis. Tomus I [-III]. Editio

4834. D. A. Dissertatio botanico-medica sistens <em>Rariora Norvegiae</em>, quam cons. nobiliss. &amp;
experientiss. Fac. med. Ups. praeside ... Carolo à Linné, ... pro gradu doctoris publice
ventilandam offert Henricus Tonning, Norvego-Nidrosiensis ... in Auditorio carolino
majori die 27 Februarii 1768. H. A. et P. M. S. Upsaliae (Litteris Johan Edman, Reg. Acad.
Typogr.) [1768]. Qu. (<em>Rar. Norveg.</em>). (SO 2381, KR p. 721, no. 1, STR 5203). 

<em>Author</em> (fide KR): Heinrich Tonning (1732-1796).
<em>Publ</em>.: 27 Feb 1768, p. [i-vi], [1]-19, [20]. <em>Copies</em>: HU, MO, US, USDA. – Other eds. SO
	2382-2384; <em>Amoen. acad.</em> 7(149): 466-496. 1769, <em>Amoen. acad., Schreber ed.</em> 7(149): 466-496.
	1789. – <em>The Corollarium de Gunnera</em> on p. 18-19 must be attributed to Linnaeus himself.

HEADING: LINNAEUS (1774)

4844a. Caroli a Linné ... <em>Systema vegetabilium</em> secundum classes ordines genera species cum
characteribus et differentiis. <em>Editio decima tertia</em> accessionibus et emendationibus novissimis
manu perillustris auctoris scriptis adornata a Joanne Andrea Murray D. ... Gottingae
[Göttingen] et Gothae [Gotha] (typis et impensis Jo. Christ. Dietrich) 1774. Oct. (<em>Syst. veg.</em>
<em>ed. 13</em>). (SO 573, STR 6838). 

<em>Authorship</em>: Linnaeus is the author of the botanical novelties ("manu perillustris auctoris
	scriptis"). Johann Andreas Murray (1740-1791) acted as editor.
<em>Publ</em>.: Apr-Jun 1774 (TL-1/902, p. [i-vii], [1]-844). <em>Copies</em>: FI, G, MO, USDA. – A new
	edition of the botanical part of the <em>Systema naturae</em>, counting on from ed. 12 (TL-2/4829).
<em>English translation</em>: 1783, 2 vols, 1: [i*, iii*], [i]-lvi, [1]-424, 2: [i, iii], [425]-897, catalogue
	dated 1784: [1-16], <em>pl. 1-11</em> (with text). <em>Copies</em>: FH, MO. – <em>A system of vegetables</em>, according
	to their classes ... translated from the thirteenth edition (as published by Dr. Murray) of
	the vegetabilium of the late professor Linnaeus; and from the Supplementum plantarum
	of the present professor Linnaeus ... by a botanical society, [i.e. Erasmus Darwin et al.]
	at Lichfield. Lichfield (printed by John Jackson,...) London, 2 vols. Oct. SO 580a (580
	is a unique proof copy dated 1782).

4851. D. D. <em>Hypericum</em>, quod, dissertatione botanico-medica, consens. exper. Facult. med.
Upsal. praeside Carolo à Linné, ... pro gradu doctoris in Audit. carol. maj. die 20 Nov. a.
1776. Horis a. et p.m. solitis. Exhibet Carolus Nicol. Hellenius, Tavastia-Fenno, ...
Upsaliae (Typis Edmannianis) [1776]. Qu. (<em>Hypericum</em>). (SO 2459, KR p. 283, no. 1, TL-
2/2609, STR 5047). 

<em>Author</em> (fide KR): Carl Niklas Hellenius (1745-1820).
<em>Publ</em>.: 20 Nov 1776, p. [i-iv], [1]-14, <em>1 pl</em>. (uncol. copp. Joh. Afzelius). <em>Copies</em>: HU, MICH,
	MO(2), NY, US, USDA. – The t.p. mentions Linnaeus as the promotor; actually
	Linnaeus fil. acted as praeses on behalf of his father. This was therefore the last
	dissertation written under Linnaeus; the last one actually defended was Acharius, <em>Pl.
	Aphyt.</em>
<em>Other ed</em>. SO 2460; <em>Amoen. acad., Schreber. ed</em> 8(171): 318-332. 1785.

Linné, Carl von, filius (1741-1783), Swedish botanist; studied at Uppsala, Dr. med.
1765, professor of medicine and botany ib. 1777-1783. (<em>L. fil.</em>)

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: The Linnaeus filius herbarium is partly at S, partly in the Smith
herbarium at LINN. Some types are at S but most are at LINN.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 656; Barnhart 2: 389; BFM no. 2293, 2294; BJI 2:
107; BL 2: 512, 516, 683; Blunt p. 300 [index]; BM 3: 1150-1151; Bret. p. 63; Collander hist.
p. 156; Dawson p. 544-545; Dryander 5: 333 [index]; GR p. 478; Henrey 2: 727; Hortus 3:
1197; Jackson p. 574; KR p. 463-465; Lasègue p. 45, 179, 330; NI 1216; PR 5526-5529 (ed.
1: 6163-6167); RS p. 116; SBC p. 126; SO 309, 502, 574, 2801, 3821-3874; TL-1/769, 770-
773; TL-2/2609; TR 810-812; Tucker 1: 434-435, 567; Zander ed. 10, p. 682, ed. 11, p. 777.
Candolle, Alph. de, Phytographie 429. 1880 (coll.).
Eriksson, G., Bot. hist. Sverige 360 [index]. 1969.

	5: 60, 326. 1911, 6: 2, 219, 258. 1912, 7: 75, 76, 88, 93, 94, 96, 185. 1917.

	portr., 102, 10 p.

	2: 296 [index, many refs.]. 1943.

HEADING: LINNÉ FIL.

Wittrock, V. B., Acta Horti Berg 3(2): 60. 1903, 3(3): 42. <em>pl. 100.</em> 1905 (portr.).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: W. T. Aiton, <em>Hort. kew.</em> 1: 403-405, 413, 414, 415-421, 460, 3: 473, 477-
478. 1789; descriptions of new taxa by L. fil., listed by KR p. 464, based on a manuscript
"Descriptiones Liliorum et Palmarum" at LINN.

<sm>DISSERTATIONS</sm> defended under Linnaeus f. but not written by him:
1. Naezén, D. E., <em>Nova graminum genera</em>, 1779, TL-2/6620, STR 6862.
2. Lundmark, J. D., <em>De Lavandula</em>, 1780, TL-2/5107, STR 6049.
3. Swartz, O., <em>Methodus muscorum illustrata</em>, 1781, STR 6052.
The Linnaean dissertation <em>Hypericum</em> (1776), by C. N. Hellenius was still written to be
defended under Linnaeus himself, but was actually defended under Linnaeus f. (STR 5047,
TL-2/4851).

4852. Carolo Linnaei fil.... <em>Decas</em> prima [secunda] <em>plantarum rariorum horti upsaliensis</em> sistens
descriptiones &amp; figuras plantarum minus cognitarum. Stockholmiae (sumtu &amp; literis
Direct. Laurentii Salvii) 1762 [-1763]. Fol. (<em>Dec. pl. horti upsal.</em>) (SO 3822, STR 6064). 

<em>1</em>: Apr-Jul 1762, p. [i-vi], [1]-20, <em>pl. 1-10</em> (uncol. copp. A. Åkerman).
<em>2</em>: Dec 1763, p. [i-ii], 21-40, <em>pl. 11-20</em> (id.). <em>Copies</em>: M; IDC 5504. – See also Dandy (1967). –
	Decas I was ready on 4 Jul 1762. Linnaeus writes to Jacquin on that day "Filius meus
	edit decurias rariorum plantarum in folio, cujus prima decuria sudat [sic], et continet
	..."
<em>Ref</em>.: Dandy, J. E., Regn. veg. 51: 16. 1967.
	Schreibers, C.N.J. et S. Endlicher, Caroli Linnaei epistolae ad Nicolaum Josephum
	Jacquin,... Wien, p. 57 (1841).

4853. Caroli C. [sic] a Linné ... <em>Plantarum rariorum horti upsaliensis</em> fasciculus primus sistens
descriptiones et figuras plantarum minus cognitarum. Lipsiae [Leipzig], (impensis Sieg-
fried Lebrecht Crusii) 1767. Fol. (<em>Pl. rar. hort. upsal.</em>). (SO 3822, STR 6065). 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1767, p. [i, iii], 1-20, <em>pl. 1-10</em> (uncol. copp.). <em>Copy</em> G. – Different from <em>Dec. pl. hort. upsal.</em>

4854. <em>Supplementum plantarum</em> systematis vegetabilium editionis decimae tertiae, generum
plantarum editionis sextae, et specierum plantarum editionis secundae. Editum a Carolo a
Linné,... Brunsvigae [Braunschweig] (Impensis orphanotrophei) 1781. Oct. (<em>Suppl. pl.</em>).
(SO 547, 3835, STR 6066). 

<em>Publ</em>.: Apr 1782, p. [i-xvi], [1]-467, [468, err.]. <em>Copies</em>: MO, NY, US(2), USDA; IDC 174. –
	Manitz (1976) has shown that the book was not published in 1781, So far the only
	indication with respect to a more precise date was Wikström's statement that Ehrhart
	supervised the printing during the summer of 1781. This is confirmed by the letters from
	Fr. Ehrhart to Linnaeus fil. at LINN. Ehrhart sent the first copy of the Supplement to
	Linnaeus fil. only on 8 Apr 1782, adding that the rest was waiting to be despatched. It
	seems unlikely that any distribution took place before that date, and perhaps even for
	some time afterwards because in July Ehrhart reports that the copies are still with him.
	The first review known to us appeared in NZgS on 31 Oct 1782; a preliminary note,
	evidently written before the actual publication, not citing correct details, appeared in
	NZgS of 17 Mai 1781. Manitz provides also a detailed discussion of the authorship of the
	new taxa in the <em>Suppl. pl.</em> – For further editions containing parts of the text see SO 3836-
	3838.
<em>German transl</em>.: see J. J. Planer, Nachtr. sechst. Ausg., Gotha 1785.

Linton, Edward Francis (1848-1928), English botanist of independent means; Univ.
College Oxford D. A. 1871, M. A. 1874; 1871-1875 curate at St. Paul's, Preston; 1875-1878
rector at St. George's-in-the-Fields; 1878-1888 vicar at Sprowston, Norfolk; 1888-1901
retired at Bournemouth; 1901-1920 rector at Edmondsham, Dorset; ultimately at South-
bourne, Hampshire. (<em>E. Linton</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM (British pl., 14.000), CGE (foreign). Distributed <em>Sets of British
willows</em> (6 fasc., 1892-1898, 1912-1913); <em>British Rubi, in dried specimens</em>, with W. R. Linton, R.
P. Murray and W. Moyle Rogers (125 nos. in 5 fasc., 1892-1895), and <em>Sets of British Hieracia</em>,
with W. R. Linton, fasc. 1-4, 1896-1898, nos. 1-100. For further details see IH and Kent.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 4: 255; Barnhart 2: 389; BL 2: 683; BM 3: 1152; Clokie

Lipp, Franz Joseph (1731-1775), German botanist at Freiburg im Breisgau, "Protomedi-
kus von Vorderösterreich." (<em>Lipp</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

469a, 551; Tucker 1: 435.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Lippaya</em> Endlicher (1834) commemorates Georg Lippay, Baron of Szombor and
Archbishop of Esztergom in Hungary, who founded a botanical garden in Endlicher's place
of birth Pressburg (now Bratislava, Czechoslovakia); as well as his brother, the priest
Johann (Janós) Lippay (1606-1660), a horticulturist who wrote a catalogue of the plants in
that garden. <em>Lippia</em> Linnaeus (1753) commemorates Augustin Lippi (1678-1709), French
traveller and botanist who collected in Egypt and was murdered in Abyssinia. The
etymology of <em>Lippius</em> S. F. Gray (1821, <em>nom. rej.</em>) could not be established.

	...) 1779. Oct.

(<em>Lippmaa</em>).

Lister, Arthur (1830-1908), English wine merchant and mycologist living in Bedfordshi-
re, then at Bradford, since 1857 at Leytonstone nr. London; retired from business 1888 and
often residing also at Lyme Regis; leading authority on myxomycetes.(<em>List</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Main collection, including slides, at BM; other material at B, DBN,
E, K, L.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Ainsworth p. 234, 321; Barnhart 2: 391; BB p. 189; BM 3:

Hawksworth p. 184, 196; IH 2: 450; Kelly p. 130-131; Kew 3: 470; LS 15709-15738, 36156-

Lister, Guilielma (1860-1949), British botanist; daughter of Arthur Lister; educated at
home; constant companion of her father in his studies on Mycetozoa. (<em>G. List.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BCW (3000 British plants), SRD (340, conif), myxomycetes at BM
and L. Letters and mss. at K.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Ainsworth p. 60, 234, 325; Barnhart 2: 391; BL 2: 240, 683;
BM 3: 1154, 7: 732; CSP 16: 812; Desmond p. 388; Hawksworth p. 184; IH 2: 451; Kelly p.
131; Kew 3: 470; LS 36163-36165, suppl. 16329-16368; MW p. 280; NAF 1(1): 164; SO
3510; Stevenson p. 1249; TL-2/2357.
Ainsworth, G. C. &amp; F. L. Balfour-Browne, Nature 188: 362-363. 1960.
Anon., The Times 6 Jun 1949.
Bisby, G. R., Trans. Brit. Mycol. Soc, Fifty-Year index 16. 1952 (bibl.).
Kent, D. H., Brit. herb. 65. 1957.
Praeger, R. L., Some Irish naturalists 120-121. 1949.
Ramsbottom, J., Nature 164: 94. 1949.
Wakefield, E. M., Trans. Brit. mycol. Soc. 33: 165-166. 1950 (portr.; b. 28 Oct 1860, d. 18
	Mai 1949).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Miss Lister published eds. 2-3 of her father's <em>Monogr. Mycetozoa</em> as
well as eds. 3-4 of his <em>Guide Bril. mycetozoa</em> (see above).
(2) Made drawings for F. J. Hanbury, <em>Ill. monogr. Brit. Hierac.</em> (1889-98) and for A.
Dallimore &amp; A. B. Jackson, <em>A handbook of Coniferae</em> (1923).

Litardière, René de (1888-1957), French botanist; Lic. Sci. Univ. Poitiers 1908, Dr. Sci.
nat. Paris 1921; 1920-1931 at the University of Lille, from 1931-1954 at the Faculté des

Litschauer, Viktor (1879-1939), Austrian mycologist; studied at Vienna under v. Höh-
nel 1899-1903; lecturer at the Vienna "Gewerbemuseum" 1903-1908; from 1908-1936
professor of natural history at the "Handelsakademie", Innsbruck. (<em>Litsch</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: W. – <em>Fungi selecti exsiccati europaei</em> (with H. Lohwag) (nos. 1-200,

Lloyd, Curtis Gates (1859-1926), American pharmaceutical industrialist, wholesale

<sm>NAME</sm>: C. G. Lloyd assumed the pseudonym Professor N.J. McGinty for his discovery of the
name <em>Anthropomorphus</em> Seger (1688) as an earlier synonym of <em>Geaster</em>. McGinty belonged to
the Poseyville Fungus Forage Club. The publication was a satire on Otto Kuntze (Mycol.
writings 2: 260). See also Donk, Reinwardtia 1: 205. 1951.

<sm>NOMENCILATOR</sm>: <em>The new fungus names proposed by C. G. Lloyd</em>, see John A. Stevenson and Edith
K. Cash, Bull. Lloyd Libr. 35, 1936, mycol. ser. 8, 209 p.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: With J. W. Lloyd editor of the <em>Bulletin of the Lloyd library of bolany</em> 1-6,
1900-1903.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: (<em>genera</em>): <em>Lloydella</em> G. Bresadola (1901); <em>Lloydellopsis</em> Z. Pouzar (1959); <em>Lloydia</em> C.
H. Chow (1935); <em>Sinolloydia</em> C. H. Chow (1936); (journal): <em>Lloydia</em>. A quarterly journal of
biological Science. Cincinnati, Ohio. Vol. 1-x. 1938-x. (also commemorating his brothers
John Uri (1849-1936), American pharmacist and plant chemist, and Nelson Ashley Lloyd,
the first of whom founded the Lloyd Library and Museum in Cincinnati). <em>Note</em>: <em>Lloydiella</em> A.
Ahmad &amp; M. Goldstein (1971), <em>Lloydina</em> A. Ahmad &amp; M. Goldstein (1972), and <em>Neolloydia
</em>N. L. Britton &amp; J. N. Rose (1922) are dedicated to Francis Ernest Lloyd (1868-1947),
American botanist.

4884. <em>Drugs and medicines of North America</em> a publication devoted to the historical and
scientific discussion of the botany, pharmacy, chemistry and therapeutics of the medicinal
plants of North America their constituents, products and sophistications ... Cincinnati (J.
U. &amp; C. G. Lloyd) 1884-1886. Press of Robert Clarke &amp; Co. 2 vols. † (<em>Drugs med. N. Amer.</em>).

Lloyd, George N. (1804-1889), British botanist at Edinburgh. (<em>G. N. Lloyd</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: 1250 sheets at K.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 393; BB p. 190; BM 3: 1159; Desmond p. 390;

Anon., Gard. Chron. 1923(1): 329.
C. V. B. M., Bull. misc. Inf. Kew 1923: 189-190 (herb, at K).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Lloydia</em> Salisbury ex H. G. L. Reichenbach (1830, <em>nom. cons.</em>) is dedicated to
Edward Lloyd (or Lluyd, or Llhwyd) (1660-1709), Welsh antiquary and student of the
flora of his country.

Lobarzewski, Hyacinth Strzemù von (1816-1862), Galician bryologist, professor of

Lobb, Thomas (1820-1894), British plant collector and explorer for Veitch and Son
(1843-1860) who collected in India and the Malesian area. (<em>T. Lobb</em>).

L'Obel, Mathias de [Lobel, Lobelius] (1538-1616), Flemish botanist; worked with
Rondelet at Montpellier 1565-1566; from 1566-1572 in England; from 1572-1584 in the
Netherlands, from 1584 again in England; botanist to James I; curator of Lord Edward
Zouche's garden at Hackney. (<em>Lobel</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: NO herbarium material known to be extant. Legré states that after
Rondelet's death in 1566, Pena and l'Obel went to London, taking their herbaria with
them. At the time of l'Obel's stay with Rondelet at Montpellier herbaria were being made
by Rondelet and his disciples.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 1: 249; Backer p. 333; Barnhart 2: 394; BB p. 191; Blunt
p. 300; BM 3: 1160, 4: 1541; Bossert p. 241; Desmond p. 391; Dryander 5: 335; DSB 8: 435-
436; Frank 3(Anh.): 60; GR p. 97; Hegi 4 (1): 160, 6 (1): 392; Henrey 1: 284, 2: 374; Herder
p. 82, 83, 408; HU 126, 127, 183; Jackson p. 27, 28, 574; JW 1: 446, 2: 196, 3: 360, 4: 396, 5:
245 (q.v. for several unusual sources); Kew 3: 478; Langmanp. 452; Lasègue p. 15, 574; LS
15785; Moebius 24, 32, 37, 120, 142; NI 1218-1220; Oudemans 2: 221; Plesch p. 313-314;
PR 5548-5550; Rehder 5: 518; Saccardo cron. p. xxv; TL-2/4308; Tucker 1: 437.
Arber, A., Herbals 318 [index]. 1953.

Irmisch, T., Bot. Zeit. 23: 299-300. 1865.

4906. <em>Stirpium adversaria nova</em>, perfactis vestigatio luculemtaque accessio ad priscorum,
presertim Dioscoridis &amp; recentiorum, materiam medicam. Quibus propediem accedet

	14, [15-26], [1-3 ills.]. "<em>Nova stirpium adversaria</em>perfacilis vestigatio luculentaque accessio

	Petro Pena et Matthia de Lobel ... quibus accessit appendix cum indice variarum
	linguarum locupletissimo eodem M. de Lobel auctore. Additis Guillielmi Rondelletii
	aliquot remediorum formulis, nunquam antehac in lucem editis." Antverpiae (apud
	Christophorum Plantinum ...) 1576. Qu. (<em>Nov. stirp. advers.</em>)
<em>Co-author of adversaria</em>: Pierre Pena (ca. 1535-ca. 1600). For a first version of these <em>Adversaria

Publ.: 1581 (p. [iv]: Jun 1581), p. [i-viii], 1-816; 1-280, [1-33, indexes, sign. Tt-Xx4 Yy6].
	<em>Copies</em>: BR, G, L, M, NY; IDC 7676. Anonymous, traditionally, but crroncously
	attributed to Lobel. The initiative to republish these 2173 woodcut illustrations without
	text (except for an introductory letter by Plantyn, indexes and names) was taken by
	Gobelius, physician to the Duke of Prussia; the execution was by Plantyn (sec Louis 1957,
	p. 188). For collation see e.g. HU 138; for ills. see NI 1220.
<em>Reissue</em> (1): 1591, p. [i-viii], 1-816, 1-280, [1-54 indexes, sign. + – 7 + 4]. <em>Copies</em>: BR, FI, G,

<em>Reissue</em>(<em>2</em>): 1655, p. [i-xxxviii], 1-170. <em>Copies</em>: FI, NY. – Matthiae de L'Obel M. D.
	Botanographi regii eximii <em>Stirpium illustrationes</em>. Plurimas elaborantes inauditas plantas,

	Londini (typis Tho: Warren, ... ) 1655. Qu. (<em>Stirp. ill.</em>).

Locke, John (1792-1856), American geologist, botanist, physician, inventor; M. D. Yale
1819; from 1823 living at Cincinnati (Ohio), leading a preparatory school from 1823;
professor of chemistry in the Medical College of Ohio from 1835; collaborator in the
geological survey of Ohio. (<em>Locke</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Appl. Cycl. 3: 751; Barnhart 2: 394 (b. 19 Feb 1792, d. 10

Cycl. 2: 105, 106; Lenley p. 463; ME 1: 207, 3: 617; Merrill p. 704, 726; Nickles p. 669-670;

Lodder, Jacomina (1905-x), Dutch mycologist at Delft; specialist on yeasts. (<em>Lodder</em>).

Loddiges, Conrad [L.] (1738-1826), Dutch-born British horticulturist who settled in
England about 1761 as nurseryman at Hackney and who introduced many plants into the
British Isles, especially from the United States. (<em>Lodd</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: some material at CGE and K. – The original drawings from the
Botanical Cabinet are at BM.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 6(1): 707; Barnhart 2: 395; BB p. 192; Blunt p. 209, 212;
BM 1: 207, 3: 1162; Bret. p. 281; Desmond p. 392; Dryander 3: 100, 5: 335; DU 187; Frank
3(Anh.): 60; GF p.85; Henrey 2: 727, 3: 78; Herder p. 146, 287, 360; Hortus 3: 1198
("Lodd."); IH 2: 455; Jackson p. 574; Kew 3: 480; Langman p. 452; Lasègue p. 530, 574;
MW p. 282-284, suppl. p. 210; NI 2228 (sub Botanical Cabinet); Plesch p. 314-315; PR
5558-5561 (ed. 1: 6205-6208); Rehder 5: 519; SK 1: 326; Tucker 1: 437; Zander ed. 10, p.
686, ed. 11, p. 782.
Fletcher, H. H., Story R. Hort. Soc. 11, 92, 136. 1969.

	collected by G. Don in Sierra Leone).

	London. The eleventh edition. London (Printed by W. Wilson, ...) 1818. Oct (in fours).
<em>Ed</em>. <em>12</em>: 1820, p. [1]-55, [56, dated 1 Mar 1820]. <em>Copies</em>: G, NY, US. – "<em>Catalogue</em>... London.

4914. <em>The botanical cabinet</em> consisting of coloured delineations of plants, from all countries,
with a short account of each, directions for mangement &amp;c. London (John and Arthur
Arch, John Hatchard, C. Loddiges &amp; Sons, G. Cooke) 1817-1833, 20 vols. Qu. and Duod.
[simultaneous editions]. (<em>Bot. Cab.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Published by "Conrad Loddiges and sons"; however, the editorial work was done by
	the son, George (1784-1846) only. The drawings are by G. Loddiges, W. Loddiges, Miss
	J. Loddiges, George Cooke, W. I. Cooke, E. W. Cooke, Miss Rebello, T. Boys, W. Miller,
	P. Heath and J. P. Heath; the engravings are by George Cooke. – Published in monthly
	fascicles of 10 plates each. The fascicles make up a volume. 2000 hand-coloured plates
	(and no 684* uncoloured). The quarto edition has fully coloured plates; those of the
	duodecimo edition are partially coloured. E. W. Cooke, in a letter to Berkeley inserted in
	the MICH copy relates, on 22 Oct 1879, that the original drawings were at that time in
	the hands of his mother but that the copper plates were no longer available for making
	further prints: "... the whole of the 2000 copper plates were stolen by one of Loddiges'
	men from his library in the Garden ..." <em>Copies</em>: US(qu.), USDA (Oct.); IDC 5312.

<em>vol</em>. <em>1</em>: 1817 (t.p.) p. [i, t.p.], [4, intr.], <em>pl. 1-100</em> each with 1-2 p. text, [3, index]

Loddiges, George (1784-1846), British horticulturist, nurseryman at Hackney; son of
Conrad Loddiges. (<em>G. Lodd.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Material of cultivated plants at BR, CGE, FI and K. Letters at K.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 334; Barnhart 2: 395; BB p. 192; Bosscrt p. 241;

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: George Loddiges was the main author of the text of <em>The Botanical Cabinet</em>;
he conducted it from 1817-1834.

Löfgren, Albert [Loefgren, Alberto] (1854-1918), Swedish-born botanist who settled
(1874) in Brazil; director of the São Paulo botanical garden 1898-1906; ultimately at the
botanical garden of Rio de Janeiro (<em>Loefgr</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: SP; duplicates see IH.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 395; BL 1: 238, 241, 243, 306; BM 3: 1165, 7:
738; CSP 16: 835; Hortus 3: 1198 ("Löfgr."); IH 2: 455; Kew 3: 481; KR p. 481-482; LS –
36215; Nordstedt p. 11; Rehder 5: 519; Tucker 1: 438; Zander ed. 11, p. 782.
Anon., Arch. Jard. bot. Rio de Janeiro 3: i-iv. 1922 (portr.); Bot. Jahrb. 25(Beibl. 60): 56.
	1898 (app. dir. bot. gard. São Paulo); Bot. Not. 1918: 308 (d. 30 Aug 1918); Nat. Nov.
	20: 338. 1898, 42: 130. 1920; Nuov. Notarisia 30: 103. 1919; Österr. Bot. Z. 48 (Lit.): 279.
	1898; Sv. bot. Tidskr. 13: 122-124. 1919 (obit., portr., b. 11 Sep 1854, d. 30 Aug 1918).
E. Bn., Physis 4: 380-381. 1918.
Hoehne, F. C., Jard. bot. São Paulo 126. 1941 (portr.).
J. C. W., Proc. Linn. Soc. London 131: 57-58. 1919.

Urban, I., Fl. Bras. 1(1): 47. 1906 (itin.).
Willis, J. C, Proc. Linn. Soc. London 131: 57-58. 1919.
Wittrock, V. B., Acta Horti Berg. 3(2): 182, <em>pl. 36.</em> 1903 (portr.) 3(3): 203. 1905 (b. 11 Sep
	1854).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Contributed to: V. B. Wittrock &amp; O. Nordstedt, <em>Algae aquae dulcis
exsiccatae</em>. (2) Translated into Portuguese: E. Warming, <em>Lagoa Santa</em>, 1908. See under
Warming (orig. Danish ed. 1892).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Loefgrenia</em> Gomont (1896); <em>Loefgrenianthus</em> Hoehne (1927).

Löfling, Pehr (Loefling) (1729-1756), Swedish botanist and explorer; to Spain 1751; from
1754-1756 in northern S. America; "Linnaei bästa discipel." (<em>Loefl</em>.)

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: LINN. – Occasional specimens in H, MA, S, SBT.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2(1): 271, 5(1): 688; Barnhart 2: 396; BM 3: 1165, 7:
738-739; Colmeiro 1: clxxxv; Dryander 1: 239, 2: 291, 339, 3: 19, 145, 187, 382, 5: 536;
Frank 3(Anh.): 60; Hegi 7: 559; Herder p. 53; Hortus 3: 1198 ("Loefl."); IH 2: 455; Jackson
p. 339; Kcw 3: 481; KR p. 482-483; Langman p. 452; Lasègue p. 574; PR 5564 (ed. 1:
6213); Rehder 5: 519; RS p. 116; SO 1290, 1556, 2551, add. 2908a, 3588, 3593; TL-1: 774;
Tucker 1: 438; Zander ed. 10, p. 686, ed. 11, p. 782.

<sm>NOTE ON NAME</sm>: Krok (KR p. 482) notes that Löfling signed himself Löfling in at least one
letter now at the library of the Swedish Academy of Sciences; he was registered at Uppsala
as "Petrus Erici Löfling". The orthography "Loefling" was used as a latinization. This
latter orthography is very generally accepted, hence our proposed abbreviation "Loefl.".

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Loeflingia</em> Linnaeus (1753).

4920. D. A. <em>Gemmae arborum</em>, quas ex cons. experientiss. et nobiliss. facult. med. in reg. acad.

naturae curiosis examinandas sistit alumnus regius, Petrus Löfling, medelpadus. In Audit.

4933. <em>Flora prussica</em>, sive plantae in regno Prussiae sponte nascentes. Quarum catalogum &amp;
nomina Johannes Loeselius ... olim disseruit, nunc additis nitidissimis iconibus rariorum,
partim ab aliis nondum delineatarum plerarumque Prussiae propriarum &amp; inquilinarum
plantarum, earumdemque accuratâ descriptione, nec non adjectis synonymiis veterum
botanicorum, interspersisque observationibus historico-philogico-criticis &amp; medico-
practicis noviter efflorescentes, curante Johanne Gottsched,... Regiomonti [Königsberg]
anno mdcciii. Sumptibus typographiae Georgianae. Qu. (<em>Fl. pruss.</em>)

Loew, Ernst (1843-1908), German botanist and flower-biologist; Dr. phil. Berlin 1865;
from 1867-1906 teacher at the (later) Kaiser-Wilhelm-Realgymnasium. (<em>E. Loew</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B.

Löw, Immanuel (1854-1944), Hungarian rabbi and scholar; rabbi of Szeged 1878-1944;
specialist in talmudic and rabbinic lexicography. (<em>I. Löw</em>).

Lohwag, Heinrich (1884-1945), Austrian cryptogamist: student of R. Wettstein; Dr. phil.
Wien 1907; professor at the Staatsgymnasium in Brüx (Bohemia) 1908-1914; from 1914-
1918 at Reichenberg; from 1918 at the first Academic Gymnasium in Wien; from 1928
lecturer, from 1940 professor at the Universität Wien. (<em>H. Lohwag</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Material at MICH, TRTC, W and WU. – For exsiccatae see under
Victor Litschauer.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 398; Bossert p. 242 (b. 10 Mai 1884, d. 22 Sep
1945); IH 2: 456; TL-2/2364; Stevenson p. 1249.
Janchen, E. Richard Wettstein 186. 1933.
Knoll, Fr., Ber. deut. bot. Ges. 68a: 132-134. 1956.
Lohwag, K., Sydowia ser. 2. vol. 3(1-6): 1-16. 1949; id. 3: 1-27. 1949 (bibl.).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) <em>Anatomie der Asco- und Basidiomyceten, in</em> Linsbauer, <em>Handbuch der</em>
<em>Pflanzenanatomie</em>, Band 6, Abt. 2, Teilband 3c, 1941.
(2) Collaborator, Hand.-Mazz., <em>Symb. sin.</em> 2, 1937.

HEADING: LOISELEUR

Loiseleur-Deslongchamps, Jean Louis Auguste (1774-1849), French physician and
botanist; in the French armée des Alpes 1793-1797; Dr. med. Paris 1806; physician at the
"bureau de charité du neuvième arrondissement" later working mainly on botany. (<em>Loisel</em>.)

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: AV; duplicates at FI, MW, P. – Correspondence with J. B.
Mougeot, 84 letters, 1806-1835, at P (Bibl. centr.).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 6(2): 581, 907; Backer p. 334; Barnhart 2: 398; BM 3:

715; IH 2: 456; Hegi 5(3): 559; Herder p. 463; Jackson p. 274, 406; Kew 3: 487-488;
Langman p. 453; MW p. 284-285, suppl. p. 210; NI 1224-1225; PFC 1: xlvi-xlvii; Plesch p.
316-317; PR 5584-5592 (ed. 1: 6235-6253); Rehder 5: 521; RS p. 116; Saccardo cron. p.
xxv; SO 809, add. 785-1, m; TL-1: 315, 775-781; TL-2/1: 1293, 1409, 1410, 1547, 4374;
Tucker 1: 439, 777; Zander ed. 10, p. 686, ed. 11, p. 783.
Anon., Bot. Zeit. 7: 592, 664. 1849.

("Nouveau Duhamel"), see TL-2/1547. For a list of L's contributions to Duhamel's Traité

4948. <em>Flora gallica</em>, seu enumeratio plantarum in Gallia spontè nascentium; ... Lutetiae

4951. <em>Recherches</em> historiques, botaniques et médicales <em>sur les Narcisses</em> indigènes, pour servir à
l'histoire des plantes de France; ... Paris (Baudouin ... chez l'Auteur.. Gabon) 1810. Qu. (<em>Rech. Narcisses</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1810, p. [i], [1]-42. <em>Copies</em>: FI, G(2). – Reprinted from Mém. Acad. Sci. divers.
	savants 2: 592-633. 1811; see also J. Méd. 20: 491-495. 1810 and Bull. Pharm. 3: 179-185.
	1811.

4952. <em>Herbier géneral de l'amateur</em>, contenant la description, l'histoire, les propriétés et la
culture des végétaux utiles et agréables; dédié au roi, par Mordant de Launay; continué par
M. Loiseleur-Deslongchamps, ... avec figures peintes d'après nature par M. P. Bessa, ...
Paris (Audot, libraire, ...) [1814] 1816-1827, 8 vols. (<em>Herb. gén. amat.</em>).

<em>Original author</em> (of parts 1-11 of vol. 1 only): Jean Claude Mien Mordant de Launay (x-
	1816).
<em>Publ</em>.: published 1814-1827 in 96 parts of 6 plates and 12 pages text each; 12 parts
	constituting a volume. In all (ideally) 574 plates: <em>1-572; 171, 172</em> and <em>199</em> double; <em>384</em>
	lacking. The precise dates of the parts can be ascertained from the Bibliographie de la
	France. There were two issues: octavo and quarto. The coloured copper engravings are
	of drawings by Pancrace Bessa (1772-1835), (one by P. J. Redouté, one by Poiteau). The
	original drawings were made for Charles Xth, who gave them to Marie-Caroline,
	Duchesse de Berry. The latter gave them to her sister, Teresa Christina of Brazil. They
	are now in private hands (P. Campos Porto, Rio de Janeiro). – <em>Copies</em>: USDA; IDC 6040.
	<em>1</em>: Nov 1814-1816, p. [i*-viii*], [i]-viii, <em>73 pl</em>. w.t. – p. [iv*]: dedication dated 22 Nov
	1814.
	<em>2</em>: 1817 (t.p.), p. [i-viii], <em>70 pl</em>. w.t.
	<em>3</em>: 1819 (t.p.), p. [i-iii], <em>72 pl</em>. w.t.
	<em>4</em>: 1820 (t.p.), p. [i-xii], <em>72 pl</em>. w.t.
	<em>5</em>: 1821 (t.p.), p. [i-iii], <em>72 pl</em>. w.t.
	<em>6</em>: 1822 (t.p.), p. [i-iii], <em>72 pl</em>. w.t.
	<em>7</em>: 1824 (t.p.), p. [i-iii], <em>72 pl</em>. w.t.
	<em>8</em>: 1827 (t.p.), p. [i-iii], <em>71 pl</em>. w.t., [i-xvi, ind.], [1]-8 subscribers.
	The analysis is based on the USDA copy (<em>574 plates</em>!).
<em>Ref</em>.: NI 2323 (details on originals, artists, engravers).

4953. <em>Nouveau voyage dans l'empire de flore</em>, ou principes élémentaires de botanique; ... A Paris
(chez Méquignon l'aîné père, ... ) 1817, 2 parts. Oct. (<em>Nouv. voy. emp. fl.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1817. <em>Copies</em>: B, G, NY.
	<em>1</em>: [i]-xii, [1]-214.
	<em>2</em>: [i, iii], [1]-377, [378, err.].

4954. <em>Manuel des plantes usuelles indigènes</em>, ou histoire abrégée des plantes de France, distri-
buées d'après une nouvelle méthode; contenant leurs proprietés et leurs usages en médicine,
dans la pharmacie et dans l'économie domestique; suivi de recherches et d'observations sur
l'emploi de plusieurs espèces, qui, dans la pratique de la médecine, peuvent remplacer un
certain nombre de substances exotiques ... Paris (Chez Méquignon aîné, ... ) 1819, 2 vols.
Oct. (<em>Man. pl. usuell.</em>).

4958. <em>Herbier de l'Amateur de fleurs</em>, contenant, gravés et coloriés, d'après nature, les végétaux
qui peuvent orner les jardins et les serres; l'on y a joint leur synonymie, leur description, leur
histoire, leurs modes de culture et de propagation, avec un précis d'organographie et de
physique végétales, servant d'introduction à l'ouvrage; par M. Draplez ... Bruxelles (Ve P.
J. de Mat, libraire-éditeur, ... ) 1828-1835, 8 vols. Qu. (<em>Herb. amat. fl.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: A reissue of the plates of the <em>Herb. gén. amat.</em> with a number of extra plates (in all 600,
	see Sotheby no. 477) provided with a new introduction by Pierre Auguste Joseph
	Drapiez (1778-1856) (see NI 2: 51 and no. 2324). Drapiez was a compiler, not an original
	author. His other main production was his <em>Encyclographie du règne végétal</em>, a work of such
	mediocrity and imitation that we decided to leave it out of account in TL-2. – <em>Copy</em>: BR.
	<em>1</em>: 1828, p. [i-iii], [1]-<em>44, pl. 1-75</em> w.t.

Lojka, Hugo (1845-1887), Hungarian lichenologist; born in Galicia; studied in Vienna;
later high school teacher at Budapest. (<em>Lojka</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: W; other material B, BM, BP, BOL, BPU, GZU, H, H-NYL, K,
LD, NTM, PRC, SAM, SLO, STU, WU, Z, ZT. L's lichenological library was acquired by
A. Zahlbruckner; the Hazslinsky lichen herbarium, owned by Lojka, was acquired by BP;
Lojka's own lichens are at WU (fide Laundon, 1979); however, according to Österr. bot. Z.
(40: 428. 1890) the entire Lojka lichen herbarium went to W (see also Gyelnik 1938). Before
his death W had already acquired many other Lojka collections as is clear from the
numerous notices on these acquisitions in the ÖbZ. The notice in ÖbZ (38: 183. 1888)
announcing the acquisition of the lichen herbarium by BP must refer to the Hazslinsky
collection.
Exsiccatae:
1. <em>Iter tirolense</em>, 1884; set at FH.
2. <em>Lichenolheca</em> (Lichenes) <em>regni hungarici exsiccati</em>, fasc. 1-4, nos. 1-200, 1882-1884, sets see IH
(50 sets issued).
3. <em>Lichenotheca universalis</em> continens lichenes exsiccatos totius orbis. Budapestini (ex Officina
Athenaei budapestinensis), fasc. 1-5, nos. 1-248, 1885-1886, sets see IH.
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Bot.Jahrb. 10, Beibl. 23: 2. 1889 (herb, forsale).
	Sayre, G., Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19(1): 33, 141. 1969.

<sm>CORRESPONDENCE</sm>: 41 Letters to W. Nylander at H-UB.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 6(2): 551, 12(2): 303; Barnhart 2: 399; Bossert p. 242;
CSP 8: 256, 12: 456, 16: 854; DTS 1: 176; Gr p. 652, <em>pl</em>. [<em>24</em>]; Hawksworth p. 184; IH 2: 456-
457; Kew 3: 488; Krem p. 3: 10, 53, 66; LS 15858-15866; Morren ed. 10, p. 39; NW p. 51;
SBC p. 126 ("Lojka"); Urban-Berl. p. 288.
Anon., Bot. Centralbl. 32: 63. 1887 (d.); Bot. Gaz. 12: 282. 1887; Bot.Jahrb. 9: Beibl. 21,
	Heft 3: 1: 1887; Bot. Not. 1888: 46 (d.); Flora 70: 450. 1887; Nat. Nov. 9: 268. 1887 (d.):
	Österr. bot. Z. 37: 370. 1887 (d.).
Beck, G., <em>in</em> K. Fritsch et al., Bot. Anst. Wiens 78. 1938 (lichens at W).
Degen, A., Magy.bot. Lap. 31: 61-66. 1932 (portr.).
Gyelnik, V. K., Ann. hist.-nat. Mus. natl. Hung., Bot. 31: 56, 1938 (lichens at W).
Kanitz, A., Magy. növén. Lap. 11: 159. 1887.
Laundon, J. R., Lichenologist 11: 13. 1978 (his lichens at WU).
Pötsch, J. S. und K. B. Schiedermayr, Syst. Aufz. samenlosen Pfl. Oesterr. ob. d. Enns xvi.
	1872 (see also AG 12(2): 303).
Staub, Ann. bot. 1: 408. 1888 (bibl.).
Szatala, Ö., Magy. bot. Lap. 31: 67-70. 1932 (general evaluation).
Szymkiewicz, D., Bibi. fl. Polsk. 47. 1925.
Verseghy, K., Feddes Repert. 68(1): 118-120. 1963 (coll., taxa, bibl., b. 6 Jan 1844, d. 7 Sep
	1887).
Wittrock, V. B., Acta Horti Berg. 3(3): 171, <em>pl. 123.</em> 1905 (portr.).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Lojkania</em> Rehm (1905).

Londes, Friedrich Wilhelm (1780-1807), German botanist at Goettingen. (<em>Londes</em>).

Long, William Henry (1867-1947), American mycologist; studied at Baylor University,
Waco, Texas; A. B. 1888; professor of natural history at Waco 1888-1892, from 1892-1899
at Greenville, Texas; A. M. Univ. Texas 1900; Ph. D. id. 1917; 1900-1910 at Denton,
Texas; from 1910-1911 at USDA, Washington, with USDA at Albuquerque, New Mexico
1911-1937. (<em>W. H. Long</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BPI (US); other material at B, CUP, NTSC, NY, PUR, TEX. –
Original herbarium, collected up to 1907, burned.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 400 (b. 7 Mar 1867, d. 10 Dec 1947); CSP 16:
860; Hawksworth p. 184; IH 1 (ed. 6): 361, 2: 458; Kelly p. 132-133; Kew 3: 495; Lasègue p.
465, 505, 574; LS 15876-15877, 36229, suppl. 16525-16551; Moebius p. 362; MW p. 285;
NAF 7(15): 1076; Stevenson p. 1249; Tucker 1: 440.
Hesler, L. R., Biogr. sketches N. Amer. mycol. 1975 (mss).
Rickett, H. W., Index Bull. Torrey bot. Club 64. 1955.
Rogers, D. P., Brief hist. mycol. N. Amer. 46-47. 1955.
Stevenson, J. A., Mycologia 41(3): 223-228. 1949 (portr., bibl. of 78 nos.); Taxon 4(8): 184.
	1955 (on herb.).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Longia</em> H. Sydow (1921); <em>Longia</em> S. M. Zeller (1943). <em>Note: Longoa</em> Curzi (1927) is

	judgement of his own work by the author: "Ach arme Flora, die niets deugt, Ach
	misgeboorte van mijn jeugd" ("Oh poor worthless Flora, oh abortion of my youth").
	The book was written to please David de Gorter after a year's lessons in botany at
	Haarlem (1777) (JW 5).
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Roozenkrans voor Loosjes Flora, Amsterdam 1779.

Modena 1909-1925; professor of botany at the agricultural university of Portici 1925-1928.

Lorek, Christian Gottlieb (1788-1871), German botanist and high school teacher at
Königsberg; Dr. phil. Königsberg 1812; taught at the Burgschule 1811-1850, retired
because of increasing loss of eye-sight. (<em>Lorek</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Originally at KBG; now destroyed. Caspary mentions a manuscript
with 90 figures of fungi at the university library, Königsberg (now Kaliningrad, USSR)
(see also E. Meyer, Preuss. Provincial-Blätter 10, 1833), identified by E. Fries.

NI 1231; PR 5602; Rehder 5: 522; Tucker 1:440.

Lorentz, Paul (Pablo) Günther (1835-1881), German botanist: in Germany until 1869;
professor of botany at Cordoba, Argentina until 1874; later high school teacher at Concep-
ción, Uruguay. (<em>Lorentz</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Lichenes at M; phanerogams at GOET; the main part of the
original mosses was destroyed in B (herb. K. Müdler Hal.), however the pre-1870 European
moss collections are at M and several of L's moss collections (e.g. from Norway) were
distributed by the Unio itineraria; other mosses are at GFW, GOET, H, NY and W. For
further details see IH.
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Flora 53: 208. 1870 (sale of his moss herbarium), Bot. Zeit. 28: 359-360. 3 Jun
	1870; Bot Jahrb. 3, Beibl. 1, 29 Dec 1882 (herb. bought by B).
	Lanjouw, J., <em>in</em> F. Verdoorn, ed., Pl. pl. sci. Latin Amer. 234. 1945.
	Mägdefrau, K., in litt. d.d. 6 Jan 1980.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 402; BL 1: 235-236, 306; BM 3: 1178, 7: 747;
Bossert p. 243; Clokie p. 203; CSP 8: 259, 10: 631, 12: 457-458; DTS 1: 176-177, 6(4): 50;
Frank 3(Anh.): 60; GR p. 107; Herder p. 112, 265; Hortus 3: 1198 ("Lorentz"); IH 1 (ed.
6): 361, 2: 460; Jackson p. 575; Kew 3: 500-501; KR p. 468; LS 15902; Moebius p. 117;
Morren ed. 2, p. 37; NAF ser. 2. 3: 39; PR 5606-5611; Rehder 5: 522; Saccardo 1: 98, 2: 64,

PAGE: 158
HEADING: LORENTZ

43: 341-486. 1882, Hedwigia 36: 84-144. 1892 (Linnaea papers reprinted 1971). <em>Phanero</em>-
<em>gams</em>: Grisebach, A. H. R., Pl. lorentz. 1874, TL-2/2186, Symb. fl. argent. 1879, TL-2/2187.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: We are grateful to Karl Mägdefrau for detailed information on Lorentz.

Lortet, Mme. Clémence, née Richard (1772-1835), French botanist at Lyon; pupil and
botanical companion of Gilibert, one of the founders of the Société linnéenne de Lyon. (<em>C.
Lortet</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: LY, in the herbarium of the Société linnéenne.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 12(2): 539; Barnhart 2: 403; Bossert p. 243.
Anon., Ann. Soc. bot. Lyon 19: 14. 1893/4; Bull. Soc. bot. France 23: clxxxv. 1876 (herb.).
Candolle, Alph. de, Phytographie 429. 1880 (herb.).

Roffavier, Ann. Soc. bot. Lyon 1856: 1-11. (portr., biogr.).

Wittrock, V. B., Acta Horti Berg. 3(2): 115. 1903.

<sm>NOTE ON THE LORTET FAMILY</sm>: Clémence Richard (1772-1835; no known connection with
the botanical Richard family) married Jean Pierre Lortet (x-1823) in 1791. Her son Pierre
Lortet (1792-1868) physician and naturalist, also active as amateur botanist, married
(1826) Nettchen Müller (1802-1837). Louis-Charles Lortet (1836-1909), physician and
botanist was the third child born out of this marriage; see below for treatment. Clémence
Lortet contributed to publications by Balbis and Gilibert; published-through Gilibert – a
<em>Calendrier de Flore</em> (1809), and left a mss. <em>Promenades botaniques</em> (1804-1805).

Lortet, Louis-Charles (1836-1909), French physician, parasitologist and botanist at
Lyon; grandson of Clémence Lortet; Dr. med. Paris 1861; Dr. sci. nat. Lyon 1867; lecturer
medical school, 1867, professor ib. 1868; lecturer in zoology at the Factulté des Sciences
1869; director of the Muséum d'histoire naturelle de Lyon 1869; professor of zoology
Faculté des Sciences 1874-1877; professor of natural history at the Faculté mixte de
Medecine et de Pharmacie 1877-1906. (<em>L. Lortet</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: LY (via herb. A.Jordan); other material at FI. L's library was also
acquired by Jordan; it was based on Roffavier's library.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 3: 199; Barnhart 2: 403; BM 3: 1181, 7: 748; CSP 4: 87,
8: 262, 10: 634, 16: 874-875; IH 2: 461; Morren ed. 10, p. 64; PR 5621; Quenstedt p. 269;
Rehder 5: 523.
Anon., Bull. Soc. bot. France 24(bibl.): 46. 1877 (transfer to new faculty).
Candolle, Alph. de, Phytographie 429. 1880 (herb. LY).
Gaillard, C., Arch. Mus. Hist. nat. Lyon 11: 1-31. 1912 (b. 22 Aug 1836, d. 26 Dec 1909,
	bibl., list of biogr. refs.; the main biography with extensive details).
Magnin, A., Bull. Soc. bot. France 23: clxxxvii. 1876; Bull. Soc. bot. Lyon 35: 33, 48-49.
	1910; 37: 56, 57, 58-65. 1912; Les Lortet, Lyon 1913, 109 p. (portr., bibl.).
