Martersteck, Johann Clemens (<em>fl</em>. 1792), German botanist and church administrator at
Bonn. (<em>Martersteck</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 453; BM 3: 1249; PR 5852 (ed. 1: 6550);
Rehder 5: 548.
Oligschläger, F. W., Flora 16: 341. 1833.

5489. <em>Bönnischer Flora</em> erster Theil. Oder Verzeichniss aller hier wild und frei-wachsenden
Arznei-Pflanzen, nebst einer vollständigen Beschreibung ihrer Eigenschaften, ihres Nut-
zens und Gebrauches, ... Bonn (gedruckt bei Joh. Frid. Abshoven, Universitäts-
Buchdruckerei) 1792. Oct. (<em>Bönn. Fl.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1792, p. [i-xvi], [1]-475, [476, err.]. <em>Copies</em>: G, NY.

Marthe, François (<em>fl</em>. 1801), French botanist and gardener at the Jardin médical, Paris.
(<em>Marthe</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

PAGE: 319
HEADING: MARTIN, C. E.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BM 3: 1249; CSP 10: 734; IF p. 717; Jackson p. 421; Kew 3:
601; MW p. 300; PR 5853 (ed. 1: 6551); Rehder 5: 548; SO add. 773a.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Marthella</em> Urban (1903) commemorates Urban's wife, Martha Urban née Kurtz,
herself a sister of the botanist Fritz Kurtz (1854-1920, q.v.). The derivation of <em>Marthea
</em>Pascher (1918) could not be established.

5490. <em>Catalogue des plantes du jardin médical de Paris</em>. disposées selon le systême de Linné, avec
l'explication de quelques changements faits à ce système. Publié par François Marthe,
cultivateur du dit Jardin. Paris (Chez Gabon, ... an IX [1801]. Duod. (<em>Cat. pl. jard. méd.
Paris.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1801, p. [1]-144. <em>Copy</em>: USDA.

Martin, Adolf (<em>fl</em>. 1851), German botanist; practicing physician at Pechelbronn (Nieder-
rhein). (<em>A. Martin</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BM 3: 1249; Jackson p. 10; PR 5855; Rehder 5: 548.
Anon., Bonplandia 2: 174. 1854, 6: 48. 1858 (cogn. Leopoldina: Weigel).

5491. <em>Die Pflanzennamen der deutschen Flora</em> mit wichtigern Synonymen in alphabetischer
Ordnung etymologisch erklärt ... Halle (Druck und Verlag von H. W. Schmidt) 1851.
Oct. (<em>Pfl. Namen deut. Fl.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1851 (p. iv: Aug 1851), p. [i]-iv, [1]-121, [122, index]. <em>Copies</em>: G, NY.
<em>Ref</em>.: Schlechtendal, D. F. L. von, Bot. Zeit. 9: 870-871. 5 Dec 1851.

Martin, Charles-Édouard (1847-1937), Swiss amateur mycologist; studied at the École
libre de théologie de la Société évangélique, Genève; professor of classical languages at the
École until 1921; from 1885 corrector for the <em>Tribune de Genève</em>; first president of the Société
mycologique de Genève; Dr. h. c. Genève 1933. (<em>C. Martin</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown; for his "iconotheca", now at G, see Wiki (1940).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 453; BJI 2: 113; BM 7: 802; Kelly p. 143; LS
16986-16998, 36625-36633, suppl. 17389-17411.
Lendner, A., Bull. Soc. bot. Genève ser. 2. 28: 184-190. 1937 (biogr., bibl., b. 10 Mai 1847,
	d. 13 Feb 1937).
Verdoorn, F., Chron. bot. 4(4/5): 438. 1938.
Wiki, B., Bull. Soc. bot. Genève 30: 240-256. 1940 (iconotheca of 5268 sheets at G.)

5492. <em>Contribution à la flore mycologique Suisse</em> et plus spécialement genevoise ... [Genève
1899]. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1899 (Nat. Nov. Jun(1) 1899), p. [1]-66 <em>Copy</em>: NY. – Reprinted and to be cited from
	Bull. Trav. Soc. bot. Genève 9: 52-117. 1899. – Other papers by this author under the
	same title: ib. 7: 171-198. 1894 and Bull. Soc. bot. Genève 11: 110-130. 1905.

5493. <em>Le 'Boletus subtomentosus' de la région genevoise</em> essai de monographie ... [Berne (K. J.
Wyss, libraire éditeur) 1903]. Oct. (<em>Boletus subtomentosus</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1903 (Bot. Zeit. and ÖbZ 1 Nov 1903; J. Bot. Nov 1903; Nat. Nov. Dec(1) 1903), p.
	[ii]-ix, [1]-39, <em>pl. 1-18</em> (col. liths.). <em>Copy</em>: USDA. – Matériaux pour la flore cryptogamique
	Suisse 2(1).

5494. <em>Catalogue systématique des Basidiomycètes</em> charnus, des Discomycètes, des Tubérinées et
des Hypocréacées <em>de la Suisse romande</em>... Genève (publié par la Société mycologique de
Genève) 1919. Qu. (<em>Cat. Basidiomyc. Suisse rom.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1919 (p. 5: 9 Feb 1919), p. [1]-47. <em>Copies</em>: BR, G, NY.

Martin, Émile (1810-1895), French botanist and judge at Romorantin (Loir-et-Cher).
(<em>E. Martin</em>).

HEADING: MARTIN, C. E.

Franchet, A., Bull. Soc. bot. France 42: 725-726. 1895.

	1894. Oct.

Martin, George Willard (1886-1971), American mycologist; M. Sc. Rutgers Univ. 1915;
in U. S. Army in France 1915-1919; at Rutgers Univ. 1919-1921; at Univ. Chicago 1921-
1923; Ph. D. Chicago 1922; from 1923-1955 at the State University of Iowa, Iowa City. (<em>G.
W. Martin</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: IA.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Ainsworth p. 345; Barnhart 2: 454; Bossert p. 255; GR p.
230; Hawksworth p. 184; Hirsch p. 190; IH 2: 507; Kelly p. 143; Kew 3: 602-603; Lenley p.
281; LS suppl. 17422-17430; ME 2: 731; MW p. 300; NAF 1(1): 264; Roon p. 74; Stevenson
p. 1250; TL-2/1: 781.
Burk, W. R., Bibl. N. Amer. Gasteromyc. 1: 117-120. 1980.
Couch, J. N., Amer. midl. Natural. 87: 257. 1972.
Hedge, I. C. &amp; J. M. Lamond, Index coll. Edinb. herb. 108. 1970 (pl. E).
Hesler, L. R., Biogr. sketches N. Amer. mycol. 1975, mss.
Hulbary, R. L., Plant Sci. Bull. 18(4): 44. 1972; Bull. Torrey bot. Cl. 100: 142. 1973.
Lentz, P. L. &amp; C. R. Benjamin, Mycopath. Mycol. appl. 45(3-4): vii-xv. 1971 (portr.,
	bibl.).
Lowy, B., Bol. Soc. mexic. Micol. 5: 114. 1971.
Martin, G. W., The Tremellales of the North Central United States and adjacent Canada,
	Iowa City, Mai 1944, 88 p. (Univ. Iowa Stud. nat. Hist. 18(3)).
Rogers, D. P., Brief hist. mycol. N. Amer. 42-43. 1977.
Stafleu, F. A., Taxon 20: 179. 1971 (on his <em>Myxomycetes</em> of 1969).
Wells, K., Mycologia 65(5): 985-998. 1973 (portr., bibl.).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) With T. H. Macbride: <em>The myxomycetes</em>, New York 1934; with C. J.
Alexopoulous; <em>The myxomycetes</em> 1969.
(2) NAF, <em>Myxomycetes</em>, 1(1): 1-151. 29 Apr 1949.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Martininia</em> K. P. Dumont &amp; R. P. Korf (1970). <em>Note</em>: <em>Marlinella</em> Baillon (1888)
commemorates Joseph Martin (fl. 1788-1826), French botanist in French Guiana, who also
collected on Martinique and Mauritius. <em>Martinella</em> (M. C. Cooke &amp; Massee ex M. C.
Cooke) P. A. Saccardo (1892) is dedicated to Flora Martin née Campbell (x-1923),
Australian botanist who is also commemorated by <em>Campbellia</em> M. C. Cooke &amp; Massee
(1890). <em>Martinia</em> E. Vaniot (1903), <em>Martinella</em> A. A. H. Léveillé (1904) and <em>Neomartinella
</em>Pilger (1906) are dedicated to Léon François Martin (1866-1919), French missionary and
botanical collector in China, Japan, Korea and Siberia. The same probably holds for
<em>Martinia</em> L. Crié (1889) which, however, could not be checked. <em>Martiniaster</em> Loeblich &amp;
Tappan (1963) commemorates E. Martini (fl. 1961), German micropalaeontologist about
whom we have no further particulars.

Martin, William (1886-1975), New Zealand botanist and high school teacher, B. Sc.
Otago Univ. 1911. (<em>W. Martin</em>).

Sayre, G., Bryologist 80: 513. 1977.

Martin, William Keble (1877-1969), British clergyman, botanist and botanical artist;
MA Oxon 1899; curate 1902-1909; vicar, Wath-upon-Dearne, Rotherham 1909-1921;
rector Haccombe, Devon, 1921-1934; Great Torrington 1934-1943; Combe-in-Teignhead
1943-1949. (<em>W. K. Martin</em>).

5497. <em>Album de la flora médico-farmaceutica</em> é industrial, indigena y exótica, ó sea coleccion de
laminas iluminadas de las plantas de applicacion en la medicina, farmacia, industria y
artes, copiadas en sa mayor parte del natural ó de los mejores dibujos que de ellas existen:
descripcion de las mismas con expresion de sa duracion, localidad donde crecen y época en
que florecen las de España; su sinonímia científica y vulgar, usos médicos, farmacéuticos é
industriales, virtudes medicinales, etc. etc. ordenadas segun el método natural de Mr. De-
Candolle ... Madrid (Imprenta de la Galeria Literaria, ...) 1862-1864, 3 vols. (<em>Album fl.
méd.-farm.</em>).

Martindale, Isaac Comly (1842-1893), American quaker, botanist, entomologist, and
bank-clerk of Camden, New Jersey. (<em>I. C. Martindale</em>).

Martins, Charles Frédéric (1806-1889), French botanist and geologist; botanical ex-
plorer of Spitsbergen and the Mediterranean; from 1851-1879 director of the botanical
garden and professor of botany at Montpellier. (<em>Martins</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. Important set at G; see IH.

Martius, Carl Friedrich Philipp von (1794-1868), German botanical traveller, ethno-
logist and botanist; M. D. Erlangen 1814, from then on at München; in Brazil 1817-1820; founder of the <em>Flora brasiliensis</em>. (<em>Mart</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Martius' own collections from Brazil (1817-1820), including the
types of most of his Brazilian species, are at München (M), often with very scanty
annotations. In addition, M has collections made by Martius in the Mediterranean area
and Madeira. Martius' herbarium, including the types of his species based on other
collections, but also including the types of species of many other authors, is at BR (63.000
specimens, acquired in 1870. For sets of duplicates see IH (not mentioned: set at TO, see
Fryxell 1976).
An important source for details on Martius' Brazilian collections is a six volume manuscript
at M, entitled <em>Plantae in itinere brasiliensi annis 1817-1820 a Car. Frid. Phil Martio descriptae</em>;
Martius often refers to this manuscript in his publications by citing the numbers (1-3320) of
the entries. These numbers often occur also on the herbarium labels of Martius' plants at M
and these specimens should therefore be consulted in connection with this manuscript.
Another manuscript at M, with abundant descriptive detail is <em>Martii Schedulae de Leguminosis
in Brasilia observatis</em>. An important collection of Martius' manuscripts, personalia, official
documents, diaries, illustrations, etc. is preserved at the Department of Manuscripts of the
Bayerische Staatsbibliothek, München.
The correspondence received by Martius is still in private hands in Germany. Some sets of
letters have been published, e.g. those with Goethe and Carus (see Anon. 1932 and G.
Schmid 1939). A large set of letters by M to Miquel is at U.
M's library was sold by auction by Weigel (Leipzig) 7 Mar 1870.

<sm>NAME</sm>: Martius used the pseudonym "Suitram" in some of his writings (see Carus et Martius
s.d.).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 20: 517-527; AG 2(2): 354, 3: 431, 7: 147; Backer p.
356; Barnhart 2: 455; BL 1: 238, 239, 308; Blunt p. 248; BM 3: 1254-1257, 7: 805; Bossert p.
255; CSP 4: 266-269, 8: 348, 12: 490, 17: 64; DSB 9: 148-149; DTS 1: 182-183; DU 192;
Frank 3(Anh.): 62-63; GF p. 66; GR p. 30-31; Hawksworth p. 184, 196; Herder p. 59;
Hortus 3: 1199 ("Mart."); IF p. 717; Jackson p. 578; Kew 3: 607-609; Klinge p. 27;
Krempelh. 2: 7-8; Langman p. 483; Lasègue p. 230-233,575 [index]; Lenley p. 281,464; LS
17025-17042, suppl. 17519-17520; Maiwaldp. 89, 106, 118, 144; Moebius p. 278, 375; MW
p. 300; NI 1284-1288; PH 364, 438, 567; Plesch p. 327; PR 5882-5913 (ed. 1: 6581-6615);
Quenstedt p. 282-283; Rehder 5: 550-551; RS p. 117-118; SBC p. 126 ("Mart."); SK 1:
cxcix; Sotheby 503-504; SO add. 809c, 2057a, 2694, add. 2699a; Stevenson p. 1250; TL-
2/191,389, 1156, 1649, 3035, 3972, see indexes; Tucker 1: 465-466; Zander ed. 10, p. 689,
ed. 11, p. 785-786.

Vol. part	pages	plates	dates
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
1(1)	1-20	1-12	late 1823 or Jan-Feb 1824
(2)	21-36	13-24	late 1823 or Jan-Feb 1824
(3)	37-80	25-55	1 Oct 1824, (1)
(4)	81-158	56-100	Jan-Mar 1826, (2)
2(1)	1-68	101-160	Apr-Jun 1826
(2)	69-148	161-200	Jan-Jun 1827
3(1)	1-80	201-231	Jun-Jun 1829
(2)	81-124	232-272	Jan-Mar (?) 1831
(3)	125-198	273-300	Sep 1832, (3)

(1) diagnoses published earlier in Flora 7(1) Beil. (4): 129-142, between 25 Apr and 30 Jun
1824. (2) idem t. <em>56-74</em> in Flora 8(1): 27-32. 14 Jan 1825; the fascicle cover of this part was
dated "1824" fide GGA 26 Jan 1829.
(3) date on p. 198.
The above information is based on reviews in GGA, Flora, Linnaea, and Isis (see also
Woodward 1908). On 29 Jun 1829 Martius informed W.J. Hooker (letter at K) that the
book was ready as far as <em>pl. 231</em>; from a letter dated 24 Mar 1832 it appears that 3(2) was
published around Mar 1831. In the preparation of this book, especially of the plates,
Martius was assisted by J. G. Zuccarini. – Sprengel (Syst. 1: 224. late 1824) cites a Martius
taxon published on 1: 156, <em>pl. 95.</em> This might indicate that 2(4) was possibly published
earlier than the Jan-Mar 1826 here accepted.
For information on the artists who prepared the 300 lithographs see NI 1288.

5530. <em>Hortus regius monacensis</em>. Verzeichniss der im königlichen botanischen Garten zu
München wachsenden Pflanzen, nach der natürlichen Methode geordnet, mit Hinweisung
auf das Linneische System und summarischer Angabe des Vaterlands, der Cultur und
Benützungsweise. Auch als Schlüssel und Übersicht in deutschen Gärten und für Herba-
rien zu gebrauchen. München (im königlichen Central-Schulbücher-Verlage), Leipzig (In
Commission bei Friedrich Fleischer) 1829. Oct. (<em>Hort. reg. monac</em>).

<em>Co-author</em>: Franz von Paula Schrank (1747-1835).
<em>Publ</em>.: 1829 (p. vi: 25 Jun 1829), p. [i]-xii, [1], [1]-210. <em>Copies</em>: NY, USDA. – For authorship

5534. <em>Conspectus regni vegetabilis</em> secundum characteres morphologicos praesertim carpicos
in classes ordines et familias digesti, adjectis cxemplis nominibusque plantarum usui medico
technico et oeconomico inservientium. Uebersicht der Classen, Ordnungen und Familien
des Gewächsreiches nach morphologischen Grundsätzen, under besonderer Rücksicht auf
den Fruchtbau, mit Angabe von Beispielen und von den in der Medicin, Technik und
Oekonomie besonders wichtigen Pflanzen, zunächst als Leitfaden bei seinen akademischen
Vorlesungen entworfen ... Nürnberg (bei Joh. Leonhard Schrag ...) 1835. Oct. (<em>Consp. regn, veg.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Sep-Oct 1835 (Hinrichs 25-31 Oct), p. [i]-xviii, [1]-72. <em>Copies</em>: FI, G, H, L, M, MO,
	NY, U, USDA.

5538. <em>Flora brasiliensis</em>. Enumeratio plantarum in Brasilia hactenus detectarum quas suis
aloirumque botanicis studiis descriptas et methodo naturali digestas partim icone illustratas

PAGE: 334
HEADING: MARTIus (<em>Fl. bras.</em>)

editit C. F. P. de Martius [later: A. W. Eichler, I. Urban]. Opus cura Musei C. R. Pal.
Vindobonensis auctore S. Endlicher successore E. Fenzl, conditum. Münchcn, Wien,
Leipzig 1840-1906. 15 Volumes (in 40), published in 130 fascicles. Fol. (<em>Fl. bras.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: In 130 dated parts. For extensive details see Urban's treatise in vol. 1(1), (1906)
	"Vitae, itineraque collectorutn botanicorum, notae collaboratorum biographicae,
	Florae brasiliensis ratio edendi chronologica, systema, index familiarum". A review of
	the contents is given by Woodward (BM), a list of the artists by Nissen. – 20.733 Pages,
	3811 lithographs and nature-prints. <em>Copies</em>: M, MO, NY, U, US. – The "page-numbers"
	actually refer to col urns.
Martius founded the work with Endlicher; he edited fasc. 1-46 (1840-1868). For his own
contributions see 1(1): 184-185. 1906. For the plan of the work sec Martius, Fl. bras. 23(1)
Int. Bl. 17-23. 1840.
<em>Facsimile ed</em>.: Cramer (Weinheim) 1965; the complete work; vol. 3(4): 317-672, <em>pl. 76-133</em>
	was already reprinted full size in 1920.
<em>Listing</em> by contents and by fascicles: see vol. 1(1). 1906.

The 32 plates of the <em>Palmetum Orbignianum</em> form part of the botanical section of the Atlas
volume (vol. 8). The botanical plates are copper-engravings and lithographs of drawings
by A. Chazal, J. Delarue and P. Oudart. 39 Originals by Delarue are at the Paris Muséum
(Ms. 329).
<em>Ref</em>.: Sherborn and Woodward, Ann. Mag. nat. Hist. ser. 7. 7: 388, 1901.
	Sherborn and Griffin, Ann. Mag. nat. Hist. ser. 10. 13: 133. 1934.

5563. Joannis Martyn <em>Historia plantarum rariorum</em>... Londini (ex typographia Richardi
Reily) 1728. Fol.†. (<em>Hist. pl. rar.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1728[-1737], p. [ii*-iii*], [i]-iv, [1]-52, 50 <em>plates</em> (color-printed copp. van Huysum).
	<em>Copies</em>: HU (<em>50 pl</em>.), MO (<em>49 pl</em>.), <em>NY</em> (<em>40 pl</em>.): IDC 6056. – One of the earliest works with
	color-printed plates. See e.g. Sotheby 505.
Re-issue: after 1768, with reset preface and Linnaean index on p. iv of the preface using plant
	names from Sp. pl. ed. 2: <em>Copies</em>: BM, Morton Arboretum (inf. I. MacPhail).
<em>German ed</em>.: 1752-1754, in five parts; decades 1-2 prelinnaean, 5 post-linnaean, p. [i-vi], 1.
	24, <em>pl. 1-50</em> (col. pl. by J. D. Meyer). <em>Copies</em>: G, NY, USDA – "Joannis Martyn <em>Historia</em>
	<em>plantarum rariorum</em> ob praestantium denuo editia studio atque opera Joannis Danielis
	Meyeri pictoris. Johann Martyns <em>Beschreibung seltener Pflanzen</em> ihrer Fürtrefflichkeit
	wegen von Neuem herausgegeben durch Johann Daniel Meyer [1713-1757] Miniatur
	Mahler ... "Nürnberg (gedruckt bey Andreas Bieling) 1752. Fol. The plates are mezzo-
	tints, partly color-printed.
<em>Second German ed</em>.: 1797, p. [i]-viii, [1]-72, <em>pl. 1-50</em> (partly col. printed). <em>Copies</em>: G, NY, –
	"Johann Martyns <em>Abbildung und Beschreibung sellener Gewaechse</em> neu übersetzt, systematiseh

PAGE: 343
HEADING: MARTYN, T.

	bearbeitet und mit Anmerkungen begleitet von D. Georg Wolffgang Franz Panzer
	[1755-1829] ... "Nürnberg (in der Frauenholzischen Kunsthandlung) 1797. Fol.
<em>Note</em> on post 1768 re-issue: See MacPhail, I. and W. J. Hess, Huntia 3: (in press) on the date
	of the Linnaean index. Internal evidence makes it clear that this index was prepared after
	1768 and added to original sheets thus producing anomalous copies which may still, with
	some liberty, be called re-issues. For a full analysis of a copy of the original issue, (with
	complete preface material) and for many additional details, e.g. a list with modern
	names of the depicted plants, see HU 476.
MacPhail, I. and W. J. Hess, Huntia 3(2): 73-81. 1980.

5564. <em>Tournefort's history of plants</em> growing about Paris, with their uses in physick; and a
mechanical account of the operation of medicines. Translated into English, with many
additions. And accomodated to the plants growing in Great-Britain. By John Martyn, F. R.
S. in two volumes ... London (printed for C. Rivington, ...) 1732. Oct. (<em>Tourn. hist. pl.</em>).

Martyn, Thomas (1735-1825), British botanist; at Cambridge from 1762; son of John
Martyn. (<em>Martyn</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. The Martyn herbarium at CGE was made by Thomas
Martyn's father John Martyn (1699-1768) (see above) and consists mostly of plants
cultivated at Cambridge. Correspondence at BM.

Wolley-Dod, A. H., Fl. Sussex xxxviii. 1937.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: The anonymous pamphlet "A short account of the late donation of a botanic garden
to the University of Cambridge ... Cambridge, printed by J. Bentham printer to the

PAGE: 344
HEADING: MARTYN, T.

University" 1763 was written by Richard Walker (1679-1764), vice-master of Trinity
College, Cambridge, and not by Th. Martyn. (See Henrey 1953).

5565. <em>Plantae cantabrigienses</em>; or, a catalogue of the plants which grow wild in the county of
Cambridge, disposed according to the system of Linnaeus. Herbationes cantabrigienses; or,
directions to the places, where they may be found, comprehended in thirteen botanical
excursions. To which are added, lists of the more rare plants growing in many parts of
England and Wales ... London (printed for the author, and sold by Mess. Thurlbourn and
Woodyer in Cambridge, and J. Beecroft ...) 1763. Oct. (in fours). (<em>Pl. cantabrig.</em>).

5570. <em>Flora rustica</em>: exhibiting accurate figures of such plants as are either useful or injurious
in husbandry. Drawn and engraved by Frederick P. Nodder, botanic painter to her

PAGE: 345
HEADING: MARUM

majesty, and coloured under his inspection. With scientific characters, popular descrip-
tions, and useful observations ... London (published by F. P. Nodder, ...) 1792-1794[-
1795], 4 vols. Oct. (<em>Fl. rust.</em>).

<em>Artist</em>: Frederick Polydore Nodder (fl. 1777-1800).
<em>Publ</em>.: In parts of which the contents and dates are still unknown: "... for here is a work
	lacking signatures, page numbers, press figures, and chainlines" (Stevenson, in HU 721).
	The 144 plates are hand-coloured engravings which carry dates: three-monthly from
	Nov 1791 to [<em>142</em>] Oct 1794. At this period the dates on the plates were often indeed dates
	of publication, and hence they have to be accepted as such until evidence to the contrary
	is produced. <em>Copies</em>: G, MO, NY, USDA. – Copies vary in the way in which the plates are
	bound. See also Henrey 1023.
<em>Vol. 1</em>: 1792 (t.p.), p. [i-xx], <em>pl. 1-39</em>, with text, [1-2, index].
<em>Vol. 2</em>: 1792 (t.p.), p. [i], <em>pl. 40-72</em>, with text, [1-4, index].
<em>Vol. 3</em>: 1793 (t.p.), p. [i], <em>pl. 73-114</em>, with text, [1-2, index] (printer B. M'Millan).
<em>Vol. 4</em>: 1794[-1795], p. [i], <em>pl. 115-144</em>, with text, [1-2, index].
<em>Re-issue</em>: 1802-1804, n.v.

5571. <em>The language of botany</em>: being a dictionary of the terms made use of in that science,
principally by Linneus [sic]: with familiar explanations, and an attempt to establish

for B. and J. White, ...) 1793. Oct. (<em>Lang. bot.</em>).

<em>Ed. 1</em>: Jun-Jul 1793 (p. viii: 8 Feb 1793; Gent. Mag. Jul 1793), p. [i]-xxviii, dictionary sign.
	B-Y2 <em>Copies</em>: G, NY.
<em>Ed. 2</em>: 1796, p. [i]-xxiii, dictionary C6-Ee6 [304 p.].<em>Copies</em>: G, NY. – "The second edition,
	corrected and enlarged ..." London (printed by J. Davis, for B. and J. White,...) 1796.
	Oct.
<em>Ed. 3</em>: 1807, p. [i]-xxiii, dictionary sign. C6-Ff3. <em>Copy</em>: NY. – "The third edition, corrected
	and enlarged ..." London (printed by T. Bensley, ... for John White, ...) 1807. Oct.

5572. <em>Introduction à la botanique</em>, ouvrage destiné à l'usage de ceux, qui veulent s'intruire [sic]
dans cette science; et pour servir d'explication à trenthuit gravures enluminées d'après
nature, publiées en anglois par Thomas Martyn, ... en françois et hollandois par J. van

	G, L. – Alternative t.p. in dutch: "<em>Inleiding tot de kruidkunde</em>,...".

Marum, Martin [Martinus] van (1750-1837), Dutch physician and naturalist; Ph. D.
Groningen 1773; main founder of the collections and library of Teyler's Stichting at
Haarlem. (<em>Marum</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

Marzari-Pencati, Giuseppe, Conte (1779-1836), Italian botanist. (<em>Marzari-Pencati</em>).

Marzell, Heinrich (1885-1970), German botanist, classicist and linguist; Dr. phil. Mün-
chen 1911; from 1918-1950 high school teacher at the Realschule Gunzenhausen; Leibnitz
Medaille 1954. (<em>Marzell</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 456 (b. 23 Jan 1885); BFM 3241; BJI 2: 113;
TL-2/2571.
Bresinsky, A., Ber. bayer. bot. Ges. 43: 155. 1972 (d. 28 Nov 1970).
Christiansen, W. &amp; W., Bot. Schrifttum Schlesw.-Holst. 317. 1936.
Diels, L., Bot. Jahrb. 60(Lit.): 75-76. 1938 (rev. Lief. 1 Wörterb. deut. Pfl.-Namen).
Ficker, H., Acta phytotherap. 18: 144-145. 1971 (d. 20 Nov 1970).
Janchen, E., Österr. bot. Z. 86: 308-309. 1937 (rev. Lief. 1, Wörterb. deut. Pfl.-Namen).
Paul, H., <em>in</em> Wörterb. deut. Pflanzennamen part 23: [2 p.]. 1976.
Poggendorff, J. C., Biogr.-lit. Handw.-Buch 7a(3): 214. 1958. (b. 23 Jan 1885; bibl.).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: M'S main work is his <em>Wörterbuch der deutschen Pflanzennamen</em> of which the first instalment
(<em>Abelia-Agrimonia</em>) appeared in 1937, the first volume (<em>Abelia-Cytisus</em>) was completed in 1943
and of which Licferung 35 (Band 4, Lief. 6, <em>Trigonella-Vaccinium</em>) was published in 1978 by

PAGE: 347
HEADING: MASCLEF

S. Hirzel Verlag, Stuttgart (originally: Leipzig). The book is now edited, on the basis of M's
manuscript left on his death, by Heinz Paul.

Pflanzen, sowie ihrer Volksnamen ... Reutlingen (Enklin &amp; Laiblins Verlagsbuchhand-

<em>Publ</em>.: Jan-Feb 1921 (ÖbZ), p. [1]-711, <em>pl. 1-32</em> (col.). <em>Copy</em>: USDA.

Masamune, Genkei (1899-x) Japanese botanist working on Asiatic Orchidaceae and the
flora of the Ryukyu Archipelago. (<em>Masam</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: TI (early work; up to ca. 1935); further material in KANA (post
war) and TAI (Taiwan mat.) (inf. H. Hara).

("Masam."); IF suppl. 3: 213, 4: 330; IH 2: 510: MW p. 300-302, suppl. p. 217-220 (bibl.);
Roon p. 74.

Syun'iti, Suzuki Shigeyoshi, Hosokawa Takahide, Mori Kunihiko, Shimada Hidetaro,

5583a. <em>Tenasserim</em>: or notes on the fauna, flora, minerals, and nations of British Burmah
and Pegu: with systematic catalogues of the known minerals, plants, mammals, fishes,
mollusks, sea-nettles, corals, sea-urchins, worms, insects, crabs, reptiles, and birds; with
vernacular names ... Maulmain (American Mission Press. Thos. S. Ranney) 1852. (<em>Tenas
serim</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1852, p. [i*-xiv*], [i]-viii, [1]-712. <em>Copy</em>: UC (inf. R. Schmid). Section on botany on
	p. 59-216, on "plants" p. 545-676 (= Flora burmanica, see above). This is a second
	edition of <em>Nat. prod. Burmah</em>, 1850, see above.

PAGE: 349
HEADING: MASSALONGO

minerals of Tenasserim, Pegu and Burmah, with systematic catalogues of the known
mammals, birds, fish, reptiles, insects, mollusks, crustaceans, annalids [sic], radiates, plants
and minerals, with vernacular names: ... Rangoon (Thos. Stowe Ranney), London
(Trubner &amp; Co....), New York (Phinney, Blakeman &amp; Mason, ...) 1860. Qu. (<em>Burmah</em>).

Mason, Francis Archibald (1878-1936), British professional chemist and naturalist;
director of the biological laboratories of Murphy and Co., Headingley, Leeds. (<em>F. Mason</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Desmond p. 425.
Blackwell, E. M., Naturalist 877: 64. 1961 (brief biogr.).

Pearsall, W. H., Naturalist 953: 133-134. 1936 (obit., portr.).

5585. Yorkshire Naturalists' Union [.] <em>A catalogue of Yorkshire fungi</em> by the late F. A. Mason,
... completed from the records of the late Alfred Clarke by John Grainger, ... London (A.
Brown &amp; Sons, ...) [1937]. Oct. (<em>Cat. Yorkshire fung.</em>).

<em>Author of records</em>: Alfred Clarke (1848-1925), <em>editor</em>: John Grainger (1904-x).
<em>Publ</em>.: Sep 1937, p. [i]-xii, [1]-110. <em>Copy</em>: Stevenson. – Lists of names for each vice-county.
	See also his Yorkshire Basidiomycetes, Naturalist 1928: 305-310.

Mason, Herbert Louis (1896-x), American botanist; B.A. Stanford 1922; Ph.D. Berkeley
1932; Mills. coll. 1923-1925; Univ. of Calif. Berkeley, in various functions from 1925. (<em>H.
Mason</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: UC; early collections at DS.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 457 (b. 3 Jan 1896); Bossert p. 256; Hortus 3:
1199 ("H. L. Mason"); IH 2: 511; Langman p. 483-484; Roon p. 74; Zander ed. 10, p. 689,
ed. 11, p. 786.
Reifschneider, O., Biogr. Nevada bot. 115-116. 1964 (portr.).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Mason published <em>A flora of the marshes of California</em>, Berkeley and Los Angeles
(University of California Press) 1957, viii, 878 p.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Masonophycus</em> W. A. Setchell &amp; N. L. Gardner (1930). <em>Note</em>: <em>Masonhalea</em> I.
Kärnefelt (1977) is dedicated to Mason Ellsworth Hale Jr. (1928-x), American lichenolo-
gist. <em>Masonia</em> G. Smith (1952), <em>Masoniella</em> G. Smith (1952) and <em>Masoniomyces</em> J. L. Crane &amp;
K. P. Dumont (1975), commemorate Edmund William Mason (1890-1975), English
mycologist, to whom also <em>Edmundmasonia</em> C. V. Subramanian (1958) is dedicated. The
derivation of <em>Masonia</em> C. P. Hansford (1944) is not given by Hansford.

Massalongo, Abramo Bartolommeo (1824-1860), Italian lichenologist and palaeobo-
tanist; high school teacher at Verona; with G. W. Koerber founder of the "Italian-Silesian"
school of lichenology. (<em>A. Massal.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: A major part of the original herbarium (mainly lichens and his
collection of fossils) is at VER.Massalongo's collections were offered for sale after his death
and some parts went elsewhere, e.g. to TO (see Anon., Oest. bot. Z. 11: 134-135. 1861), M,

PAGE: 350
HEADING: MASSALONGO

NAP (lich.), and PAD. Exsiccatae: <em>Lichenes italici exsiccati</em>, fasc. 1-10, nos. 1-360, 1855-1856.
Sets in several herbaria (see IH, Sayre, and Micheletti 1889). <em>Schedulae</em> with descriptions.
Massalongo specimens, from his herbarium, were included by Anzi in his <em>Lichenes rariores
veneti</em>. – Manuscripts and archival material at Museo eivieo di Verona.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Massalongo's name appears on several of his publieations with the initials D.A.B.P.,
standing for "Dottore A. B. Professore Massalongo".

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Andrews p. 301; Barnhart 2: 458; BM 3: 1262-1263; Bossert
p. 256; Cesati, Saggio p. 46; CSP 4: 277-278, 8: 351; De Toni 1: lxxxiii; DTS 1: 183; Frank

2: 511-512; Jackson p. 578; Kelly p. 143; Kew 3: 613-614; Krempelh. 1: front., 2: 221-309;

Massalongo, Caro Benigno (1852-1928), Italian botanist at Ferrara; son of A. B.
Massalongo. (<em>C. Massal.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Cecidia and hepatics: VER. Important material also at BM, FI, H.
L, PAD and VEN. – Exsiccatae: <em>Hepaticae italiae venetae exsiccatae</em> dec. 1-12, nos. 1-120, 1878-
1881; sets in many herbaria.

256; CSP 10: 742, 12: 491, 17: 74-76; DTS 1: 184; GR p. 534; Hawksworth p. 184; IH 2: 512;

Massart, Jean (1865-1925), Belgian botanist; curator at the Jardin botanique de l'État,
Bruxelles (1902-1905); director of the botanical institute Léo Errera (1906-1925). (<em>Mas-
sart</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BR.

<em>Ref</em>.: Ramsbottom, J., J. Bot. 52: 81-82. 1914, Mycol. Centralbl. 4: 207. 1914.

Masson, Francis (1741-1805), British plant collector and gardener, from Kew, at the
Cape (1772-1774), Canaries and Azores (1776-1782), Spain and Portugal (1781-1785),
Cape (1786-1795), N. America (1798). (<em>Masson</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Plant collector for Kew working for Joseph Banks. Masson's living
plants went to Kew and his herbarium specimens (mainly) to Banks (now BM) (some to
Lambert). Masson described no new taxa himself. The <em>Stapeliae novae</em> are 41 plates engraved
after drawings made by him in South Africa. These drawings are now also at BM. Masson
collected at the Cape (1772-1774, 1786-1795), Azores (1776), Canaries (1777), Madeira
(1778), West Indies (1779-1780), Spain and Portugal (1783), North Africa (1783), North
America and E. Canada (1798-1805). Duplicates of Masson's collections are in several
herbaria, e.g. BR, CGE, DBN, HAL, LD, LINN, MO, PH, UPS (Thunberg herb.).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: "NOW every garret and cottage-window is filled with numerous species of that
beautiful tribe [<em>Pelargonium</em>], and every greenhouse glows with the innumerable bulbous
plants and heaths of the Cape. For all these we are principally indebted to Mr. Masson ..."
(J. E. Smith, in Rees, Cycl. vol. 22, 1812).

PAGE: 362
HEADING: MASSON

5663. <em>Stapeliae novae</em>: or, a collection of several new species of that genus; discovered in the
interior parts of Africa by Francis Masson. London (printed by W. Bulmer and Co. for
George Nicol, ...) 1796. [-1797]. Fol. (<em>Stapel. nov.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: in four decades, 1796-1797, plates dated as below, p. [i]-viii, [9]-24, <em>pl. 1-41.</em> <em>Copies</em>: G,
	MO, NY (has in addition four original sketches), USDA; IDC 6059.
<em>Decas 1</em>: <em>pl. 1-10.</em> Apr 1776.

PAGE: 363
HEADING: MASTERS

<em>Decas 2</em>: <em>pl. 11-20.</em> Mar 1797.
<em>Decas 3</em>: <em>pl. 21-30.</em> 20 Mai 1797, but publ. Nov-Dec 1797.
<em>Decas 4</em>: <em>pl. 31-40.</em> 20 Jun 1797, <em>pl. 41</em>: 1 Jun 1797, almost certainly publ. 1798.
H. S. Miller (1970) mentions a statement by Lambert, dated 4 Nov 1776 that the first
number would appear "in a few days"; this agrees with a statement by Banks on 28 Sep
1797 to publish the fasc. "at once" (see Sotheby 509). Apart from this there is no indication
that the dates on dec. 1 and 2 are not those of publication (see also TL-1). The <em>plates</em> are
handcoloured engravings (line and stipple or roulette) of drawings by Masson (made in
Africa). – The text was in part reprinted by Usteri, P., Ann. Bot. 22: 14-19. – A <em>facsimile
</em>reprint was announced by Asher (1974).

Masters, Maxwell Tylden (1833-1907), British physician and botanist; MD. St. An-
drews 1862; lecturer, St. George's Hospital, 1855-1868; editor of Gardnener's Chronicle
1865-1907. (<em>Mast</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: K; British material at Canterbury Museum; for duplicates see IH.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 357; BB p. 210; BFM 2421; BJI 1: 39, 2: 113; BM
3: 1264-1265; Bossert p. 256; Clokie p. 208; CSP 4: 280-281, 8: 352, 10: 743-744, 12: 491-
492, 17: 81-82; Desmond p. 427; DNB suppl. 2. 2: 586: Herder p. 465; Hortus 3: 1199
("Mast., M. T."); IH 2: 513; Jackson p. 579 [index]; Kew 3: 617-618; Langman p. 484; LS
17303, 36718-36733; Moebius p. 305; Morren ed. 2., p. 24, ed. 10, p. 72, 73; MW p. 302-
303, suppl. p. 220; NAF 28B: 345, ser. 2: 165; NI 1302; Plesch p. 329; PH 567; PR 5972-
5973; Rehder 5: 553-554; TL-1/1039; TL-2/1: 978, 1814, 2448, 2981; Tucker 1: 468-469;
Zander ed. 10, p. 689, ed. 11, p, 786 (b. 15 Apr 1833, d. 30 Mai 1907).
Anon., Bot. Centralbl. 105: 16. 1907 (d.); Bot. Jahrb. 40(Beibl. 92): 46. 1908 (d.); Gard.
	Magaz. 50: 419. 1907 (portr.); J. R. Hortic. Soc. London 35: fig. 35. 1910 (portr.; on
	Masters memorial lectures); Nat. Nov. 29: 321. 1907 (d. 29 Mai [err.!] 1907); ÖbZ 57:
	367. 1907(d.); Orchid Review 15: 201-202. 1907; The Garden 8 Jun 1907, p. vi; Torreya
	7: 156. 1907.
Britten, J., J. Bot. 45: 257-258. 1907 (portr.).
Bullock, A. A., Bibl. S. Afr. bot. 75. 1978.
Druce, G. C, Fl. Oxfordshire 397. 1886.

Mattick, Wilhelm Fritz (1901-x), German lichenologist; student of O. Drude and F.
Tobler; Dr. rer. techn. Dresden 1927; assistant Technische Hochschule Dresden 1927-
1932; assistant at Berlin-Dahlem 1932-1945; at Staatsstelle f. Vegetationskartierung,
Stolzenau/Weser 1946-1947; from 1947 again at Berlin-Dahlem, 1947-1953 assistant,
1953-1964 "Kustos," 1964-1966 "Wiss. Oberrath"; professor of plant geography Freie
Univ. 1958; in retirement still working at Berlin-Dahlem (1980).(<em>Mattick</em>).

Matuda, Eizi (1894-1978), Japanese-born Mexican botanist; specialist on Araceae and
Meliaceae; at Taihoku University 1911-1921; emigrated to Mexico 1922 (naturalized
1928); in Chiapas from 1922; teaching at University of Mexico 1950-1978; Dr. phil. h.c.
Tokyo 1962. (<em>Matuda</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: MEXU; other large sets at F and MICH; for duplicates see IH.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 463+ Bossert p. 258+ Hortus 3: 1199
("Matuda"); IF suppl. 4: 330; IH 1(ed. 6): 361, 2: 516; Langman p. 486-488 (!); MW
suppl. p. 221, 223; Roon p. 75; Zander ed. 10, p. 690, ed. 11, p. 786-787 (b. 20 Apr 1894).
Croat, T. B., Aroideana 1(1): 27. 1978.
Knobloch, I. W., Pl. coll. N. Mexico 42. 1979.
Mains, E. B., <em>in</em> W. A. Donelly et al., The University of Michigan, an encyclopaedic survey
	1454. 1956 (coll. at MICH).
Moldenke, N. H., Plant Life 2: 71. 1946 (1948) (epon.).
Smith, L. B., J. Bromel. Soc. 24(2): 59-62. 1974 (portr., tribute).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Matudacalamus</em> Maekawa (1961); <em>Matudaea</em> Lundell (1940); <em>Matudanthus</em> Hunt
(1978); <em>Matudina</em> R. King &amp; H. Robinson (1973).

living in Schlagendorf und Kesmark (Kežmarok), botanical explorer of the Tatra; colla-

	Mauksch).

Maund, Benjamin (1790-1864), British pharmacist, botanist and bookseller; at Broms-

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. The original drawings for the Botanic Garden are at
BM.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 465; BB p. 211; Blunt p. 300; BM 3: 1270, 7:
814; Desmond p. 429; DNB 37: 91; DU 199-201; GF p. 85; Herder p. 146, 361; Hortus 3:
1199 ("Maund"); IH 2: 517 (refers to plates); Jackson p. 579 [index]; Kew 3: 630;
Langman p. 489; MW p. 310-311; NAF ser. 2. 2: 165; NI (alph.), 1315n; Plesch p. 331; PR
6004-6005 (ed. 1: 6673-6674); Rehder 5: 556; TL-1/813-814; TL-2/see Henslow, J. S.;
Tucker 1: 472; Zander ed. 10, p. 690, ed. 11, p. 787.
Allibone, S. A., Crit. dict. Engl. lit. Brit. Amer. auth. 1247-1248. 1870.
Anon., Proc. Linn. Soc. 8: xxx-xxxi. 1864 (d. 21 Apr 1863).
Britten, J., J. Bot. 56: 235-243. 1918 (<em>Botanist</em>).

Jessen, K. F. W., Bot. Gegenw. Vorz. 394. 1884.
Rendle, A. B., J. Bot. 66: 184. 1928.
Woodward, B. B.,<em>in</em> G. Murray, Hist. coll. BM(NH) 1:42. 1904 (orig. drawings <em>Bot. Gard.</em>).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Maundia</em> F. von Mueller (1858) commemorates John Maund, a medical doctor
about whom we have no further information, except that he died in or before 1858.

5712. <em>The Botanic Garden</em>; consisting of highly finished representations of hardy ornamental
flowering plants, cultivated in Great Britain; with their names, classes, orders, history,
qualities, culture and physiological observations ... London (published by Baldwin and
Chadock) 1825-1831, 13 vols. Qu. (<em>Bot. Gard.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: [Cardew, q.v. for further details] In monthly numbers consisting of one coloured
	plate representing four flowers (also numbered serially) and four leaves of text, one
	dealing with each. The 12 (dated) monthly numbers of a year constituted a part, the
	parts of two years formed a volume, so that the publication was running on four series of
	numeration: 13 volumes, 26 parts, 312 monthly numbers, 312 plates, 1248 figures. There
	were two issues: "Large" (e.g. US copy, with engraved t.p.'s) and "Small" (e.g. NY
	copy; not always with engr. t.p.'s). The analysis given below is based on the copy at NY.
	<em>Copies</em>: G, L, NY (orig. covers), US (vols. 1-9), USDA; IDC 7358.

<em>Vol. 1</em>: Jan 1825-Dec 1826, p. [i-x], <em>pl. 1-24</em> (4 plants per plate, see above; 1-2 p. text/plant).
<em>Vol. 2</em>: Jan 1827-Dec 1828, p. [i-viii], <em>pl. 25-48</em> (id.).
<em>Vol. 3</em>: Jan 1829-Dec 1830, p. [i-vi], <em>pl. 49-72</em> (id.).
<em>Vol. 4</em>: Jan 1831-Dec 1832, p. [i-x], <em>pl. 73-96</em> (id.).
<em>Vol. 5</em>: Jan 1833-Dec 1834, p. [i-viii], <em>pl. 97-120</em> (id.) (t.p.: 1834-5).
<em>Vol. 6</em>: Jan 1835-Dec 1836, [i, engr. t.p.], [iii-vhi], <em>pl. 121-144</em> (id.).
<em>Vol. 7</em>: s.d. [Jan 1837-Dec 1838], [i, engr. t.p.], [iii-viii], <em>pl. 145-168</em> (id.).
<em>Vol. 8</em>: s.d. [Jan 1839-Dec 1840], [i, engr. t.p.], [iii-vi], <em>pl. 169-192</em> (id.).
<em>Vol. 9</em>: s.d. [Jan 1841-Dec 1842], [i, engr. t.p.], [iii-ix], <em>pl. 193-216</em> (id.).
<em>Vol. 10</em>: s.d. [Jan 1843-Dec 1844], [i-vi],<em>pl. 217-240</em> (id.).
<em>Vol. 11</em>: s.d. [Jan 1845-Nov 1846], [i-vi], <em>pl. 241-265</em> (id.).
<em>Vol. 12</em>: s.d. [Feb 1847-Dec 1848], [i-viii], <em>pl. 265-288</em> (id.).
<em>Vol. 13</em>: s.d. [Jan 1849-Dec 1850], [i-xxii], <em>pl. 289-312</em> (id.).
<em>Later editions</em>: 1878, 12 vols., ed. by James C. Niven; 3 vols. of orig. ed. re-issued 1851-1854.

PAGE: 378
HEADING: MAUND

5713. <em>The botanist</em>; containing accurately coloured figures, of tender and hardy ornamental
plants; with descriptions, scientific and popular; intended to convey both moral and
intellectual gratification ... London (published by R. Groombridge, ...), Edinburgh (W.
White and Co., ...), Dublin (Robertson and Co.,...), Paris (M. Galignian, ...), Brussels
(Hauman and Co., ...), New York (Jackson, ...) [1836-1842], 5 vols. Qu. and Oct.
† (<em>Botanist</em>).

<em>Co-author</em>: John Stevens Henslow (1796-1861).
<em>Publ</em>.: Twelve monthly parts of 4 plates each with a supplement of 2 plates each year. Vol.
	nos. 1-4, dated Jan-Apr 1837 appeared on Sep 1836, Nov 1836, Jan 1837 and Mar 1837
	respectively, parts 5-12 (Mar-Dec 1837) were on schedule. Volumes 2-4 and vol. 5 (nos.
	1-8) appeared on schedule, except <em>pl. 201-203</em> which came out in 1841. Parts 9-12 of vol. 5
	were delayed, the December issue being issued in 1842. Each volume had an engraved
	t.p. as well as a printed one. There were two issues: large paper and small paper (copies
	cited). See Britten (1918) and Cardew (1958) for further details and NI (1224) for details
	on artists. <em>Copies</em>: G, MO, NY(orig. covers), USDA. – The analysis given below is that of
	the copy at G.

<em>1</em>: 1836-1837 (see above), engr. t.p., p. [i*-iii* [i]-iv, [v-vi], <em>pl. 1-50.</em>
<em>2</em>: 1838, engr. t.p., p. [i-vi], <em>pl. 50-100</em> (col. liths. with text).
<em>3</em>. 1839, engr. t.p., p.[i-vi], <em>pl. 101-150</em> (id.).

Maurizio, Adam (1862-1941), Rhaetian (Bündner, Swiss) botanist, born in Cracow; Dr.
phil. Bern 1894; assistant at the Schule für Wein- Obst- und Gartenbau Wädensweil 1896;
at the Versuchsstation für Müllerei der Landwirthschaftlichen Hochschule, Berlin 1899
(with L. Wittmack); at the Landwirthschaftliche Versuchsstation Zürich 1900; habil.
Zürich E.T.H. 1903; professor of botany at the Technische Hochschule, Lemberg [Lwow]
1907; ordinary professor ib. 1911-1923; at Bromberg (Bydgoszcz) 1923-1927; at the
Faculty of Pharmacy, Warsaw 1927-1935; from 1935-1941 back in Switzerland (<em>Maurizio</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

Maximowicz, Carl Johann (Ivanovic) (1827-1891), Russian botanist and explorer, at
St. Petersburg from 1852; travelled in Eastern Asia 1853-1857 and in China and Japan
1859-1864; curator of the St. Petersburg herbaria (Bot. Gard. and Academy). (<em>Maxim</em>.).

Mayer, Anton (1867-1951), German algologist and specialist on <em>Rubus</em> and <em>Salix</em> at
Regensburg; studied at the teachers college of Altdorf; teacher at Eschenfeld 1887-1888.
from 1888-1932 at various schools in Regensburg, from 1900 at the Müllersche Töchter-
schule (girls Gymnasium). (<em>An. Mayer</em>).

Mayer, Johann Prokop (1737-1804), Bohemian horticulturist and botanist; later at
Würzburg. (<em>J. P. Mayer</em>).

franken und Aschaffenburg, at Würzburg (fide NI).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 467 (b. 2 Jul 1737, d. 25 Jun 1804); BM 3: 1273;

5748. <em>Pomona franconica</em>. Description des arbres fruitiers, les plus connus et les plus estimés
en Europe, qui se cultivent maintenant au jardin de la cour de Wurzbourg; avec la
représentation èxacte [sic] de leurs fruits, en figures en taille-douce, dessinées, gravées et
enluminées d'après nature. On y a joint les détails les plus interessants sur leur culture,
greffe, plantation &amp;c. ... A Nuremberg [Nürnberg] (chez Adam Wolfgang Winter-
schmidt, ...) 1776-1801, 3 vols. Qu. (<em>Pom. francon.</em>).

<em>1</em>: 1776 (p. xxxvi: 4 Jan 1776), p. [i]-civ, [1]-152, map of garden, <em>pl. 1-8, 1-8, 1-17.</em>

PAGE: 390
HEADING: MAYR, H.

	30 Jan 1891), p. [i*-iii*], i-viii, [1]-104, <em>pl. 1-7</em> (col. liths.). <em>Copies</em>: BR, E, G, NY, U,
	USDA; IDC 7371.
<em>Re-issue</em>: 1895, n.v. fide Bot. Zeit. 16 Apr 1895 ("billige Ausgabe").
<em>Note</em>: According to the Prospectus of Rieger at München (Mai 1891), the book had just been
received from Japan and was now available. The copy at E has a loose sheet dated 6 Mai
1891 in which the München publisher sends it out for review. This would point at
distribution from the European center in 1891. However, the notes in Nat. Nov. and Bot.
Zeit. might be based on copies received directly from Japan; we therefore accept for the
moment publication in 1890 in agreement with the t.p. date.
<em>Ref</em>.: Jännicke, Bot. Centralbl. 46: 129-136. 1891 (rev.) (ann. 2 Jan 1891).

Mazé, Hippolyte Pierre (1818-1892), French naval author who collected in the West
Indies. (<em>Mazé</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: The original herbarium, made jointly with Alphons Schramm
(1823-1875), was destroyed at Guadeloupe in 1871. Important sets of Mazé material,
especially algae, are at BM, K, L and PC.

Medikus, Friedrich Kasimir (1736-1808) [Medicus, Friedrich Casimir], German bota-
nist; in charge of the Mannheim botanic garden from 1766; at Schwetzingen and Mann-
heim. (<em>Medik</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>NAME</sm>: Friedrich Kasimir Medikus on title pages of publications until 1786; in 1771 and
from 1786 onward Friedrich Kasimir Medicus; Brosi (1958) found Friedrich Casimir
Medikus to be correct.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Ainsworth p. 18, 298; Barnhart 2: 470; BM 3: 1277; CSP 4:
319, 17: 127; Dryander 3: 48, 83, 203, 207, 217, 276, 291, 313, 370, 394, 399, 442, 444, 611,
616, 623, 636, 647; 5: 350; DSB 9: 253-254; Frank 3(Anh.): 63; Herder p. 465 [index];
Hortus 3: 1199 ("Medic."); Jackson p. 3, 429; Kew 3: 637-638; LS 17632-17634; Moebius
p. 323, 328, 395; PR 6028-6043 (ed. 1: 6712-6728); Rehder 5: 559-560; RS p. 118; SO 721,
753a; TL-1/819-821; Tucker 1: 475-476; Zander ed. 10, p. 690, ed. 11, p. 787 (d. 15 Jul
1808).
Brosi, M., Bull. Soc. bot. Suisse 68: 397-398. 1958 (on the use of "L.W. Medikus" in Fiori,
	A., <em>Nuova fl. anal. Italia</em>. Ludwig Wallrad Medikus, 8 Aug 1771-18 Sep 1850, prof. of
	agric. München, did not describe new taxa; the father's name is correctly Friedrich
	Casimir Medikus).
Fries, Th. M., Bref Skrifv. Linné 1(3): 261. 1909.
Fuchs, H. P., J. Soc. Bibl. nat. Hist. 4: 63-65. 1962.
Jessen, K. F. W., Bot. Gegenw. Vorz. 319, 331, 388. 1884.
Jourdan, A. J. L., Dict. Sci. méd., Biogr. méd. 6: 245-246. 1824.
Lütjeharms, W.J., Gesch. Mykol. 52, 86, 118, 123, 171, 177. 1936.
Medikus, F. C., Beiträge zur Kultur exotischer Gewächse. Mannheim 1806, autobiogra-
	phy, 3 p. following p. 264 (bibl.).
Poggendorff, J. C., Biogr.-lit. Handw.-Buch 2: 99. 1863 (d. 15 Jul 1809).
Reynolds, G. W., Aloes South Africa 91. 1950 (on <em>Theodora</em>).
Sachs, J. v., Hist. botanique 277. 1892.
Schmid, G., Sv. Linné Sällsk. Årsskr. 20: 47-70. 1937.
Stafleu, F. A., <em>in</em> Lawrence, G. H. M., ed., Adanson 1: 299. 1963; Linnaeus and the
	Linnaeans 252, 256, 260-265. 1971.
Stearn, W. T., <em>in</em> Cat. Bot. Books Hunt 2: xli-cxl. 1961; <em>in</em> C. Moench, Methodus, facs. ed.,
	1966, p. xi-xv; see also DSB.
Zuchold, E. A., Jahresber. naturf. Ver. Halle 5: 38. 1853.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Medicusia</em> Moench (1794) might commemorate F. K. Medikus ("In memoriam
Cl. Medici, observatioris acutissimi").

5771. <em>Theodora speciosa</em> ein neues Pflanzen Geschlecht. Seiner churfürstlichen Durchlaucht
von Pfalz-Baiern geheiliget. Nebst einem Entwurfe, die künstliche und natürliche Methode
in Ordnung des Pflanzenreiches zugleich anzuwenden, als der sichersten, ein Pflanzenken-
ner zu werden. Von Friedrich Kasimir Medikus, ... mit vier Kupfertafeln. Mannheim (in
der neuen Hof- und akademischen Buchhandlung) 1786. Oct. (<em>Theodora</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1786, p. [1]-116, <em>pl. 1-4</em> (uncol. copper engr. A. Karcher). <em>Copies</em>: FI, G, L, M, MO,
	NY, USDA; IDC 8135. – The copy at M has a coloured original drawing by Medicus
	himself of <em>Theodora speciosa</em>.

5772. <em>Ueber einige künstliche Geschlechter aus der Malven-Familie</em>, denn der Klasse der Monadel-
phien. Mit beigefügtem Urtheile über Linneische Geschlechter, und deren Klassifikation;
über Herbarien und Terminologie; dann Empfehlung einer Sammlung von Fruchtgehäu-
sen, und deren Saamen; vorzüglich einer genauen Zergliederung sämtlicher
Fruktifikations-Theile jeder Pflanze. Von Friedrich Kasimir Medicus ... Mannheim (in
der neuen Hof- und akademischen Buchhandlung) 1787. Oct. (<em>Malvenfam</em>.).

<em>Publ</em>.: before 9 Mai 1787 (Manitz 1975), p. [i], [1]-158. <em>Copies</em>: FI, G, M, MO, NY, USDA;
	IDC 840.

<em>Publ</em>.: 2 Hefte 1789-1791. <em>Copies</em>: FI, G, MO, NY, U, USDA; IDC 8138.

5774. <em>Über den gynandrischen Situs der Staubfäden und Pistille einiger Pflanzen</em>. München s.d. Qu. (<em>Gynandr. Situs</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Apr-Jun 1790 in Hist. Comment. [Acta] Acad. Theod.-Palat. pars phys. 6 (1790); no
	reprints are known to have been made at the time of publication. The publisher Franz at
	Munich offered copies of the articles from the Acta for sale separately in 1830, announ-
	cing them erroneously as of the year 1787.
<em>Ref</em>.: Fuchs, H.P., J. Soc. Bibl. nat. Hist. 4: 63-65. 1962.

Medlicott, Henry Benedict (1829-1905), British geologist; from 1854 until 1887 with the
Geological Survey of India; 1854-1862 also professor of geology at Rurki; Mutiny Medal
1857; from 1876-1885 director of the Survey. (<em>Medlicott</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Andrews p. 302; BM 3: 1277-1278; CSP 4: 319, 8: 368, 10:
760-761, 17: 128; Quenstedt p. 287.
Anon., Rec. Geol. Survey India 20: 121-122. 1887 (bibl.).
Blandford, W. T., Rec. Geol. Survey India 32: 233-241. 1905.
Poggendorff, J. C, Biogr.-lit. Handw.-Buch 3: 893. 1898, 4(2): 981. 1904 (b. 8 Aug 1829),
	5(2): 826 (d. 6 Apr 1905).
R. L., Quart. J. Geol. Soc. London 62: lx-lxi. 1906.
Zittel, K. A. von, Hist. geol. palaeontol. 210, 211, 310, 457. 1901.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Medlicottipites</em> B. Biswas (1962).

5782. <em>A manual of the geology of India</em>. Chiefly compiled from the observations of the
Geological Survey. Calcutta (sold at the office of the Superintendent of Government
Printing; Geological Survey office; ...) London (Trübner &amp; Co.) 1879. Oct. (<em>Man. geol.
India</em>).

<em>Co-author</em>: William Thomas Blandford (1832-1905).
<em>Publ</em>.: 1879, p. [i]-xviii, [i]-lxxx, [1]-444. <em>Copy</em>: Teyler.

Meehan, Thomas (1826-1901), British-born nurseryman; Kew gardener 1846-1848;
from 1853 at Germantown (Philadelphia). (<em>Meehan</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Material at GH, NY and PH.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 470; BB p. 212; BJI 1: 39; BM 3: 1278; Bossert
p. 262; CSP 4: 319, 8:368-370, 10: 761-762, 12:496, 17: 128-130; DAB (by Harshberger);

509; Kew 3: 638; Langman p. 496; Lenley p. 284; LS 17640-17651, 36872-36881; ME 1:
211, 2: 208, 582, 3: 467,484; Morren ed. 2, p. 36, ed. 10, p. 129; MW suppl. p. 224; NI 1331;
PR (alph.); Rehder 5: 560-562; SO 880a; Tucker 1: 476-477.
Anon., Bot. Gaz. 32: 443-444. 1901; Bot. Not. 1902: 94 (b. 26 Mar 1826, d. 19 Oct 1901);
	Fern Bull. 9: 87-88. 1901 (portr.), 10: 29. 1902; Gard. Chron. ser. 3. 29: 285-286, 382-

Meerburgh, Nicolaas (1734-1814), Dutch gardener; curator of the Leiden botanical
garden 1774-1814. (<em>Meerb</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: A small number of plants from the Leiden garden is at E and at L.
The original herbarium of 5000 "species" was offered for sale by his son in 1816, but the
present location is unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Aa 12(1): 484, Barnhart 2: 470; BM 3: 1278; Dawson p.
536, 866; Dryander 5: 350-351; DU 203-204; GF p. 67; Herder p. 146; Hortus 3: 1199
("Meerb."); HU 705; IH 2: 521; Jackson p. 33, 113; JW 1: 446, 3: 362, 5: 246; Kew 3: 639;
Lenley p. 284; MW p. 315; NAF 28B(2): 345; NI 1333-1334; Plesch p. 333; PR 6044-6047
(ed. 1: 6732-6734); Rehder 5: 562; RS p. 74; Sotheby 527; TL-1/822-824; TL-2/1: see
Gorter, D. de; Tucker 1: 477; Zander ed. 10, p. 690-691, ed. 11, p. 787.
Anon., Alg. Konst. Letterb. 1816(2): 240 (herb. for sale).
Forbes, R. J., ed., Mart. v. Marum 3: 256. 1971.
Fuchs, H. P., Acta bot. neerl. 11: 69-89. 1962, 12: 12-16. 1963 (updates nomenclature of the
	three illustrated works by M.).
Hedge, I. C. &amp; J. M. Lamond, Index coll. Edinb. herb. 109. 1970 (pl. E).
Stafleu, F. A., Linnaeus and the Linnaeans 173, 183. 1971.
Steenis-Kruseman, M. J. v., Blumea 25: 34. 1979 (coll. L).
Thunberg, C. P., Voyages au Japon 1: 23. 1796.
Veendorp, H. &amp; L. G. M. Baas-Beeking, Hortus acad. lugd.-bat. 130-131, 137, 142. 1938.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Meerburgia</em> [sic] Moench (1802).

5784. <em>Afbeeldingen van zeldzame gewassen</em>... te Leyden (by Johannes le Mair) 1775[-1780].
Fol. (<em>Afb. zeldz. gew.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1775-1780, in five parts, p. [i-xxiv], <em>pl. 1-50 Copies</em>: MO; IDC 441. – See Sotheby 527
	for a copy with <em>55 plates</em>. We have seen no such copy. – The contents and the dates were
	established by H. P. Fuchs (1962), who added (1963) further nomenclatural details, e.g.
	on the legitimate name <em>Impatiens capensis</em> Meerburgh.

HEADING: MEESE

1	[8]	1-10	10 Nov 1775	4	[4]	31-40	31 Dec 1777
2	[4]	11-20	14 Jun 1776	5	[4]	41-50	25 Dec 1780
3	[4]	21-30	26 Mai 1777

The coloured plates were drawn and engraved by Meerburgh himself. The Plesch copy has
<em>55 pl</em>. (see Sotheby), see below: <em>Pl. rar. depict.</em>

5785. <em>Plantae rariores vivis coloribus depictae</em>... Lugduni Batavorum [Leiden] (apud Jacobum
Meerburg) 1789. Fol. (<em>Pl. rar. depict.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1789, probably late. A reprint of the <em>Afb. zeldz. gew.</em> with <em>55 pl</em>. and 4 extra pages of
	text, p. [1-27], <em>pl. 1-55. Copies</em>: BR, G, HU, MO, NY, U, USDA: IDC 6062. The plates are
	etchings, coloured by hand. "Clumsy unconvincing etching; colouring thin and poor"
	(DU).

5786. <em>Plantae selectarum icones pictae</em>... Lugduni Batavorum [Leiden] (apud J. Meerburg)
1798. Fol. (<em>Pl. select. icon. pict.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1798 – 12 unnumbered pages and 28 coloured plates (<em>1-28</em>, no. 19 as "29"), drawn
	and engraved by Meerburgh himself. – The book was reviewed in J. Bot. Schrader 2(1):
	152. 1799 (sem. 2). <em>Copies</em>: BR, G, MO, NY, USDA; IDC 6063. – The plates are crude
	etchings, coloured by hand.
<em>Ref</em>.: Schrader, H. J., Bot. 2(1): 152. 1799 (sem. 2).

Meese, David (1723-1770), Dutch gardener at Franeker. (<em>Meese</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: In the former Franeker herbarium which is now at GRO.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Aa 12(1): 521; Barnhart 2: 470 (b. 25 Dec 1723); BM 3:
1279; De Toni 1: lxxxiii; Dryander 5: 351;. Herder p. 253, 304; IH 2: 521; JW 1: 446, 2: 197
(d. 23 Aug 1770), 3: 362; LS 17653; Moebius p. 119, 293; NNBM 10: 601; Oudemans p.
236; PR 6048-6050 (ed. 1: 6737-6739); Rehder 5: 562; SO 303, 638b; TL-1/825-826;
Tucker 1: 477.
Andreas, C. H., In en om een botanische tuin, Hortus Groningianus 1626-1966, p. 102,
	1976.
Forbes, R. J., ed., Martinus van Marum 3: 259. 1971.
Hornschuch, C. F., Flora 8: 215, 229-230. 1825 (on his moss experiments).
Hulth, J. M. &amp; A. H. Uggla, Bref Skrifv. Linné 2(2): 210, 211, 213. 1943.
Mulder, N., Oratio de meritis Davidis Meese, cum botanicis, turn aliis; publice habita ad
	diem 1 Octobris mdcccxxii, Groningen 1822, 30 p.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Meesia</em> J. Gaertner (1788, <em>nom. rej.</em>); <em>Meesia</em> J. Hedwig (1801, <em>nom. cons.</em>).

5787. <em>Flora frisica</em> of lyst der planten welke in de provintie Friesland in het wilde gevonden
worden. Waarby gevoegt is een korte beschrijvinge van booven-genoemde landschap.
Door David Meese, hovenier in de kruid-tuin aan Frieslands Hooge-Schole te Franeker.
Franeker (gedrukt by Jacob Brouwer ...) 1760. Oct. (<em>Fl. fris</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Aug-Oct 1760 (p. viii: 9 Feb 1758; Ned. Letter-Courant 24 Oct 1760; Linnaeus had a
	copy by late Feb 1761 fide letter to J. Burman), p. [i-xii], [1]-87, [88, err.], <em>pl. 1-2. Copies</em>:
	G, KNAW, L, NY. – Plates uncol. copp. engr.
<em>Facsimile ed</em>.: 1978, Leiden (Boerhaave Press), ISBN 90-70153-09-2. <em>Copies</em>: FAS(2).
<em>Ref</em>.: Jansen en Wachter, Ned. kruidk. Arch. 49: 254-257. 1939 (on Meese's bryophytes).

5788. <em>Het xix classe van de Genera Plantarum</em> van de Heer Carolus Linnaeus, Syngenesia
genaamt. Opgeheldert en vermeerdert. Mitsgaders een bericht van een nieuw-botanisch
stuk, aangaande het leeren kennen der planten kort na hunne geboorte of uitspruiting uyt
hun zaad. Als meede de beschrijving en afbeelding van een zeldzame en zonderlinge zee-
plant ... te Leeuwarden (by H. A. de Chalmot) 1761. Oct. (<em>XIX cl. Gen. Pl.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1761 (p. [vi*]: 16 Jan 1761), p. [i*-vi*], [i]-iv, [1]-152. [1-6, index, err.], <em>pl. 1-7</em>, [<em>8</em>]
	(uncol. copp.). <em>Copies</em>: G, L, USDA.

PAGE: 400
HEADING: MEESE

5789. <em>Plantarum rudimenta</em>, sive illarum methodus. Ducta ex differentia earum seminum,
cotyledonum, aliarumque partium, quae brevi tempore post earum propullulationem, ac
ulterius incrementum, in iis conspiciuntur; quorum omnium utilatem praefatio satis
superque lectorem docebit. Investigata, effecta ac composita a Davide Meese ... Leovar-
diae [Leeuwarden] (Excudit Guilielmus Coulon, ...) 1763. Qu. †. (<em>Pl. rudim.</em>).

<em>Pars I</em>: 1763 (preface 1 Mar 1762), p. [i-Iv], [1]-23, [24, index], <em>pl. 1-2</em> (coll. copp.), [i-vii,
	err., ind.].
<em>Pars II</em>: 1763, p. 25-81, <em>pl. 3-7</em>, 82 [1-10, index, err.].
<em>Copies</em>: B-S, USDA. – Dutch title: <em>Eerste beginselen der planten</em>, of leerwijze der zelve ..." – The
	remaining manuscript is in the Leiden University Library.

Méhu, Marie Antoine Adolphe (1840-1881), French botanist; Dr. pharm. Montpellier
1867, from 1867-1881 pharmacist at Villefranehe-sur-Saône, Rhône, from 1871 also
professor of botany at the École normale. (<em>Méhu</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: For a description of M's herbarium and library, then still at his
home, see Chaboisseau (1876).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 471; BL 2: 115; CSP 8: 372; Jackson p. 284; PR
6054; Rehder 5: 562; Tucker 1: 477.
Anon., Ann. Soc. bot. Lyon 9(2):xviii. 1882 (d.); Bull. Soc. bot. France 28: 246, (Bibl.) 140.
	1881; Feuille jeunes Natural. 12: 24. 1882 (d.).
Audin, M. &amp; T. Chaboisseau, Adolphe Méhu s.l. 1904, 23 p. (reprinted from Bull. Soc. Sci.
	Arts Beaujolais Avril-Juin 1904) (biogr., bibl., portr., b. 27 Sep 1840, d. 9 Oct 1881).
Chaboisseau, abbé, Bull. Soc. bot. France 23: cxcvi-cxcix. 1876 (herb., libr.); 29: 73-76.
	1882.
Flahault, C., Univ. Montpellier, Inst. Bot. 36. 1890 (brief note).
Magnin, A., Bull. Soc. bot. Lyon 32: 59. 1907 (b. 27 Sep 1840, d. 9 Oct 1881), 35: 50. 1910.

5790. <em>Herborisations dans les montagnes d'Hauteville</em>, du Colombier du Bugey et du Pilat ...
Lyon (Association typographique ...) 1876. Oct. 

<em>Co-authors</em>: (p. 31-36) Louis Antoine Cusin (1824-1901) (p. 17-30) Jean-Baptiste Saint-
	Lager (1825-1912).
<em>Publ</em>.: Jun 1876 (BSbF 14 Jul 1876), p. [1]-16, [17]-39. <em>Copy</em>: G. – Reprinted and to be cited
	from Ann. Soc. bot. Lyon 3(2): 116-127. 1876.
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Bull. Soc.bot. France 23(C.R.): 239, (Bibl.): 68-69 (sess. extr. juin-juillet): civ
	(distribué d'avance). 1873.

Meigen, Johann Wilhelm (1764-1845), German dipterologist and botanist; private
teacher at Aachen 1784-1786, organist and teacher at Solingen 1786-1792, again at Aachen
1792-1796; teacher (French, geography, history, music) at a private school at Stolberg nr
Aachen 1796-1810; secretary of the Stolberg chamber of commerce during the French
occupation; variously employed, e.g. drawing geographical maps 1812-1825, finally orga-
nist of the Stolberg protestant church. (<em>Meigen</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 471 (b. 3 Mai 1764, d. 11 Jul 1845); BM 3:
1280; CSP 4: 322; Herder p. 186; PR 6057-6059 (ed. 1: 6745-6747); Rehder 5: 562; SO add.
828d.
Anon., Bot. Not. 1845: 220; Bot. Zeit. 3: 624. 1845; Flora 28: 544. 1845 (d. 11 Jul 1845).
Boventer, K., Südhoffs Arch. Gesch. Med. 44: 45-53. 1960 (biogr., b. 3 Mai 1764, d. 11 Jul
	1845, portr., bibl. [1798 item erroneous]).
Förster, J. A., Entom. Zeit., Stettin 7(3): 66-74, 7(5):130-141. 1846 (obit. "Unstreitig der
	älteste Veteran in der Entomologie"), English translation (p.p.) in Mosquito systematics
	6: 79-87. 1974.
Gilbert, P., Comp. biogr. lit. deceased entom. 251. 1977.
Howard, L. O., Smithson. misc. Coll. 84: 202, 203-204. 1930.
Marquardt, M., Ann. Soc. entom. ser. 2. 5: 323-334, lxxvi-lxxvii. 1847 (obit.); English
	translation (p.p.) <em>in</em> Mosquito systematics 6: 87-88. 1974.

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: Beitr. Entom. 24 (Sonderheft): 157-161. 1974.

5791. <em>Systematisches Verzeichniss der an den Ufern des Rheins</em>, der Roer, der Maas, der Ourte,
und in den angränzenden Gegenden wild <em>wachsenden</em> und gebaut werdenden phanerogami-
schen <em>Pflanzen</em>. In Beziehung auf die von den Herausgebern gelieferten und noch zu
liefernden Herbarien ... Köln (gedruckt und verlegt von H. Rommerskirchen) 1819. Qu. (<em>Syst. Verz. Ufern Rheins Pfl.</em>).

<em>Co-author</em>: H. L. Weniger (<em>fl</em>. 1819).
<em>Publ</em>.: Nov 1819 (p. viii: Jul 1819; Flora 28 Nov 1819 "nunmehr erschienen.), p. [i]-viii,
	[1]-108. <em>Copies</em>: B-S, BR. – We have found no record of the five centuries of phanerogams
	issued by the authors as mentioned in the text.

5792. <em>Versuch einer Flora der Ufer des Niederrheins</em>, der Roër, der Maas, der Ourte, und den
angränzenden Gegenden. Enthaltend die Charakteristik der Klassen, Ordnungen und
Arten der Pflanzen, nach Linné's Systeme, so wie den medizinischen, chemischen, techno-
logischen und ökonomischen Nutzen derselben. Für Naturfreunde, Apotheker und Gärt-
ner Nach Anleitung von J. W. Meigen's und H. L. Weniger's systematischem Verzeichnis-
se. Nebst alphabetisch geordneten Registern, einem Lateinischen und Deutschen Cöln
[Köln] (Verlag von Rommerskirchen's Buchhandlung) 1823. 18-mo. (<em>Vers. Fl. Ufer Nie-
derrheins</em>).

<em>Co-author</em>: H. L. Weniger.
<em>Publ</em>.: 1823 (p. xxxii: 1 Mar 1823), p. [i]-xxxii, [1]-518. <em>Copies</em>: B-S, BR.
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Flora 7: 92-93. 14 Feb 1824 (rev.).

5793. <em>Deutschlands Flora</em>, oder systematische Beschreibung der in Deutschland wildwach-
senden und im Freien angebaut werdenden Pflanzen ... Essen (bei G. D. Bädeker) 1836-
1842. Oct. (<em>Deutschl. Fl.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: In three volumes, each of which came out in three Hefte. <em>Copies</em>: B, G(orig. covers),
	NY USDA. – Plate <em>49</em> often bound with vol. 1.
<em>1</em>(<em>1</em>): 1836 (t.p. cover; p. vii: Aug 1836; Flora 14 Jul 1836), p. [i]-xx, [1]-140, <em>pl. 1-16</em>
	(uncol.).
	(<em>2</em>): 1836 (Flora 14 Jul 1836), p. 141-300, <em>pl. 17-32.</em>
	(<em>3</em>): 1836 (Flora rd 14 Dec 1836), p. 301-478, <em>pl. 33-48</em>, [1-2, err.].
<em>2</em>(<em>1</em>): 1837 (t.p.; p. vi: 25 Dec 1836), p. [1]-156, [iii]-vi, <em>pl. 49-64.</em>
	(<em>2</em>): 1837, p. 157-316, <em>pl. 65-84.</em>
	(<em>3</em>): 1838 (t.p. 1837; Flora 28 Sep 1838), p. 317-500, <em>pl. 85-97.</em>
<em>3</em>(<em>1-3</em>): 1842 (p. 620: 25 Jun 1842), p. [1]-620, [1, err.], <em>pl. 98-144</em> (no orig. covers seen).

Meigen, Wilhelm (1826/7-x), German high school teacher and botanist at Wesel. (<em>W.
Meigen</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BM 3: 1280; BJI 1: 40, 2:114; Kew 3: 642; Rehder 5: 562;
Tucker 1: 477.

<em>Publ</em>.: Nov. 1898 (p. vi: Apr 1898; ÖbZ Nov 1898; Bot. Centralbl. Nov 1898; Nat. Nov. Nov

	1885-1886. Hierzu als wissenschaftliche Beilage: <em>Die Flora von Wesel</em> vom Professor Dr.
	Meigen".

Meijer, Frans Nicholaas (after 1908 Frank Nicholas Meyer) (1875-1918), Dutch bota-
nist, gardener and botanical explorer; with Hugo de Vries before 1900; travelled through
the United States and Mexico 1901-1904; at the Missouri Botanical Garden 1904-1905;
with USDA as plant collector at the initiative of David Fairchild in 1905-1908, 1909-1912,
1913-1915 and 1916-1918; naturalised U.S. citizen 1908; drowned (murdered?) in the
Yang-tsze-kiang. (<em>F. N. Meyer</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: A; for duplicates see IH.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 483; IH 2: 533; JW 3: 363, 4: 398, 5: 246-247,
MW p. 320.
Coats, A. M., Plant hunters 129, 137-139. 1969.
Eeden, F. van, De Levende Natuur 5: 231. 1901.
Harkness, B., Plants &amp; Gardens ser. 2. 23(3): 64-67. 1967(portr.).
Laren, A. J. van, Onze Tuinen 3(45): 706-707. 1909, 3(46): 721-723. 1909.
Uildriks, F. J. van, De aarde en haar volken 1929: 1-24, 41-96, 145-171 (general biography,
	descr. of travels, portr., b. 29 Nov 1875, d. 2 Jun 1918).
Smith, E. F., Science ser. 2. 48: 335-336. 1918.
Veendorp, Weekbl. Maatsch. Tuinb. Plantk. 12(12): 91. 1938.

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: Cornelis, H. W., Handschrift en karakter ed. 2, 1925, p. 40-41.

5796. <em>Chinese plant names</em>... New York, N. Y. (Chinese &amp; Japanese Publishing Company)
[1911]. (<em>Chin. pl. names</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1911, p. [i-vii], 1-40. <em>Copies</em>: MO, US.

Meinecke, Emilio Pepe Michael (1869-1957), California-born American botanist and
phytopathologist of German descent; Ph. D. Heidelberg 1893; until 1907 at Heidelberg,
Copenhagen and München; from 1907-1909 at La Plata, Argentina; U.S. Forest Service
pathologist in California 1910-1928; id. in National Park Service 1928-1939. (<em>E. Meinecke</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Some material at NY and CAS.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 471; BM 7: 821; Bossert p. 263; CSP 17: 138;
Herder p. 148; Hirsch p. 194; IH 2: 522; LS suppl. 18048-18059; NAF 7: 1078; Stevenson p.
1251; Tucker 1: 777.
Anon., Österr. bot. Z. 68: 292. 1919 (reported to have died), 69: 88. 1920 (still alive).
Ewan, J. et al., Leafl. W. Bot. 7(3): 94. 1953.
Rodgers, A. D., Bernard Eduard Fernow 123, 349, 534, 1951.
Wagener, W. W. et al., Phytopathology 47: 633-634. 1957 (portr., b. 26 Jul 1869, d. 10 Feb
	1957).

5797. <em>Forest tree diseases</em> common in California and Nevada. A manual for field use ...
Washington (Government Printing Office) 1914. Oct. (<em>Forest tree diseases</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 14 Feb 1914, p. [1]-67, <em>pl. 1-24. Copies</em>: NY, USDA.

HEADING: MEINSHAUSEN

Meinecke, Johann Ludwig Georg (1721-1823), German physicist and biologist; high
school teacher at Halle 1805-1811; idem at Kassel 1811-1814; professor of technology at
Halle 1814-1823 (<em>Meinecke</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BM 3: 1280-1281; CSP 4: 324-325, 8: 373; Kew 3: 644; PR
6061-6062, (ed. 1: 6750-6751); Rehder 5: 562; SO 439f; TL-2/1: 2000.
Poggendorff, J. C., Biogr.-lit. Handw.-Buch 2: 103-104. 1858 (b. 3 Jan 1781, d. 27 Aug 1823
	by suicide).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: See TL-2/1: 2000, E. F. Germar, for Meinecke's <em>Lehrbuch der Mineralogie</em>.
Meinecke's Lehrbuch der Mineralogie, Halle 1808, counted for Germar as the first edition
of his Lehrbuch. (see also BM 3: 1280).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: The derivation of <em>Meineckia</em> Baillon (1858) is not given by Baillon.

5797a. <em>Über das Zahlenverhältniss in den Fructificalions-Organen der Pflanzen</em>, und Beyträge zur
Pflanzen-Physiologie ... Halle (J. C. Hendels Verlag) 1809, 2 Hefte. Oct. (<em>Zahlenverh. Fruct.-Org. Pfl.</em>).

<em>1</em>: 1809, p. [i-v], [1]-18.
<em>2</em>: 1809, p. [19]-50.
<em>Copy</em>: PH. – Published in Neue Schr. naturf. Ges. Halle 1(1,2). 1809.

Meins, Claus (1806-1873), German theologist and botanist; high school teacher at the
Glückstadt gymnasium 1848-1865; from 1865 clergyman at St. Margarethen. (<em>Meins</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 471 (b. 29 Sep 1806, d. 25 Dec 1873); PR 6063;
Rehder 1: 385; Tucker 1: 477.
Christiansen, W. &amp; W., Bot. Schrifttum Schlesw.-Holst. 317. 1936.
Fischer-Benzon, R.J. D. v., <em>in</em> Prahl, P., Krit. Fl. Schlesw.-Holst. 2: 36. 1890 (b. 29 Sep
	1806, d. 25 Dec 1873).

5798. Zu der öffentlichen Classenprüfung den 4.5.7.8. April, so wie zu der Entlassungsfeier
... 11 April Nachmittags 3 Uhr, ladet ... ein Prof. Dr. P. H. Jessen, Rector. Voran: <em>Die
Flora der Umgegend von Glückstadt</em> in Beziehung auf den Unterricht in der Botanik, vom
Collaborator Meins, Glückstadt (Gedruckt bei W. Augustin) 1862. Qu. (<em>Fl. Glückstadt</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Mar or early Apr 1862, p. [i], [1]-18 [<em>Flora</em>], 19-25 [Rector]. <em>Copies</em>: B-S, MO, NY.

Meinshausen, Karl [Friedrich] (1819-1899), Riga (Livonia)-born Baltic-
German/Russian botanist at St. Petersburg; travelling for the botanical garden 1839-1844,
curator of the garden herbarium until 1851; from 1851-1896 curator at the botanical
museum of the Academy of Sciences (<em>Meinsh</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: LE. His exsiccatae, <em>Herbarium florae Ingricae</em>, at CGE, H, LE,
MANCH, MW, OXF, W.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 4: 250; Barnhart 2: 471; BJI 2: 114; BM 3: 1281, 7: 821;
Clokie p. 209; CSP 4: 325, 8: 374, 17:139; DTS 1: xxi, 188, 6(4): 1705 Herder p. 465 [index];
IH 2: 522; Jackson p. 579 [index]; Kew 3: 644; Langman p. 496; Morren ed. 10, p. 95; MW
p. 315; PR 6064; Rehder 5: 562-563; TR 869-874; Tucker 1: 477; Zander ed. 10, p. 691, ed.
11 p. 788.
Anon., Bot. Centralbl. 81: 288. 1900 (d.); Bot. Not. 1900: 47 (d); Nat. 22: 176. 1900.
Beck, G. v., Bot. Centralbl. 34: 150. 1888 (876 specim. fl. ingr. at W).
Borodin, J., Trav. Mus. bot. Acad. Sci. St. Petersb. 4: 75-76. 1908.
Candolle, A. P. de, Phytographie 432. 1880 ("Meinhausen", pl. at LE).
Herder, F. v., Bot. Centralbl. 55: 258 (Herb. fl. ingr. at LE), 259, 261, 266 (All-Russian
	herb. also at LE), 296. 1893, 58: 386, 390. 1894; Bot. Jahrb. 9: 441. 1888.

HEADING: MEINSHAUSEN

Meisel, Max (1892-1969), American bibliographer and historian of natural history; B.Sc.
New York 1914, librarian at New York public library 1916-1917; at Battle Creek, Mich.
1917-1918, at Brooklyn 1918-? (<em>Meisel</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 472; BL 1: 159, 308; BM 7: 821.
Allen, E. G., Trans. Amer, philos. Soc. ser. 2. 41(3): 387-591. 1951 (Hist. Amer. ornithol.
	before Audubon; Max Meisel's copy (libr. FAS) has annotations made for a suppl. of his
	Bibl. Amer. nat. hist.).
Anon., Miami Herald 22 Jun 1969 (d. 21[?] Jun 1969) (inf. J. Ewan).

5802. <em>A bibliography of American natural history</em> the pioneer century, 1769-1865 the rôle played
by scientific societies, scientific journals, natural history museums and botanic gardens;
State Geological and natural history surveys, federal exploring expeditions in the rise and
progress of American botany, geology, mineralogy, paleontology and zoology ... New
York (The Premier Publishing Co. ....) 1924-1929, 3 vols. (<em>Bibl. Amer. nat. hist.</em>).

<em>1</em>: Nov 1924 (Copy sent to Barnhart by author on 18 Nov 1924; Torreya 19 Aug 1925), p.
	[l]-224.
<em>2</em>: 1926, p. [i]-xii, [1]-741.
<em>3</em>: 1929, p. [i]-xii, [1]-749.
<em>Copy</em>: FAS (Barnhart's copy).
<em>Facsimile ed</em>.: New York and London (Hafner Publishing Company) 1967, 3 vols. <em>Copy</em>: FAS.
	– See Taxon 16: 548. 1967.
The most important bibliographical treatment of American natural history 1769—1865.
Essential source for biographies, bibliographies, societies, expeditions, sources and dates.

PAGE: 405
HEADING: MEISNER

<em>Ref</em>.: Barnhart, J. H., Torreya 25: 83-85. 1925.

Meisner, Carl Friedrich (1800-1874), Swiss botanist; Dr. med. Goettingen 1824; at
Genève with A. P. de Candolle 1825-1828; professor of physiology Basel 1828-1836,
professor of botany 1836-1867. (<em>Meisn</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Meisner's herbarium was bought by John J. Crooke and presented
to Columbia University; it is now at NY. It contains part of his types, but since he worked
extensively with other material, Meisner types may be encountered also at e.g. B., BM,
DBN, G, K, LINN. Letters at G and U.
<em>Ref</em>.: Trimen, H., J Bot. 11: 32. 1873 (herb. purchased for Columbia College, New York).
	Anon., Bull. Torrey bot. Club 6: 128. 1876 (J. J. Crooke purchased the herbarium for
	Columbia); see also Torreya 27: 75-76. 1927.
	Barneby, R. C., Garden J. 13: 129-140, 142. 1963.

<sm>NOTE ON NAME</sm>. Meisner signed his earlier letters, at least until 13 Apr 1845 (letters to
Miquel at ULU), Meisner. In later years (at any rate after 1861) he signed Meissner, (see
TL ed. 1, sub no. 827; see also Nevling, Ann. Missouri Bot. Garden 46: 269-270. 1959 for a
different conclusion).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 21: 246-248; Barnhart 2: 472; BM 3: 1281; Bossert p.
263; CSP 4: 325-326; 6: 725, 8: 375, 10: 767-768, 12: 497; Frank 3(Anh.): 63; GR cat. p. 68;
Herder p. 465 [index]; Hortus 3: 1199 ("Meisn."); IH 1(ed. 6): 361, 2: 522-523; Jackson p.
116, 495; Kew 3: 644-645; Langman p. 496; Lasègue 526; Lenley p. 464; Maiwald p. 58,
113; MW p. 315; NAF ser. 2. 7: 42; PR 6065-6067 (ed. 1: 6753-6754); Rehder 5: 563; RS p.
18; SBC p. 127 ("Meisn."); TL-1/827; TL-2/1: 999, 1004, 1676, 2025, 4332; Tucker 1: 477;
Zander ed. 10, p. 691, ed. 11. p. 788.
Allan, M., The Hookers of Kew 213. 1967.
Anon., Bonplandia 3: 32. 1855 (Leopoldina, cogn. J. J. Römer), 5: 48. 1857 (elected
	Foreign Member Linn. Soc. London), 6: 48. 1858; Bot. Not. 1875 (15 Feb): 30. (d.); Bot.
	Zeit. 32: 672. 1874 (catalogue of his library); Bull. Soc. bot. France 21 (bibl.): 44. 1874; J.

(1968).

Mela, Aukusti Juhana (until 1876 August Johan Malmberg) (1846-1904), Finnish
zoologist and botanist; high school teacher in Helsinki; active promoter of Finnish culture
and language. (<em>Mela</em>).

HEADING: MELCHIOR

Melchior, Hans (1894-x), German botanist; student of Engler; 1917 assistant with G.
Haberlandt, Berlin; Dr. phil. Berlin 1920; at the Botanical Museum as Assistant 1920;
Oberassistent 1929; Kustos 1932-1955; from 1940 professor; Wissenschaftlicher Oberrat
1955; kommissarischer Leiter 1958-1959. (<em>Melch</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 363; Barnhart 2: 472 (b. 5 Aug 1894); BFM 2274,
2919; BJI 2: 114-115; Bossert p. 263; Hirsch p. 195; Hortus 3: 1199 ("Melchior"); IH 2: 523;
Kew 3: 646; Langman p. 497; MW p. 316, suppl. p. 225; Roon p. 76; TL-2/1: 1707, 1711;
Zander ed. 10, p. 691, ed. 11, p. 788; Zep.-Tim. p. 83-84.
Anon., Österr. bot. Z. 81: 320. 1932 (app. Kustos).
Becker, K. &amp; E. Schumacher, S. B. Ges. naturf. Fr. Berlin ser. 2. 13(2): 144. 1973.
Eckardt, Th., Willdenowia 4(2): 176. 1966.
Pilger, R., Mitt. bot. Gart. Mus. Berl.-Dahl. 1(1): 2, 15. 1953.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1)EP, <em>Die natürlichen Pflanzenfamilien</em>, ed. 2:
(a) <em>Medusagynaceae</em>(with A. Engler), 21: 50-52, <em>fig. 31</em>, Dec 1925.
(b) <em>Theaceae</em>, 21: 109-154, <em>fig. 59-67.</em> Dec 1925.
(c) <em>Violaceae</em>, 21: 109-154,) <em>fig. 148-162.</em> Dec 1925.
(d) <em>Canellaceae</em>, Nachtrag (with W. Schultze-Motel) 17a II: 221-224. Jan-Jul 1959.
(2) Engler, <em>Syllabus der Pflanzenfamilien</em>, ed. 12, 2 vols. 1954-1964 (with E. Werdermann), see
TL-2/1: 1707.
(3) Melchior, H. &amp; H. Kastner, <em>Gewürze</em>, Berlin und Hamburg 1974, 290 p., 'Grundlagen
und Fortschritte der Lebensmitteluntersuchung' vol. 2 (Taxon 24: 162. 1974).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Melchiora</em>Kobuski (1956). <em>Note</em>: <em>Melchioria</em>Penzig &amp; Saccardo (1897) is dedica-
ted to Melchior Treub (1851-1910), Dutch botanist (q.v.) Considering Kobuski's name a
later homonym, Verdcourt replaced it by the name <em>Balthasaria</em>Verdcourt (1969), stating:
"Since a new name is inevitable I have chosen one based on one of the other wise men." The
third companion of the party of the Magi was not forgotten by botanists, see <em>Casparea</em>and
<em>Caspareopsis</em>under Caspar Bauhin.

Melén, Eric Gustaf (1801-1828), Swedish physician and botanist; student of C. P.
Thunberg; Dr. med. Upsal. 1826; hospital physician at Kalmar 1826-1828 (<em>Melén</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Types, if any, in UPS (Thunberg herb.).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 172; BM 3: 1283; KR p. 499 (b. 6 Oct 1850, d.
12 Feb 1919); PR 6073 (ed. 1, 6762).

5814. <em>De Erythraeis svecanis</em>dissertatio botanico medica. Quam venia exp. Facult. med.
upsal. praeside C. P. Thunberg ... pro gradu medico conscripsit et publicae censurae offert
Ericus Gustavus Melén Calmariensis. In audit, botanico die [6] junii mdcccxxvi h.a. et
p.m.s. Upsaliae (excudebant Palmblad &amp; C.) Qu. (<em>Erylhr. svec</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 6 Jun 1826, p. [1]-8. <em>Copy</em>: FI.

Melhus, Irving E. (1881-1969), American phytopathologist and pteridologist; B. Sc.
Iowa State 1906, Ph. D. Madison 1912; plant pathologist in the Agricultural Experiment
Station and Botany Dept. of Iowa State University 1912-1946; director of the Iowa State
University Guatemala Tropical Research Center 1946-1953. (<em>Melhus</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Some material at F.

Melsheimer, Marcellus (1827-1920), German botanist and forester; studied at the
Eisenach forestry college 1852-1854; from 1856-1896 Oberförster at Linz a. Rhein; in
retirement ibid, until 1920. (<em>Melsheimer</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Some material at BHU.
