Melvill, James Cosmo (1845-1929), British businessman and naturalist at Manchester;
B. A. Cantab. 1868; D. Sc. Manchester 1908. (<em>Melvill</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: H WB (basis of his <em>Flora of Harrow</em>, 1864), MANCH (later material).
Dupl.: BM, CGE, HWB, K, MANCH, NY, OXF. Melvill presented the major part of his
herbarium, 42.000 species, to the Museum of Owens College, Manchester in 1904; this is
now at MANCH. The British plants, cryptogams and grasses were retained by him; they
are now at HWB (often in poor condition).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 474; BL 1: 173, 309, 2: 252, 257, 690; BM 3:
1284, 7: 828; Clokie p. 209; CSP 8: 378, 10: 771, 12:498, 17: 151; De Toni 1: lxxxii; IH 1(ed.
6): 361; 2: 525; Jackson p. 253; Kew 3: 649; KR p. 500; LS suppl. 18164; PH 98; PR 6076;
Rehder 5: 564; SO 2956, 3534; TL-2: see Hind, W. M.; Tucker 1: 478.
Anon., Manchester Museum Rep. 1929-30: 6-7. 1930.
Britten, J., J. Bot. 41: 415. 1903, 42: 391. 1904, 46: 272. 1908.

Hedge, I. C. &amp; J. M. Lamond, Index coll. Edinb. herb. 109. 1970 (pl. E).

Mendel, Gregor Johann (1822-1884), Czech geneticist, clergyman and teacher at Brno.

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: A. Peter's <em>Hieracia Naegeliana</em>(3 centuries and 1 supplementary

bibliography of Mendel on and the taxonomically relevant aspects of his work. For an
exhaustive bibliography see Jakubicek, M. &amp; J. Kubicek (1965); for sources and supporting

Meneghini, Giuseppe Giovanni Antonio (1811-1889), Italian algologist and palaeobo-
tanist; educated at University of Padua (M. D. 1834); assistant (1834-1839) and professor
of botany 1834-1838 at Padua; id. of Science faculty 1838-1849; professor of physical
geography and geology at Pisa 1849-1889. (<em>Menegh</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: PI (main herb.), FI (crypt.); some material also in the Kützing
herbarium at L and some other herbaria (see IH).

Menge, Franz Anton (1808-1880), German high school teacher, palaeontologist, arach-
nologist and botanist; studied at Bonn 1828-1832; high school teacher at Graudenz 1833-
1836, and at the Petrischule, Danzig 1836-1877; specialist on amber fossils. (<em>Menge</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Original collection at the Danziger Provinzialmuseum, now des-
troyed. Bryophytes at WRSL.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 5(1): 271; Andrews p. 302; Barnhart 2: 475 (b. 15 Feb
1808, d. 27 Jan 1880); BM 3: 1286-1287; CSP 4: 342, 8: 380, 10: 774; Herder p. 186; Kew 3:
654; PR 6084 (ed. 1: 6779); Quenstedt p. 289; Rehder 1: 380; SBC p. 127 ("Menge"); TL-
2/1: 2080.
Anon., Zool. Anz. 3: 120. 1880 (b. 10 Feb 1808, d. 27 Jan 1880).

Ohlert, B., Schrift. naturf. Ges. Danzig ser. 2. 5: xl-xlviii. 1881 (obit., b. 15 Feb 1808, d. 26
	Jan 1880).
Sayre, G., Bryologist 80: 513. 1977 (musci WRSL).

Menzel, Paul Julius (1864-1927), German palaeontologist; Dr. med. Greifswald 1889;
practicing physician at Heinitz-Grosspostritz, 1889-1898; id. at Dresden 1898-1914; id. in

Menzies, Archibald (1754-1842), British physician, gardener, botanist, zoologist and
plant collector; assistant-surgeon in the Royal Navy 1782; in N.W. America 1786-1789;
with Capt. Vancouver on the Voyage of the Discovery and Chatham 1791-1795. (<em>Menzies</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: E (main herbarium); some original collections, however, also at
BM, CGE, FH, K, LINN, NY, OXF and S. For details see IH. Various materials were
acquired by F.R.S. Balfour who passed on diplomas, charters and relics to the Provincial
Archives at Victoria, B. C., and certain papers to the Library of the State of Washington.
Correspondence with W. J. Hooker at K.

<sm>NAME</sm>: The "Z" in Scots is the equivalent of "Y" and should be so pronounced. See e.g.
Balfour (1944/5).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 1: 202; Backer p. 366; Barnhart 2: 476; BB p. 213; BM 3:
1288, 7: 826; Bossert p. 264; Clokie p. 209-210; CSP 4: 345; Dawson p. 46, 309, 425, 604-
607, 633; Desmond p. 434; DNB 37: 258; Dryander 2: 20, 466, 5: 82; Frank 3(Anh.): 63; GR
p. 377, cat. p. 68; Hortus 3: 1199 ("Menz."); HR; IH2: 527; Kew 3: 656; Lasègue p. 366-
368, 502, 324, 328, 337, 391; Lenley p. 285; PR (alph.); SBC p. 127 ("Menz."); SK 5: ccci-
cccii, 8: lxv; Urban-Berl. p. 307; Zander ed. 11, p. 788.

Mérat de Vaumartoise, François Victor (1780-1851), French botanist and physician
at Paris; Dr. méd. Paris 1803; at the Charité hospital 1803-1813; editor of the Dictionnaire
des sciences médicales. (<em>Mérat</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Mérat's herbarium was sold to Alphonse Maille (1813-1865), whose
herbarium was split up and sold as <em>Reliquae Mailleanae</em> to various botanists and institutes.
Parts of the herbarium are now at BR, G, P and PC. P acquired also ca. 1500 Maille
specimens in 1866 and 1867. The Mérat herbarium of 8000 specimens acquired by P in
1850 was by Jean Mérat.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 5(1): 600; Backer p. 366; Barnhart 2: 476 (b. 16 Jul
1780); BM 3: 1288; Colmeiro 1: clxxxliii; CSP 4: 345-346, 12: 501; Frank 3(Anh.): 63; GR
p. 288, cat. p. 68; Hawksworth p. 184, 196; Herder p. 88, 175, 409; Hortus 3: 1199
("Mérat"); IF p. 718; IH 2: 527-528; Jackson p. 14; Kelly p. 148, 255; Langman p. 501;
Lasègue p. 219, 540; LS 17714-17715; PR 6095-6099 (ed. 1: 6793-6801); Rehder 5: 566;
SBC p. 127 ("Mér."); SO add. 802b-d; Stevenson p. 1251; TL-1/258, 437, <em>828-829</em>; TL-
2/1239; Tucker 1: 479.
Anon., Bull. Soc. bot. Fr. sess. extr. 1876, p. 196.

	(copy: G).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Mérat's grandfather, Laurent Germain Mérat (1712-1790), a pharmacist at Auxerre
(from 1740), was also a diligent botanist, even though he left no published papers. His
grandson François Victor, owned four manuscripts of his grandfather of which one, an
<em>Histoire des plantes qui croissent dans le comté d'Auxerre</em> (1778) is now at NY.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Meratia</em> Loiseleur-Deslongchamps (1818, <em>no</em>m. rej.); <em>Meratia</em> Cassini (1824);
<em>Meratia</em> Alph. de Candolle (1846).

Mercier, Marie Philippe (1781-1831), French botanist, born on Martinique; soldier,
police officer, salesman, refugee in Genève 1822-1831 working with A. P. de Candolle. (<em>P.
Mercier</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: FI; duplicates at E, G, P, S.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 477; IH 1(ed. 6): 361, 2: 528; Lasègue p. 317;
Lenley p. 464; PR (alph.); Rehder 5: 566.
Briquet, J., Bull. Soc. bot. Suisse 50a: 316-317. 1940 (biogr., bibl., epon., d. 30 Oct 1831),
	q.v. for botanical manuscripts by M.
Candolle, Alph. de, Phytographie 433. 1880 (herb, bought by Webb).
Candolle, A. P. de, Hist. bot. Genev. 60. 1830, Mém. souv. 331, 333. 1862.
Pritzel, G. A., Linnaea 19: 457. 1846 (d. 30 Oct 1831).
Steinberg, C., Webbia 32(1): 6, 8, 31. 1977 (herb, at FI).

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: Webbia 32(1): 6. 1977.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Mercier prepared a quarto publication <em>Choix de plantes exotiques rares ou nouvelles</em> for
publication. According to Seringe the manuscript was nearly ready by Mai 1830. The
book, however, remained unpublished and Mercier died on 30 Oct 1831. The only part of
the text published was a short article with the same title in the Bulletin botanique (Seringe)
1(6); 167-170. Jun 1830. Seringe, in a footnote on p. 167, announces the quarto volume
which was still awaiting the plates by Heyland.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Merciera</em> Alph. de Candolle (1830) is dedicated to Marie Philippe Mercier (1781-
1831), French traveller and collector born in Martinique who lived in Geneva from 1822
until his death, friend of Seringe and the de Candolles.

Mercklin, Carl Eugen [Eugeniewitsch] von (1821-1904), Livonian (Baltic-German)
botanist and paleontologist; studied at Dorpat and Jena, Dr. phil. Jena 1846; from 1848-
1855 plant physiologist at St. Petersburg; professor of forestry botany at St. Petersburg
1847-1865; professor of botany at the medical academy of St. Petersburg 1867. (<em>Merckl</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: LE; some further material at MW.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Andrews p. 302-303; Barnhart 2: 477; BM 3: 1289; CSP 4:
347, 8: 382, 10: 780, 17: 169; Herder p. 465 [index]; IH 2: 528; Jackson p. 70, 188, 494; Kew
3: 656-657; LS 17718-17721; Morren ed. 10, p. 95; PR 6100-6102 (ed. 1: 6802); Quenstedt
p. 290; Ratzeburg p. 351-352; Rehder 5: 566; TR 875-881; Tucker 1: 480.
Anon., Acta Horti bot. Univ. Jurjev. 5: 272. 1904, 6: 54-59. 1906 (b. 7/19 Apr 1828, d. 26
	Nov/9 Dec 1904): Annuaire géol. mineral. Russie 7: 248. 1904 (bibl.); Bot. Jahrb.
	37(Beibl. 84): 3. 1906 (d.); Hedwigia 44 (Beibl. 3): 137. 1905 (d.); Verh. russ. mineralog.
	Ges. 42, Protokolle 67-69. 1905 (for 1904).

Meredith, Louisa Anne, née Twamley (1812-1895), British botanical artist, bush
naturalist, writer and poetess; settled in Australia 1839 (mainly N.S.W. and Tasmania)
(<em>Meredith</em>).

Merlet de la Boulaye, Gabriel-Eléonor (1736-1807), French botanist at Angers;
director of the Angers botanical garden. (<em>Merlet</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 478 (b. 3 Apr 1736, d. 17 Feb 1807); BM 3:
1291; GR p. 340; PR 6106 (ed. 1: 6807); Rehder 1: 407; Tucker 1: 480.
Candolle, A. P. de, Mém. souv. 172. 1862.
Dawson, W. R., Smith papers 69. 1934.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: The etymology of <em>Merleta</em> Refinesque (1840) is not given by Rafinesque.

5849. <em>Herborisations, dans le département de Maine et Loire</em>, et aux environs de Thouars, départ.
des Deux-Sêvres, par feu M. Merlet de la Boulaye, ... publiées par plusieurs de ses élèves, et
augmentées de notices sur le site, la nature du terrain, les minéraux et les antiquités. Angers
(Chez Fourier-Mame, ...) 1809. Duod. (in sixes). (<em>Herboris. Maine et Loire</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1889, p. [i]-vi, [(7)]-(12), [1]-226, [1-2, err.]. <em>Copies</em>: G, NY. – Contains on p. 7-12 a
	biographical notice of M by Em. D. d.l. R. (Davy de la Roche).

PAGE: 425
HEADING: MERRILL, E. D.

Merrem, Blasius (1761-1824), German botanist, mathematician and physicist; lecturer
at Göttingen 1781-1784; professor of physics and political economy at Duisburg 1784-1804;
from 1804-1821, professor of political economy and botany at Marburg. (<em>Merrem</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 367; Barnhart 2: 478 (b. 4 Feb 1761 d. 23 Feb
1824); BM 3: 1291; CSP 4: 351; Jackson p. 429; LS 17725; PR 6107-6109 (ed. 1: 6809-
6811); Rehder 5: 567; SO 609, 610, 612.
Poggendorff, J. C., Biogr.-lit. Handw.-Buch 2: 125. 1863 (b. 4 Feb 1761, d. 23 Feb 1824).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Merremia</em> Dennstedt ex Endlicher (1941, <em>nom. cons.</em>).

5850. <em>Handbuch der Pflanzenkunde</em> nach dem Linneischen System ... Marburg (in der neuen
academischen Buchhandlung) 1809. Oct. 2 vols (<em>Handb. Pflanzenk.</em>).

<em>1</em>: 1809, p. [i]-xii, [1]-140.
<em>2</em>: 1809, p. [i-ii], [1]-618.

5851. Des Ritters Carl von Linné's <em>vollständiges Pflanzensystem</em> neu bearbeitet und mit den
neueren Fortschritten dieser Wissenschaft bereichert. Zum zweckmässigen Gebrauch für
Apotheker, künftige Landwirthe, Thierärzte, Gärtner, gebildete Frauenzimmer und alle
Liebhaber der Pflanzenkunde die keine Gelehrte sind ... Marburg (In der neuen academi-
schen Buchhandlung) 1811, 2 vols. Oct. (<em>Vollst. Pfl.-Syst.</em>).

<em>Ed. 1</em>: 2 vols. 1811. <em>Copy</em>: MO.

	<em>2</em>: [i], 215-618.
<em>Ed. 2</em>: 2 vols. 1823, n.v.

Merriam, Clinton Hart (1855-1942), American botanist, zoologist and ethnologist; M.
D Columbia 1879; practicing physician in Locust Grove 1879-1885; ornithologist in the
office of the"Commissioner of agriculture" (now USDA) and leader of the Bureau of
Biological Survey 1885-1910; working with the support of the Harnman Trust (Smithso-
nian Institution) from 1910; outstanding mammalogist and zoogeographer (<em>Merriam</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: US.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 478 (b. 5 Dec 1855, d. 1942); BL 1: 132, 168,
309; BM 3: 1291; Hortus 3: 1199 (Merriam); IH 2: 529; Lenley p. 285; Zander ed. 10, p.
691, ed. 11, p. 781.
Anon., Entom. News 53: 150. 1942 (d.); Science 95: 318. 1942.
Cantelow, E. D. &amp; H. C., Leafl. W. Bot. 8: 95. 1957 (d. 19 Mar 1942).
Daubenmire, R. F., Quart. Rev. Biol. 13: 327-332. 1938. (Merriam's life zones of North
	America).
Ewan, J., Rocky Mt. natural. 266. 1950.
Ewan, J. et al., Short hist. bot. U. S. 117. 1969.
Grinnell, H. W., J. Mammalogy 24(4): 436-437. 1943 (bibl.).
Howell, J. T., Leafl. W. Bot. 7(3): 94. 1953.
Hultén, E., Bot. Not. 1940: 308. (Alaskan coll. US).
Jaeger, E. C., Source book biol. names terms ed. 3. 317. 1966.
Osgood, W. H., J. Mammalogy 24: 421-436. 1943, Natl. Acad. Sci., Biogr. Mem. 24: 1-57.
	1947 (main biogr., bibl., portr., b. 5 Dec 1855, d. 19 Mar 1942).

<em>Publ</em>.: Aug 1890 (Bot. Centralbl. 10 Dec 1890), p. [i]-vii, frontisp., 1-136, <em>pl. 1-13</em>, map 1-5
	with text. Published and to be cited as North American fauna 3, 1890.
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Bull. Torrey bot. Club 17: 298. 9 Nov 1890.

Merrill, Elmer Drew (1876-1956), American botanist; in the Philippines 1902-1924; at

PAGE: 426
HEADING: MERRILL, E. D.

Berkeley 1924-1930; director of the New York Botanical Garden 1930-1935 succeeding N.
L. Britton; at Harvard 1935-1948 (retirement as Arnold Professor); active until 1954;
outstanding plant systematist ("get-the-job-done"). (<em>Merr</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: A, FH, NY, PNH, UC. For further details see IH and SK. Merrill's
library, medals, diplomas, and many of his manuscripts are at NY. <em>Correspondence</em> at HH and
NY; 52 letters to Brotherus at H-UB; other correspondence in many herbaria (e.g. G, K,
PH) and in IAPT nomenclature files.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 194, 367; Barnhart 2: 479; BJI 1: 115; BL 1: 103,
104, 117, 118, 122, 123, 124, 129, 131, 308; BM 3: 1291-1292, 7: 828; Bossert p. 264; CSP 17:
177; DSB 15: 421-422 (J. Ewan); Hirsch p. 196; Hortus 3: 1199 ("Merrill"); Hawksworth p.
184; IF p. 718, suppl. 3: 215, 4: 331; IH 1 (ed. 6): 361, 2: 529; Kelly p. 148; Kew 3: 658-661;
Langman p. 501; Lenley p. 286-289; LS suppl. 18267-18268; MW p. 316-318, suppl. p. 225-
226; NW p. 53; Pennell p. 614; PH p. 500 [index]; Plesch p. 334; RS p. 118; SBC p. 127; SK
1: cxxiv, lxv, 355-356, 4: cxii, 5: cccii, 6(6): 6-16; SO 3527; TL-2/329, 2500, 3500-3501,
4166-4167; Tucker 1: 480-481; Urban-Berl. p. 279, 374; Zander ed. 10, p. 691, ed. 11, p.
788.
Anon., Bot. Centralbl. 80: 240. 1899 (assistant Division of Agrostology [with Lamson-
	Scribner] Washington); Notices in N. Y. Times and N. Y. Herald Tribune of 26 Feb
	1956; Taxon 1: 36. 1952 (portr.); The Times 1 Mar 1956.

Cormack, M., Taxon 1: 123. 1952 (poem to Merrill).

Ewan, J., Rocky Mt. nat. 266-267. 1950; J. Washington Acad. Sci. 46(8): 267-268. 1956
	(obit., "... for his time probably the most widely known botanist in the world").
Ewan, J. et al., 18, 19, 22, 100, 123. 1969.
Gager, C. S., Brooklyn Bot. Gard. Record 27(3): 353, 370. 1938 (Merrill was director of the
	California Botanic Garden 1927-1929; owing to the depression this garden was abando-
	ned in 1930. The herbarium of the garden went to UCLA; Merrill was Director of the
	Arnold Arboretum from 1937;"supervisor" in 1936).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) See Frank Lamson-Scribner, <em>Chaetochloa</em> and <em>Stud. Amer. grasses</em> (TL-
2/4166-4167); for further publications with this author see Schwarten (1946).
(2) Co-editor <em>The Philippine Journal of Science</em> 1906-1923.
(3) With L. Diels and T. F. Chipp, <em>International address book of botanists</em>, 1931, xv, 605 p.
(4) Founder of <em>Brittonia</em> (vol. 1(1) Feb 1931), in honor of Nathaniel Lord Britton.

HEADING: MERRILL, G. K.

Merrill, George Knox (1864-1927), American lichenologist, journalist and photogra-
pher; active at Rockland, Maine were he kept an art studio. (<em>G. Merr.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: FH (50.000). Exsiccatae: <em>Lichenes exsiccati</em>, fasc. 1-11, nos. 1-275
(1909-1913), ser. 2, fasc. 1-6, nos. 1-150, (1925-1927); for sets see IH, for dates etc. see Sayre
and Stevenson.

Mertens, Franz Karl (Carl) (1764-1831), German botanist, director of a business school

Mertens, Karl (Carl) Heinrich (1796-1830), German botanist at St. Petersburg; son of
F. K. Mertens. (<em>K. Mert.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: LE, incl. material collected on the voyage around the world on the
Corvette Seniavin under Capt. Friedrich Lütke (1826-1829). See Clokie and SK for details.
A large collection of letters received by M. is at HU.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 1: 188; Backer p. 367; BM 3: 1292; Bret. p. 322; Clokie

Mettenius, Georg Heinrich (1823-1866), German pteridologist; professor of botany and

PAGE: 433
HEADING: METTENIUS

director of the Leipzig botanical garden from 1851-1866; succeeding Gustav Kunze;
married Cecilie Braun, daughter of Alexander Braun; died of cholera. (<em>Mett</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: The Mettenius herbarium, exclusive of the ferns, was at LZ and is
now destroyed. The fern herbarium, acquired by Berlin (B) between 1870 and 1875, was
incorporated in the general herbarium (extant). An important set of ferns (448) is at W;
further material at E and FR.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 21: 523-524; AG 2(2): 9; Backer p. 368; Barnhart 2:
481; BM 3: 1293; Bossert p. 265; CSP 4: 355, 8: 388; De Toni 1: lxxxiv; DSB 9: 340; DTS
6(4): 170; Frank 3(Anh.): 64; Hegi p. 466; Hortus 3: 1199 ("Mett."); IF p. 718-719; IH 1
(ed. 6): 361, 2: 531; Jackson p. 149, 150, 152, 224, 428; Kew 3: 668; Moebius p. 135, 136,
204; NI 1346; PR 6115-6123 (ed. 1: 6822-6823); Rehder 5: 568; Tl-1/830-832; TL-2/1:
1764, 3507, 3984; Tucker 1: 481; Urban-Berl. p. 36-37, 321; Zander ed. 10, p. 691, ed. 11, p.
788.
Anon., Bot. Zeit. 25: 80, 88. 1867 (library and herbarium for sale); Bull. Soc. bot. France
	13(c.r.): 400. 1866, 13(bibl.): 236-327. 1866, 14(bibl): 47. 1867 (sale herb., libr.);
	Hedwigia 5: 144. 1866; Flora 50: 13. 1867; J. Bot. 4: 336. 1866; Österr. bot. W. 1: 85, 1851
	(prof. bot. Freiburg, succeeding A. Braun), 2: 172. 1852 (called to Leipzig), 6: 406. 1856
	(Filic. Hort. bot. Lips.), 14: 26. 1864 (in charge of LZ herbarium), 16: 232. 1866 (d. 19
	Aug 1866, of cholera).
Beck, G., Bot. Centralbl. 34: 150. 1888 (448 ferns at W).
Blum, J., Ber. Senckenb. naturf. Ges. Wiss. Abh. 1901: 19-20.

	in-law); <em>in</em> Seemann, B., J. Bot. 4: 388-390. 1866 (from Gard. Chron. 1866: 1018).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1)<em>Cryptogamae vasculares</em>, in Fenzl, <em>Reise Novara</em>, see TL-2/1: 1764.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Cecilie Mettenius (née Braun, b. 17 Feb 1836) published a biography of her father
Alexander Braun (Berlin 1882, viii, 706 p.) which is an important source for the history of
German botany in the middle of the nineteenth century.

	G, MO, NY, US. – Preprinted with special t.p. from Abh. kön. sächs. Ges. Wiss., math.-
	phys. Cl. 7: 403-505, <em>pl. 1-5.</em> 1864.

Metzger, Johann (1789-1852), German botanist and gardener at Heidelberg; from 1851
director of the agricultural garden and college at Karlsruhe. (<em>Metzg</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Some <em>Cerealia</em> at W.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm>ans <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2(1): 682; Barnhart 2: 481; BM 3: 1294; Frank 3(Anh.):

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Metzgeria</em> Raddi (1818) is dedicated to Giovanni Metzger, a copper engraver
and restorer of old paintings, of Stauffen im Breisgau, a pupil of Raffaello Morghen. The
same etymology holds for: <em>Metzgeriites</em> Steere (1947); <em>Metsgeriopsis</em> Goebel (1888); <em>Austro-
metzgeria</em> Kuwahara (1966); <em>Apometzgeria</em> Kuwahara (1966).

von C. F. Winter) 1824. Fol. (<em>Eur. Cereal.</em>).

here. He should not be confused with the Thüringian F. F. Meurer (1809-1882), treated

Meusel, Hermann (1909-x), German botanist at Halle; Dr. phil. Halle 1935 (student of
W. Troll); assistant Bot. Inst. Halle 1935-1947; professor of botany ib. 1947 (ord. 1952);
Nationalpreis DDR 1966; specially interested in the chorology of the eurasiatic flora.
(<em>Meusel</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: HAL.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: For Meusel, H., Jäger, E. und Weinert, E., <em>Vergleichende Chorologie der zentraleuropäi-
schen Flora</em>, erster Teil, Jena 1965, see e.g. Markgraf, F., Bot. Jahrb. 87(Lit.): 4-5. 1967.
Volume 2 was published 1978, see G. Wagenitz, Taxon 28: 657. 1979. The book continues
his <em>Vergleichende Arealkunde</em>, 2 vols., Berlin 1943 (see e.g. L. Diels, Bot. Jahrb. 74(Lit.): 9-10.
1949).

Mexia, Ynes Enriquetta Julietta (1870-1938), American botanical explorer (of Mexi-
can descent) of Alaska and Latin America. (<em>Mexia</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: UC. – Duplicates of collections widely distributed; see IH (total
number of specimens collected about 150.000; ca. 9300 species). Records of the collections,
letters and information about the Mexia family are in the Bancroft Library, Univ. Calif.,
Berkeley.

Meyen, Franz Julius Ferdinand (1804-1840), Prussian physician and botanist; Dr.
med. Berlin 1826; travelled around the world with W. Wendt on the Prinzess Luise (1830-
1832); Dr. phil. h.c. Bonn 1834; professor of botany at the University of Berlin. (<em>Meyen</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Meyen's herbarium, mainly consisting of the authentic material of
his trip around the world, was acquired by B in 1842. The herbarium consisted of 2188
specimens, said by Urban to represent 1353 species. This herbarium now being lost, the
most important extant sets of Meyen specimens seem to be at BR, CAS, CGE, K and L; the
important set at KIEL is also lost. Some bryophytes are at BM.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: "Zijn arbeid is, ook onder ons, op hoogen prys gesteld. Zijne werkzaamheid en echt
Duitsche vlijt grensden schier aan het onmogelijke en ongeloofelijke. Zijn aanzijn was een
merkwaardig verschijnsel, een voorbeeld ter navolging en ter waarschuwing" (De Vriese).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 21: 549-553; AG 2(2): 309; Ainsworth p. 314, 345;
Backer p. 368; Barnhart 2: 482; BM 3: 1297, 7: 833; Bossert p. 265; Bret. p. 302; Cesati p.
266; CSP 4: 357-359, 8: 391; De Toni 1: lxxxiv; DSB 9: 344-345 (by H. Querner); Frank
3(Anh.): 64; GR p. 31-32, cat. p. 68; Hawksworth p. 184; Herder p. 466; Hortus 3: 1199
("Meyen"); IF p. 719; IH 2: 532; Jackson p. 68, 69, 102, 193, 222, 224, 503; Kew 3: 669-
670; KR p. 502; Langman p. 502; Lasègue p. 384, 502, 521; LS 17758-17765; Moebius p.
453 [index]; MW p. 319; NI 1352-1353; Nordstedt p. 23; PR 6132-6143 (ed. 1: 6834-6849);
Ratzeburg p. 352-356; Rehder p. 568-569; RS p. 118; SBC p. 127 ("Meyen"); SK 1: 358;
Stevenson p. 1250; TL-1/833; Tl-2/1: see Grisebach, A. H. R.; Tucker 1: 482; Urban-Berl.
p. 267, 271, 279, 289, 308, 374; Zander ed. 10, p. 692, ed. 11, p. 789 (b. 28 Jun 1804, d. 2 Sep
1840).
Anon., Bot. Not. 1840: 211. (d. 1 Sep 1836); Flora 23: 544. 1840 (d. 1/2 Sep 1840).
Embacher, F., Lexik. Reisen 206. 1882.
Ewan, J. et al., Short hist. bot. U.S. 116. 1969.
Forbes, R. J., ed., Martinus van Marum 1: 330. 1969, 3: 32. 1971.

	"Meyen's Nachlass"), 8 Mai 1943 (vol. 19 suppl. 1 of Nova Acta not yet out), 23 Mar

Poggendorff, J. C., Biogr.-lit. Handw.-Buch 2: 133. 1858, 3: 907. 1898 (b. 28 Jun 1804, d. 2
	Sep 1840).
Ratzeburg, J. T. C., Nova Acta Acad. Leop. 19: xii-xxxii. 1843 (bibl.), also in Meyen, J. F.
	J., Reise um die Erde 4: xiii-xxxii. 1843 (biogr., d. 1/2 Sep 1840; bibl.).

Whetzel, H. H., Hist. phytopath. 38. 1918 (portr.).
Wood, R. D., Monogr. Charac. 1: 826. 1965.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Meyen was a Baltic German; he was born in Tilsit, Eastern Prussia (now Sovetsk,
USSR) and educated in Tilsit, Memel and Berlin. After practicing as physician in the
Charité hospital of Berlin 1826/27, he served as military physician in Köln, Bonn, Potsdam
and Berlin before going on the voyage around the world on the <em>Prinzessin Luise</em> as ship's
physician. A good contemporary account is given by Ratzeburg (1843).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Meyenia</em> C. G. D. Nees (1832); <em>Meyenia</em> Backeberg (1931). <em>Note</em>: <em>Meyenites</em> Unger
(1842) and <em>Meyenia</em> Schlechtendal (1833), probably also commemorate Meyen but the
authors give no derivation.

5894. <em>Grundriss der Pflanzengeographie</em> mit ausführlichen Untersuchungen über das Vater-
land, den Anbau und den Nutzen der vorzüglichsten Culturpflanzen, welche den Wohl-
stand der Völker begründen ... Berlin (Maude und Spenersche Buchhandlung (S. J.
Joseephy)). 1836. Oct. (<em>Grundr. Pfl.-Geogr.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1836, p. [i]-x, [1]-478. <em>Copy</em>: MO.
<em>English</em>: 1846, p. [i]-x, [1]-422. <em>Copies</em>: MO, US. – "<em>Outlines of the geography of plants</em>: with
	particular enquiries concerning the native country, the culture, and the uses of the
	principal cultivated plants on which the prosperity of nations is based ..." translated by
	Margaret Johnston. London (printed for the Ray Society) 1846. Oct.
<em>Swedish</em>: 1841, viii, 308 and 127 p., n.v., see KR (p. 702) "<em>Utkast till växt-geografien</em>...",
	translation by Gustaf Torssell (1811-1849).

5895. F. J. F. Meyenii <em>Observationes botanicas</em> in itinere circum terram institutas. Opus
posthumum, sociorum Academiae curis suppletum. Cum tabulis xiii. Vratislaviae et
Bonnae [Breslau and Bonn] 1843. Qu. (<em>Observ. bot.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Nov Acta Leopoldina 17, suppl. 2 (is at the same time vol. 19, suppl. 1); counts as
	Theil 4 of <em>Reise um die Erde</em> (see e.g. BM 3: 1297). <em>Date</em>: Dec 1843 (forwarded from Breslau
	to Nees on 13 Dec 1843 (PAW); Nees sent a copy to Miquel on 23 Mar 1844 with excuses
	for the delay), p. [xiii]-xxxii (Meyen's Lebenslauf, by J. T. C. Ratzeburg), p. [ix]-xxxii,
	[1]-512, <em>pl. 1-13</em> (partly col. and uncol. liths.). <em>Copies</em>: FI, NY, U, USDA; IDC 6064/5227.
	– German title: <em>Beiträge zur Botanik</em> gesammelt auf einer Reise um die Erde ..."
<em>Collaborators</em>: Julius Christian Gottlieb Ulrich Flotow (1788-1856), lichenes (with Meyen);
	Ignaz Goldmann (1810-1848), filices; Carl Moritz Gottsche (1808-1892), Carl Johann
	Lindeberg (1815-1900) and Nees von Esenbeck, Hepaticae; August Heinrich Rudolph
	Grisebach (1814-1879), Gentianaceae; Johann Friedrich Klotzsch (1805-1860) fungi;
	Christian Gottfried Daniel Nees von Esenbeck (1776-1858); Johann Conrad Schauer
	(1813-1848), Apocynaceae, Asclepiadaceae; Wilhelm Gerhard Walpers (1816-1853),
	Compositae, e.a.; Julius Rudolph Theodor Vogel (1812-1841), Leguminosae.
<em>Additional</em> botanical information was contained in footnotes of parts 1 and 2 of Meyen's <em>Reise
um die Erde</em>, Berlin 1834, 1835 (Theil 1: 25-31 Mai 1834, Theil 2: 18-23 Aug 1834). Theil 3
contained zoology. Theil 4 is the above botanical treatment.
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Bot. Zeit. 2: 793. 1844.

PAGE: 440
HEADING: MEYER, A.

Meyer, Albert (<em>fl</em>. 1884), German botanist from Müllrose; Dr. phil. Marburg 1884. (<em>Alb.

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

(Universitäts-Buchdruckerei (R. Friedrich)). 1884. Oct. (<em>Beitr. Anat. Ranunc.</em>).

Meyer, Bernhard (1767-1836), German botanist and ornithologist in the Wetterau;
1791-1796 practicing physician at Hanau; from 1796 pharmacist and dentist at Offenbach.
(<em>B. Mey.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: FR (donated 1826); further material at JE.

Meyer, Carl Anton von [Karl Anton; Carl Andreevic] (1795-1855), Russian botanist

Meyer, Ernst Heinrich Friedrich (1791-1858), Prussian botanist; Dr. med. Göttingen
1819; lecturer Göttingen 1819-1826; from 1826 professor of botany and director of the
botanical garden in Königsberg; Dr. phil.h.c. Königsberg 1829. (<em>E. Mey.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Meyer was for the greater part of his career a professor at Königs-
berg (now Kaliningrad). The herbarium (19.000 species plus the Ehrhart exsiccata) was
offered for sale in 1859. It was bought by the Gesellschaft zur Beförderung gemeinnütziger
Tätigkeit at Lübeck in 1875. In 1915 the herbarium (24000 specimens) was transferred to
Berlin (B); most of it is now destroyed. For the disposal of Meyer's library see Verdoorn
(1965), p. 13-15. – The "Sammlung deutscher Flechten", announced by Flora (5: 253-256)
was never issued.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 21: 565-569; AG 4: 224; Backer p. 369; Barnhart 2:
483; BFM 1624; BL 1: 137, 308; BM 3: 1300-1301; CSP 4: 361-362, 8: 392, 10: 791, 17: 202;
Frank 3(Anh.): 64; GR p. 111; Herder p. 466 [index], Hortus 3: 1199 ("Mey., E. H."); IH
2: 533; Jackson p. 3, 21, 134, 346, 428; Kew 3: 671; Langman p. 503; Lasègue p. 183; LS
17777-17779; Moebius p. 3, 9, 13, 35, 153, 213, 304; MW p. 320; PH 59, 939; PR 6146-6165
(ed. 1: 6857-6873); Rehder 5: 569; RS p. 118-119; TL-1/834-835, 956, 1012; TL-2/1082,
1518, 4285, 4332; Tucker 1: 482; Urban-Berl. p. 375; Zander ed. 10, p. 691, ed. 11, p. 788.
Anon., Bonplandia 3: 32. 1855 (Leopoldina cogn. Hill), 6: 18. 1858 (ann. Alb. Magni de
	Veget....), 241-242. 1858 (rev. <em>Gesch. Bot.</em>), 362. 1858 (b. 1 Jan 1791, d. 7 Aug 1858), 9:
	38. 1861 (Jessen will continue <em>Gesch. Bot.</em>); Bot. Zeit. 16: 256. 1858, 17: 224, 296, 303.
	1859 (sale herb. &amp; libr.), 33: 583. 1875 (herb. bought); Bull. Soc. bot. France 5: 311, 672.
	1859, 6: 384. 1859 (sale herb., libr.), 7: 542-543. 1861; Flora 9: 319. 1826 (to Königsberg)
	41: 593. 1858; Österr. bot. Z. 8: 342. 1858 (d. 7 Aug 1858; heart disease).
Bullock, A. A., Bibl. S. Afr. bot 76. 1978.
Bratanek, F. T., Goethe's naturwissenschaftliche Correspondenz (1812-1832)1: 373-388.
	1874 (Goethe-Meyer correspondence; see also Verdoorn 1965, p. 58, 60; see also Goethe
	Jahrb. 5: 134-176. 1884.
Candolle, A. P. de, Phytographie 439. 1880 (types <em>Fl. Prov. Preussen</em> in Königsberg).
Fritsch, C., ed., in R. Caspary, Lebensbeschreibungen ost- und westpreussischer Botaniker.
	1912, p. 248-249 (portr., bibl.).
Glass, B. et al., Forerunners of Darwin 327. 1968.
Helm, J., Kulturpflanze 14: 352. 1966.
Jackson, B. D., Bull. misc. Inf. Kew 1901: 45 (pl. K).

HEADING: MEYER, E. H. F.

Jessen, K. F. W, Bot. Gegenw. Vorz. 485 [many refs.!] 1884 (for Jessen &amp; Meyer see
	Verdoorn, 1965, p. 56-57).
Lehnerdt, <em>in</em> Krollmann, Altpreussische Biographie 1: 434. 1942 (n.v.).

	Oct. (n.v.; cited by Meyer (1857), p. 214; important for Meyer's religious activities and

Wunschmann, E., Allg. deut. Biogr. 21: 565-569. 1885.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1)see Lehmann, J. G. C., <em>Plantae Preissianae</em>, TL-2/4332. (<em>Junceae</em>).
(2) see Drège, J. F., <em>Zswei Pflanzengeogr. Dokum.</em>, TL-2/1518; p. 17-230 issued 14 Aug-28 Dec
1843.
(3) see Ledebour, C. F. v., <em>Fl. ross.</em>, vol. 4, 1853, <em>Juncaceae</em>, TL-2/4285.
(4) see Patze, C. et al., <em>Fl. Prov. Preussen</em> [1848-]1850 (family and genera descriptions by
Meyer).
(5) see Brown, R., <em>Vermischte botanische Schriften</em> TL-2/ 833); Jessen took part in the
translation and added anotations. See Verdoorn (1965), p. 45 for background.
(6) see Pritzel, <em>Thesaurus</em>, ed. 2. – Jessen published fasc. 5-7 in 1877 from Pritzel's manus-
cript.
(7) see Pritzel and Jessen, <em>Die deutschen Volksnamen der Pflanzen</em>. Hannover. 1882-1884.
(8) Goethe, W., <em>Versuch iiber die Metamorphose der Pflanzen</em>, ed. 1831, edited by Fréd. Soret; several contributions by Meyer, see G. Schmid 1940 (no. 146).
(9) Pritzel, G. A., <em>Thesaurus</em>, ed. 1, 1851, is dedicated to seven colleagues who assisted
Pritzel; among them was E. H. F. Meyer.
(10) see Presl, C. B., <em>Reliquiae haenkeanae</em>, vol. 1, 1825 (<em>Junceae</em>).
(11) Numerous reviews signed E. M. in GGA 1819-1827, in Flora and in Bot. Zeit.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Ernestia</em> A. P. de Candolle (1828); <em>Ernestimeyera</em> O. Kuntze (1903); <em>Meyeria</em> A. P.
de Candolle (1836, collectively dedicated to Ernst Meyer and four of his namesakes: 1.
Johann Meyer, whose identity we could not establish; <em>Meyera</em> Schreber (1791) the etymolo-
gy of which is not given by Schreber, might commemorate him as well; 2. Friedrich
Albrecht Anton Meyer (1769-1795, German botanist and entomologist; 3. Georg Friedrich
Wilhelm Meyer (1782-1856), q.v.; 4. Carl Anton von Meyer (1795-1855), q.v.; <em>Pseudoernes</em>-
<em>tia</em> (Cogniaux) Krasser (1893). <em>Note</em>: <em>Meyerafra</em> O. Kuntze (1891) is dedicated to Hans
Heinrich Joseph Meyer (1858-?), German explorer and plant collector in Europe, Africa,
Asia and North and South America, who was the first European to ascend the Kilimanjaro.
<em>Meyerophytum</em> G. Schwantes (1927) is dedicated to G. Meyer, German missionary and
botanical explorer in Namibia, about whom we have no further details. The etymology of
<em>Meyera</em> Adanson (1763) is not explained by Adanson.

PAGE: 446
HEADING: MEYER, E. H. F. (1819)

5918. <em>Junci generis monographiae specimen</em>. Dissertatio inauguralis quam gratiosi ordinis

die [] mensis [] mdcccxix Ernestus Meyer hanoveranus. Gottingae [Göttingen] (typis J. C.

	Arten ...").

Vandenhoeck et Ruprecht) 1822. Oct. (<em>Syn. junc.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: probably Jul 1822 (fide rev. GGA 1 Aug 1822 [GGA almost always immediately
	reviewed books published in Göttingen], preface 19 Mai 1822; the projected monograph
	remained unpublished for reasons given by Meyer (1857, p. 210) and by Wunschmann
	(ADB 21: 565-569)), p. [1]-66. <em>Copies</em>: FI, G, H. MO, NY, USDA; IDC 209.

<em>Publ</em>.: 1830 (announced for Easter fair 1830 but probably publ. only second half 1830; p.

Meyer, Georg Friedrich Wilhelm (1782-1856), German botanist in Göttingen; from
1820 physiographer of the Kingdom of Hanover. (<em>G. Mey.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: GOET; contained part of F. Ehrhart's herbarium.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Meyeria</em> A. P. de Candolle (1836) was collectively dedicated to him and four of his
namesakes, see above under Ernst Heinrich Friedrich Meyer (1791-1858).

5930. <em>Primitiae florae essequeboensis</em> adjectis descriptionibus centum circiter stirpium nova-
rum, observationibusque criticis auctore Georgio Friderico Wilhelmi Meyer ... cum
tabulis aeneis duabus. Gottingae [Göttingen] (sumptibus Henrici Dieterich) 1818. Qu. (<em>Prim. fl. esseq.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Nov 1818 (p. x: Sep 1818; rev. Isis 1818(2): 1839-1845. Nov 1818; GGA 30 Jan 1819.
	The BM copy has an autograph letter dated 1 o Nov 1818 in which Meyer states that his
	<em>Primitiae</em> are just published), p. [i]-x, [1, h.t.], [1]-316, [1-2, err.], <em>pl. 1-2</em> (uncol. copp.
	auth.). <em>Copies</em>: FI, G, MO, NY, Stevenson, US (3) USDA; IDC 5480.
<em>Facsimile reprint</em>: announced, but not yet publ., by Asher and Koeltz (1974).
<em>Ref</em>.: X., Flora 2(1): 337-344. 14 Jun 1819 (rev.).

5931. <em>Beiträge zur chorographischen Kenntniss des Flussgebietes der Innerste</em> in den Fürstenthü-
mern Grubenhagen und Hildesheim mit besonderer Rücksicht auf die Veränderungen, die
durch diesen Strom in der Beschaffenheit des Bodens und in der Vegetation bewirkt worden
sind. Eine Anlage zur Flora des Königreichs Hannover ... Göttingen 1822, 2 vols. Oct. (<em>Beitr. chorogr. Kenntn. Innerste</em>).

<em>1</em>: Mai-Jun 1822, p, [i]-xxix, [1]-368, [1, err.], 2 charts.
<em>2</em>: Mai-Jun 1822, p. [i]-x, [1]-368, [1, err.], <em>pl. 1-2. Copies</em>: B, NY, US. – Alternative t.p. "Die
	<em>Verheerungen der Innerste</em> im Fürstenthume Hildesheim nach ihren Wirkungen und ihren
	Ursachen betrachtet, nebst Vorschlägen zu ihrer Verminderung und zur Wiederherstel-
	lung des versandeten Terrains." One of the earliest phytosociological and ecological
	treatises. Cover title: "<em>Erste Anlage zur Flora</em>... Hannover" Göttingen (Gedruckt bei C.
	Herbst).
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., FLora 5(1), Beil. 3: 107. 28 Jun 1822 (Neue Schriften; just rd by Flora).

5932. <em>Nebenstunden meiner Beschaeftigungen in Gebiete der Pflanzenkunde</em> von Geo. Friedr. Wilh.
Meyer. Erster Theil. Goettingen 1825. Oct. (<em>Nebenst. Beschaeft. Pflanzenk.</em>)

<em>Publ</em>.: Sep-Dec 1825 (p. viii: Apr 1825; Flora 21 Sep 1825 "nächstens"), double frontisp.
	plate (col. lith. Wachsmann), engr. t.p., [i*, printed t.p.], [1]-xi, [1, h.t.], [1]-372. Copies:
	G, L, NY, PH, Stevenson. – Only one volume publ.; the engr. t.p. was meant to cover the
	multivolume work. This first volume has a separate printed t.p.: "<em>Die Entwickelung,
	Metamorphose und Fortpflanzung der Flechten</em> in Anwendung auf ihre systematische Anord-
	nung und zur Nachweisung des allgemeinen Ganges der Formbildung in den untern

PAGE: 449
HEADING: MEYER, G. F. W. (1849)

	Ordnungen cryptogamischer Gewächse ..." Goettingen (bey Vandenhoeck und Ru-
	precht).
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Flora 8(1) Beil. 5: 146-147. Jul 1825 (printed but not yet distributed; awaiting
	the colouring of the plate).
	Schlechtendal, D. F. L. von, Linnaea 1(1): 104-107. Jan 1826 (rev.).
	Meyer, E., Flora 8(2): 558-560. 21 Sep 1825 (letter written summer 1825; book not yet
	out).

5933. <em>Chloris hanoverana</em> oder nach den natürlichen Familien geordnete Úbersicht der im
Königreiche Hannover wildwachsenden sichtbar blühenden Gewächse und Farn nebst
einer Zusammenstellung derselben nach ihrer Benutzung im Haushalte, in den landwirth-
schaftlichen Gewerben und in den Künsten ... Göttingen (Bei Vandenhoeck und Ru-
precht) 1836. Qu. (<em>Chloris han</em>.).

<em>Publ</em>.: prob. Jul-Aug 1836 (Hinrichs 7-13 Aug; p. viii "Anfang des Jahres 1836"), p. [i*],
	[i]iii, [1-3, table], [i]-vi (consp.), [1]-744. <em>Copies</em>: BR, G, H, MO, NY. – Infraspecific
	categories used: Unterarten (subspecies), Scheinarten, Abarten, Spielarten (varieties),
	Abünderungen und Umbildungen (forms). Flora (19: 728. 1836) mentions an "Erste
	Lieferung" present at the assembly of the Naturforscher of 25 Sep 1836.
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Lit. Ber. Flora 6: 143. 28 Nov 1836, 8: 52-64, 65-74. 1838.

5934. <em>Flora des Königreichs Hannover, angewandter Theil</em>. Untersuchung der einzelnen Vegeta-
bilien und der Vegetationsverhältnisse des Königreichs, in Anwendung auf die Erhöhung
seiner Naturalproduction und die Beförderung seines Gewerbwesens, ... Erster Theil.
Göttingen (Gedruckt in der Dieterichschen Universitäts Buchdruckerei) 1837. Oct. † (<em>Fl.
Hannover, angew. Theil</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Oct-Dec 1837 (p. xxviii: 17 Sep 1837), p. [v, sic]-xlii, [1], [1]-306, [1, err.]. <em>Copies</em>:
	NY, US. – Remained incomplete; intended to be the "applied part" of the sumptuous
	<em>Flora der Königreichs Hannover</em>. This first volume has a second t.p.: "<em>Úber die Matur der
	Schachtelhalme</em>, insbesondere des Sumpf-Schachtelhalms oder Duwocks, ... unter Hinzu-
	fügung einer Monographie der deutschen Schachtelhalmarten ..."

5935. <em>Flora des Königreichs Hannover</em>, oder Schilderung seiner Vegetation, nach ihrem
Gehalte an Gewächsen, deren Verbreitungs- und Vertheilungszustande und deren Ge-
schichtlichem Verhalten, in Anwendung auf die Beförderung des Volkswohlstandes. Be-
gründet durch Seine Majestät den König Wilhelm IV. Und fortgeführt auf Befehl und dem
huldreichen Schultze Ernst August ... Göttingen (bei dem Verfasser. Gedruckt bei Hein-
rich Gottfried Voigt in Hamburg) 1842-1854. Fol. (<em>Fl. Hannover</em>).

5936. <em>Flora hanoverana excursoria</em> enthaltend die Beschreibungen der phanerogamischen
Gewächse Norddeutschlands in den Flussgebieten der Ems, Weser und Unterelbe geordnet
nach natürlichen Familien unter Angabe der Wohn-und Standorte, der Bodenbeschaffen-
heit, der Begrenzung der Gesammtverbreitung und des Vorkommens im Gebiete, der
Häufigkeit, des Geselligkeitsverhältnisses und des geschichtlichen Verhaltens der einzeln
Pflanzenarten. Nebst einer speciellen Nachweisung ihrer gewerblichen Benutzung in
pharmaceutisch-medicinischer, technischer, ökonomischer und forstlicher Beziehung
... Göttingen (bei Vandenhoeck und Ruprecht) 1849. Oct. (<em>Fl. hanov. excurs.</em>).

Meyer-Abich, Adolf (1893-x), German biologist, philosopher and historian of biology;
Dr. phil Jena 1916; assistant librarian Univ. Göttingen 1917-1919, id. Kiel 1919-1921;
librarian Univ. Hamburg 1921-1937 ("Bibliothekrat"), professor's title 1930; professor of
philosophy Santiago, Chili 1929-1932; dir. Domin.-German Inst. Rep. Dominicana 1937-
1939; from 1956 professor Univ. Hamburg. (<em>Mey.-Abich</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Though not a systematic botanist Meyer-Abich should be mentioned here if only
because of the coining of the term <em>taxon</em> in his <em>Logik der Morphologie</em> 127, 133, 138. 1926
(Berlin, Julius Springer, vii, 290 p.) The present more precise use of the term was proposed
by H.J. Lam and accepted by the International Botanical Congress, Stockholm (1950).
The use of the word <em>Taxon</em> for the journal of IAPT came forward in a discussion, summer
1951, among C.E.B. Bremekamp, J. Lanjouw and F.A. Stafleu.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Bossert p. 265: GR p. 11; TL-2/3139.
Poggendorf, J.C., Biogr.-Lit. Handw.-Buch 7a (3): 291-292. 1958 (bibl.).

Meylan, Charles 1868-1941), Swiss cryptogamist at Lausanne, high school teacher at La
Chaux nr. Ste.-Croix (Lausanne) 1888-1923; Dr. sci.h.c. Lausanne 1922. (<em>Meyl</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: LAU and G (in herb. Walter Meyland 1873-1946). Further
material at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 484; BJI 2: 116; BM 7: 834; CSP 17: 214; GR p.

18376; MW suppl. p. 227; NAF 1(1): 165; SBC p. 127 ("Meyl.").
Guinet, A., Bull. Soc. bot. Genève ser. 2. 11: 8-11. 1919 (in CR. session 10 Feb 1919 Guinet
	explains the delay in publication from 1912-1918).

Mez, Carl Christian (1866-1944), German botanist; Dr. phil. Berlin 1888; habil. Breslau
1890; in München with Radlkofer 1888-1890; at the University of Breslau 1890-1899; 1899-
1910 professor of botany at Halle; director of the Königsberg botanical garden 1910-1935,
ultimately at Freiburg i.Br.; main promotor of serodiagnostics ("Königsberger Stamm-
baum") in systematic botany. (<em>Mez</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Some material at B and WRSL. The Königsberg University
herbarium, which contained much of Mez' material, was destroyed during an air-attack in
Sep 1944, shortly after M's death. Many of M's types designated in his "composite works"
may be found at B, M and G.
<em>Note</em>: Ziegenspeck (1944): "Wir beide waren Nationalsozialisten inmitten einer verjudeten
und mit Freimaurern gepflasterten Fakultät." [Better left untranslated]. It is possible that
this citation gives more information on the biographer than on the biographee.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 4: 749; Ainsworth p. 94, 324; Backer p. 369; Barnhart 2:
484; BJI 1: 40, 2: 116-117; BM 3: 1303, 7: 835; Bossert p. 266; CSP 17: 216; Hortus 3: 1199
("Mez"); IH 2: 535; Kew 3: 674; Langman p. 504; Lenley p. 291; LS 17789-17791, 36962-

PAGE: 452
HEADING: MEZ

36966, suppl. 18377-18379; Moebius p. 63; MW p. 321; Nordstedt suppl. p. 11; Rehder 5:
570; TL-2/1: 978, 1713; Tucker 1: 483; Zander ed. 10, p. 692, ed. 11, p. 789.
Anon., Bot. Centralbl. 44: 416. 1890 (habil. Breslau), 80: xv, 368. 1899 (ordinary prof. bot.
	Halle), 111: 256. 1909 (to Königsberg), 114: 176. 1910 (app. ib.); Hedwigia 75 (Beibl. 1):
	72. 1935 (retired 1 Apr 1934); Nat. Nov. 18: 531. 1896 (titular prof. Breslau), 21: 687.
	1899 (professor at Halle), 31: 415. 1909 (replaces Luerssen at Königsberg), 32: 372. 1910
	(definitive appointment Königsberg); Österr. bot. Z. 50: 30. 1 Jan 1900 (app. Halle).
Bergdolt, E., Karl von Goebel ed. 2. 133, 142. 1941.
Butzin, F., Willdenowia 4: 401-417. 1968 (bibl., 115 nos., main biogr., b. 24 Mar 1866, d. 15
	Jan 1944).
Diels, L., Bot. Jahrb. 51 (Lit.): 37-40. 1914 (fundamental criticism of the Serum-Diagnostik
	in a review of Mez, C. &amp; K. Gohlke, Physiol.-syst. Unters. Verwandtsch. Angiosp., Beitr.
	Biol. Pfl. 12(1): 155-180. 1913. "In sonderbarem Gemisch verrät Sie bald vorsichtige
	Bescheidung, bald ein ungehemmtes Bestreben, rein hypothetische Vorstellungen wie
	nachgewiesene Tatsachen vorzutragen" ... Für eine scharenweise Vermehrung der
	Spekulationen ... scheint ... kein Bedürfnis vorzuliegen; wir haben mehr als genug
	davon".)
Kneucker, A., Allg. bot. Z. 3: 36. 1897 (extraord. prof. bot. Breslau), 5: 204. 1899 (app.
	Halle), 15: 148. 1909 (temporarily replacing Luerssen at Königsberg).
Merrill, E. D., Enum. Philipp. pl. 4: 208. 1926 (bibl.); Bernice P. Bishop Mus. Bull. 144:
	135. 1937 (bibl.); Contr. U.S. natl. Herb. 30: 212. 1947.

	Bot. 10(2): 48-50. 1952.

5952. <em>Führer für Pilzfreunde</em>. Die am häufigsten vorkommenden essbaren, verdächtigen und
giftigen Pilze ... Zwickau i.S. (Druck und Verlag von Förster &amp; Borries) 1895. Oct. (<em>Führ.
Pilzfr.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: In many editions and reprints. Our inventory is incomplete.

<em>Main edition</em>: in three volumes which went through several editions independent of each
other.
	<em>Volume 1, ed. 1</em>: Jul 1895 (pref. Jul 1895; Nat. Nov. Jul(1) 1895; Hedwigia 19 Oct 1895), p.
	[i]-x, [1]-26, 47 figs. ("Pilzgruppen") on <em>40 pl</em>. (col.; with text). <em>Copy</em>: B.
	<em>ed. 2</em>: Jun 1896 (p. vi: Jun 1896, Nat. Nov. Jul(1) 1896), p. [i]-xi, [1]-31, <em>68 figs</em>. by A.
	Schmalfuss (col., with text). <em>Copy</em>: MICH.
	<em>ed. 2, reissue</em>: 1897 (t.p.), p. [i]-xi, [1]-31, <em>68 figs</em>. (id.). <em>Copies</em>: UC, USDA.
	<em>ed.3</em>: 1898, p. [i]-xii, [1]-31, <em>68 figs</em>. (id.). <em>Copy</em>: NY.

	MICH. – (We saw no copy of the 13.-15. Tausend).

	(<em>Zweites Tausend</em>): 1905, p. [i]-x, [1], <em>131 figs</em>. (id.). <em>Copy</em>: MICH.
	(<em>3.-5. Tausend</em>, called ed. 2 in preface): 1908 (p. v: Feb 1908), n.v.
	(<em>6.-8. Tausend</em>, called ed. 3 in preface): 1912 (p. v: Jun 1912), p. [i]-xi, [xii], <em>131 figs</em>.
	(id.). <em>Copies</em>: B, MICH.

<em>Note</em>: the linen-bound volumes were sold as <em>Ausgabe B</em> but not so designated on the t.p. until
	1917. The paperback edition (for schools) was sometimes referred to as Ausgabe "A".
	This term was also used for the issues of large size "Wandtafeln" on which the illustrations
	were reproduced (e.g. <em>5 pl</em>. 1895 with <em>47 figs., 8 pl</em>. with <em>76 figs</em>. ca. 1917; n.v.).

<em>Ausgabe</em> B: 1917-1919, 3 vols. With <em>346 figs</em>. (t.p. says 345). <em>Copies</em>: B, G, MICH – Zwickau Sa.
	(Druck und Verlag von &amp; Borries).
	<em>1</em> (<em>16.-20. Tausend</em>): 1917, n.v. (p. 6 Mai 1917).
	<em>1</em> (<em>21.-28. Tausend</em>): 1918 (p. 6: Jun 1918; all copies seen), p. [1]-81, <em>figs. 1-82</em> (1/4 per pl.; on
	<em>68 pl</em>.; col.).
	<em>2</em> (<em>15.-22. Tausend</em>): 1918, p. [1]-10, [1], <em>figs. 83-206</em> (id. on <em>84 pl</em>.).
	<em>3</em> (<em>13.-19. Tausend</em>): 1919, p. [1]-10, [1], <em>figs. 207-346</em> (id. on <em>86 pl</em>.).

<em>Volksausgabe</em> (<em>Ausgabe C</em>): one volume, various editions.
	<em>ed. 1</em>: 1896 (Nat. Nov. Jul(1) 1896), <em>29 pl</em>., n.v.
	<em>ed. 2</em>: 1906 (n.v.) (Bot. Centralbl. 9 Oct 1906).
	<em>ed</em>. [<em>?</em>] (<em>61.-80. Tausend</em>: 1917, p. [1]-25, <em>figs. 1-40</em> on <em>32 pl</em>. (col., w.t.). <em>Copy</em>: G.
	<em>ed</em>. [<em>?</em>] (<em>81.-100. Tausend</em>): 1918, p. [1]-25, <em>figs. 1-40</em> on <em>19 pl</em>. w.t. [p. 26-58]. <em>Copy</em>: NY.

<em>Ausgabe</em> D: 3 plates, 54 × 74 cm, "<em>Unsere besten Speise und Wirtschaftspilze</em>, ...", <em>40 figs</em>. n.v.

<em>New edition</em>: 1922-1924, of vol. 1, in four parts, "... systematisch geordnet und gänzlich neu
	bearbeitet von Roman Schulz, Berlin. Ausgabe E. Lieferungsausgabe der dreibändigen
	Gesammtwerkes ..." Zwickau, Sa. (Druck und Verlag von Förster &amp; Borries). – We saw
	only a single <em>copy</em> of the first volume published in 4 parts (MICH):
	<em>1</em>: text for nos. 1-32, <em>figs. 1-33.</em> Jun 1922.
	<em>2</em>: text for nos. 33-70, <em>figs. 34-71.</em> Mar 1923.
	<em>3</em>: text for nos. 71-111, <em>figs. 72-113.</em> Jul 1923.
	<em>4</em>: text for nos. 112-113,+ [1]-120. Jul 1924.
	The combined issue, in a single volume, was called "Ausgabe B", <em>fifth edition</em>, <em>29.-36.
	Tausend</em> of vol. 1.

	Pilzarten. Begründet von Edmund Michael herausgegeben und neu bearbeitet von
	Bruno Hennig, Jena (VEB Gustav Fischer Verlag). <em>Copies</em>: B, BR, UC.

	<em>6</em>: 1975, p. [2]-291, <em>pl 1-32</em>, id.
This edition actually started in 1939, vol. 1, 214 p., 123 figs. See E. Ulbrich, Hedwigia 80:
	(Beibl. 1): (40). 1942.

Michael, Paul Oskar (1861-?), German botanist from Oelsnitz i.V., Dr. phil. Leipzig
1885 (<em>P. Michael</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

5956. <em>Histoire naturelle du Jura</em> et des départements voisins, ... tome ii. <em>Botanique</em> par M. E.
Michalet, magistrat, ... revue et achevée par M. Grenier, ... Paris (Victor Masson et fils,

<em>Editor</em>: Jean Charles Marie Grenier (1808-1875).
<em>Publ</em>.: 1864, p. [i-iii], [1]-400. <em>Copy</em>: USDA.

Michaux, André (1746-1803), French botanist and explorer of Iran (1782-1785), North
America (1785-1796); later on a French exploring expedition (1800-1805) under Capt.
Baudin as far as Madagascar, where he died. (<em>Michx</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: The North American herbarium, mainly collected by Michaux
himself, is at P, kept separate as an <em>herbier historique</em> (2.192 species). The North American
bryophytes are kept separately at PC. This herbarium contains the types of the <em>Flora boreali</em>-
<em>americana</em>. On his return from N. America in 1769 Michaux was shipwrecked on the Dutch
coast and lost part of his collections. Duplicates are e.g. at B, BR, G and LIV, and also in the
general herbarium of P through the Richard herbarium. For Michaux' fern herbarium see
Morton (1967). The herbarium of the <em>Flora boreali-americana</em> is available on IDC microfiche
(no. 6211). Michaux' mss. itinerary is at PH.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 6: 591-592; AG 2(1): 450, 4: 532; Backer p. 369;
Barnhart 2: 485; BM 3; 1305, 7: 838; CSP 17: 226; DAB 12: 591-592; Dawson p. 610, 711;
DSB 9: 365-366; Dryander 3: 185; Frank 3(Anh.): 65; GF p. 67; GR p. 288; Herder p. 225,
296; Hortus 3: 1199 ("Michx."); IF p. 719; IH 1 (ed. 6): 362, 2: 535; Jackson p. 141, 360,
508; Kew 3: 675; Langman p. 505; Lasègue p. 461, 505; LS 17084a; ME 1: 212, 3: 358, 359,
362, 364, 735-736; MW p. 321; NI 1357-1359; Pennell p. 614; Plesch p. 334-335; PR 6194
(ed. 1: 6904-6905); Rehder 5: 571; RS p. 119, SBC p. 127 ("Michx."); Stevenson p. 1251;
SY p. 15; TL-1/839-840; TL-2/see index; Tucker 1: 483; Urban-Berl. p. 375; Zander ed. 10,
p. 692, ed. 11, p. 789.

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: Bartonia 28: <em>pl. 6.</em> 1957; see also <em>in</em> J. F. Leroy, Bot. franç. Amér. nord <em>pl. xxxi.</em>
1957.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Michauxia</em> L'Héritier (1788); <em>Michauxia</em> Salisbury (1796).

5957. <em>Histoire des chênes de l'Amérique</em>, ou descriptions et figures de toutes les espèces et
vatiétés de Chênes de l'Amérique septentrionale, considérées sous les rapports de la
botanique, de leur culture et de leur usage ... A Paris (De l'imprimerie de Crapelet) An ix-
1801. Fol. (<em>Hist. chênes Amér.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Mai 1801 (TL-1), p. [i, iii], [1]-[56] (sign. 1-14, only a few pages actually numbered),
	<em>pl. 1-36</em>, uncol. copp. by H. J. Redouté (nos. <em>1, 20, 33, 34</em>) and P. J. Redouté (all others).
	<em>Copies</em>: BR, FI, G, HU, L, MO, NY, U; IDC 6065. – In his preface Michaux states that he
	has left the work of publishing his books to his son: "J'ai laissé à mon fils le soin de
	surveiller l'impression de ces deux ouvrages [i.e. <em>Hist. chênes</em> and <em>Fl Am. sept.</em>]." There are
	copies on laid paper and, a smaller number, on wove paper. A copy with manuscript
	annotations by F. A. Michaux, as well as with many proofs and originals is at K.
<em>Abbreviated edition</em>: 1801, p. [i], [1]-2, [i]-iv, [i-iv, conspectus, notfound in orig. ed.], <em>pl. 1-36</em>
	(id.). <em>Copy</em>: G. – "<em>Histoire des chênes de l'Amérique</em>, ou ... septentrionale. Par André
	Michaux, ..." A Paris (Chez Levrault Frères, Quai Malaquais) An ix-1801. Fol. – We
	do not know whether this abbreviated variant edition with a new conspectus was indeed
	published later than the Crapelet edition.
<em>German translation</em>: 1802-1804. <em>Copy</em>: MO. – "<em>Geschichte der amerikanischen Eichen</em>, oder Be-
	schreibungen und Abbildungen aller Arten und Abarten der Eichen des nördlichen
	Amerika; nach ihren Kennzeichen, ihrem Anbau und Nutzen ... Übersetzt und mit
	illuminirten Abbildungen begleitet von Hofr. und Prof. J. S. Kerner [Johann Simon von
	Kerner 1755-1830] ..." Stuttgart (auf Kosten des Herausgebers. Gedruckt in Stras-
	bourg, bey Gebr. Levrault) 1802-1804. Qu. (<em>Gesch. amer. Eichen</em>). <em>Erstes Heft</em>: 1802, p. [i],
	[1]-16, <em>pl. 1-5</em> (col.). <em>Zweytes Heft</em>: 1804, p. [i], 17-28, <em>pl. 6-14</em> (id.). We have seen no copy
	of Hefte 3 and 4; they probably remained unpublished. The publisher announced also
	the availability of copies with uncolored plates. The book seems to be very rare (see e.g.
	Junk, Catal. 206, no. 211. 1977).
<em>English version</em>: 1808, by W. Wade, Trans. Roy. Dublin Soc. 6, 1808.

5958. <em>Flora boreali-americana</em>, sistens caracteres plantarum quas in America septentrionali
collegit et detexit Andreas Michaux, ... tabulis aeneis 51 ornata ... Parisiis et Argentorati
[Paris et Strasbourg] (typis Caroli Crapelet; apud Fratres Levrault) anno xi-1803, 2 vols.
Qu. and Oct. (<em>Fl. bor. -amer.</em>).

<em>Ed. 1</em>: 19 Mar 1803 (see also ICBN 30. 1).
	<em>Vol. 1</em>: p. [i]-x, [1, err.], [1]-330, <em>pl. 1-29.</em>
	<em>Vol. 2</em>: p. [i, iii], [1]-340, <em>pl. 30-51.</em>
	<em>Copies</em>: FAS (Oct.), G (Qu.), HU (Qu.), L (Oct.), MO (Oct.), NY (Oct.), US (Qu.,
	Oct.), USDA (Oct.); IDC 6130.
<em>Ed. 2</em> (actually a reissue): Parisiis (Bibliopola Jouanaux Junior ...) 1820. Oct. – Replace-
	ment of title pages only. Rarer than the first edition.
	<em>Copies</em>: G, NY, USDA; IDC 1061.
	<em>Vol. 1</em>: [i]-x, [1, err.], [1]-330, <em>pl. 1-29.</em>
	<em>Vol. 2</em>: [i-iii], [1]-340, <em>pl. 30-51.</em>
<em>Facsimile ed</em>.: New York (Hafner Press), New York (Collier Macmillan Publishers) 1974,
	Classica botanica americana vol. 3. Introduction [important!] by J. Ewan. ISBN 0-02-

PAGE: 459
HEADING: MICHAUX, F. A.

	849230-7. <em>Copy</em>: FAS. – See Taxon 23: 643. 1974.– 1: introduction [i]-xlvi, facsimile; 2: [i-
	iv, new t.p.'s], facsimile.

<sm>NOTES</sm>: Kunth (Rev. gram. 137. 1829; Biogr. univ. 27:560-570) and Pritzel attribute this
work to L. C. M. Richard. Martius (Fl. bras. 1:88. 1840) states of Richard "autor quoque
est, saltern pro maxima parte, Florae boreali-americanae ab Michaux 1803 editae" (cf.
McClure). Asa Gray (1841) states "Michaux himself, though an excellent and industrious
collector and observer, was by no means qualified for authorship: and it is to L. C. Richard
that the sagacious observations, and the elegant terse and highly characteristic specific
phrases of this work are entirely due". Gray states in 1882 that the tradition that the
descriptions were drawn up by L. C. Richard "is confirmed by the fact that Richard's
herbarium ... contains an almost complete set of the plants described, and I found that the
specimens of Michaux supplied to Willdenow's herbarium at Berlin were ticketed and sent
by Richard." See also Sayre 1976. – It is likely that Richard gave advice in the preparation
of the manuscript and even prepared part of the descriptions, but Michaux regarded this
work certainly as his own. His son saw the book through the press (<em>Hist. Chênes</em>, preface).
Michaux must be cited as the author of the new taxa. The author citation is anyhow simply
a bibliographical reference and not an award of merit. The book was published in two
issues, quarto and octavo, with identical type setting and pagination. The octavo issue is on
"papier grand raisin", The quarto issue is on "papier vélin", the quarto edition came out
somewhat later: on 28 Mai 1803 it was not yet available (JT) ... Since the two volumes were
published at the same time and as a whole, it is necessary to take the addenda et corrigenda
on p. [xii] of volume 1 into account for the orthography of new names published in the <em>Flora</em>.
The 51 uncoloured copper engravings are all from drawings by P. J. Redouté.

<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., J. typogr. 6: 217. 1803 (30 germ. 11).
	Mitchell, Med. Repos. 8: 394-395. 1805 (rev. of Flora; fide Swan).
	Hooker, W. J., Edinburgh J. Sci. 2: 108-129. 1825 (attributes the Flora to Richard).
	Gray, A., <em>in</em> W. J. Hooker J. Bot. 3: 368. 1841.
	Gray, A., Amer. J. Sci. ser. 3. 24: 322-323. 1882, see also Bot. Gaz. 7: 139-141. 1882
	(attributes the <em>Flora</em> to Richard).

Michaux, François-André (1770-1855), French botanist; son of André M., whom he
accompanied to the United States 1785-1790; travelled again in the U.S. 1801-1803 and
1806-1807. (<em>F. Michx</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: <sm>NO</sm>separate collections made by Michaux fils are known to exist. He
may have based himself mainly on his father's herbarium. According to Deleuze (Hist.
Muséum p. 319) F. A. Michaux' types are at P. – The original drawings for the <em>Histoi</em>re des
<em>arbres forestiers</em> are at the Bibliothèque Centrale of the Paris Muséum national d'Histoire
naturelle.

montagnes et la Basse Louisiane; entrepris pendant l'an x-1802, sous les auspices de son
excellence M. Chaptal, ministre de intérieur. Avec une carte très-soignée des états du

The 140 (138 plus 2 bis plates which were intended to replace the proper numbers) stipple
engravings are colour-printed and retouched by hand. They are from drawings by P. Bessa
(75), P.J. Redouté (32), H.J. Redouté (27), A. Riché (3) and A. Redouté [sic] (1).– Ms 328
of the Paris Muséum contains 147 [sic] of the original drawings. This is possible because
some figures are combined on one plate.

5964. <em>The North American sylva</em>; or, a description of the forest trees of the United States,
Canada, and Nova Scotia, considered particularly with respect to their use in the arts, and
their introduction into commerce; to which is added a description of the most useful of the
European forest trees. Illustrated by 156 coloured engravings. Translated from the French
of F. Andrew Michaux, ... with three additional volumes, containing all the forest trees
discovered in the Rocky Mountains, the territory of Oregon, down to the shores of the
Pacific and into the confines of California, as well as in various parts of the United States.
Illustrated by 122 finely coloured plates. By Thomas Nuttall, F.L.S., ... the whole forming
six volumes, and comprising 278 plates ... Philadelphia (J. Dobson, ... Printed by William
Amphlett, New Harmony, Indiana) 1841-1842. Qu. (<em>N. Amer. sylv.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: The first three volumes of this <em>New Harmony edition</em> are a reprint of the 1819 Paris
	reissue (3 vols.) of the Hillhouse translation (no. 5962). Volumes 4-6, by Nuttall, are
	treated under that author. The plates are as in the 1819 reissue. <em>Copies</em>: MO (bound in 2
	vols.), NY (complete).
	<em>1</em>: 1841, p. [i]-xviii, [1]-122, <em>pl. 1-50</em> (as in 1819 reissue).
	<em>2</em>: s.d. [1841], p. [i]-iv, 123-184, <em>pl. 51-76</em>, [1]-74, <em>pl. 77-100.</em>
	<em>3</em>: 1842, p. [i]-iv, [75]-216, <em>pl. 101-105, 106</em> (as "107"), 107 (as "106"), <em>108-142, 143</em> (as
	"144"), <em>144</em> ("143"), <em>145-156</em>.

5965. <em>North American sylva</em>, or a description of the forest trees of the United States, Canada
and Nova Scotia; considered particularly with respect to their use in the arts, and their
introduction into commerce. To which is added a description of the most useful of the
European forest trees. Illustrated by 156 colored engravings. Translated from the French of
F. Andrew Michaux, ... in two volumes ... Cincinnati (published by W. Amphlett and
Doolittle &amp; Munson) 1842. Qu. (<em>N. Amer. sylv.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: A reissue in two volumes of the material contained in the first three volumes of the
	1841 New Harmony edition treated above. The coloring of the plates is poor; they are
	still the same as those in the Paris 1819 Hillhouse translation. <em>Copy</em>: MO.
	<em>1</em>: 1842, p. [i], [1]-184, <em>pl. 1-75.</em>
	<em>2</em>: 1842, p. [i], 1-216, <em>pl. 76-105, 106</em> (<em>as</em> "<em>107</em>"), <em>107</em> (as "106"), <em>108-142,143</em> (as "144"), 144
	(as "143"), <em>145-156</em>.

5966. <em>The North American sylva</em>; or a description of the forest trees of the United States,
Canada, and Nova Scotia, considered particularly with respect to their use in the arts, and
their introduction into commerce; to which is added a description of the most useful of the

Bessa, etc. Translated from the French of F. Andrew Michaux, ... with notes by J. Jay
Smith, ... in three volumes ... Philadelphia (Robert P. Smith) New York (G. P. Putnam)
1850-1851. Qu. (<em>N. Amer. sylv.</em>).

<em>Notes</em>: John Jay Smith (1798-1881), see Barnhart 3: 294.

Michel, Etienne (<em>fl</em>. 1816), French publisher and (in part) editor of the "Nouveau
Duhamel" (<em>Michel</em>).

<em>Note</em>: for the "Nouveau Duhamel" see TL-2/1547.

Michel, Mathieu Joseph (1825-1890), Belgian self-taught botanist and workman at
Fraipont; founder, 1876, of the "Société de Botanique de Fraipont et de Nessonvaux"
consisting of workmen only. (<em>M. Michel</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 485; BL 2: 41, 691; Jackson p. 272; Morren ed.
10, p. 46; Rehder 1: 393.
Anon., Rev. Verviét. Hist. nat. 9(5/6): 53. 1952 (b. 25 Oct 1825, d. 5 Jul 1890).
Grondal, G., Biogr. Verviét., nos anciens botanistes 28-29. 1952 (b. 25 Oct 1825, d 5. Jul
	1890); Rev. Verviét. Hist. nat. 9: 53. 1952.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Michelsonia</em> L. Hauman (1952) is dedicated to A. Michelson (fl. 1912), Russian
traveller and explorer.

5968. Société de botanique de Fraipont et Nessonvaux. <em>Flore de Fraipont</em>, Nessonvaux et
leurs environs, y compris toute la Vallée de la Vesdre, depuis Limbourg jusqu'à Chênée, le
cours de l'Ourthe, depuis Hamoire jusqu'à la Meuse, les cours de la Hoëgne et le ruisseau
dit le Waag, depuis Sart jusqu'à Pepinster, les bords de l'Amblêve, depuis Nanceveux
jusqu'à Douflamme et depuis Stavelot à la Cascade de Coo, les bords de la Meuse, d'Ougrée
à Herstal, Ile Moncin et Jupille. Exploration par la Société, sous la direction de Mr. M.
Michel, botaniste amateur. Étude de plantes récoltées depuis 1869 jusqu'en 1876. Verviers
(imp. E. Piette et Cie.) 1877. 16-mo. (<em>Fl. Fraipont</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1877 (Bot. Zeit. 7 Dec 1877), p. [1]-389. <em>Copies</em>: B, BR, G.
<em>Additions</em>: Bull. Soc. Bot. Belg. 18: 98-103. 1879.
<em>Note</em>: The title-page of this flora is a manifestation of an early emancipatory movement
among the working class of the eastern part of the province of Liège, Belgium. Michel, as
"botaniste amateur" simply "directed" the work of his society which consisted exclusively
of workmen.

Micheletti, Luigi (1844-1912), Italian army officer, lichenologist and general floristic
botanist. (<em>Micheletti</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: TO; further material PAD (types), Fl (Erytrea).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 486; BL 2: 343, 691; Bossert p. 266; CSP 17:
229-230; GR p. 535; 1H 2: 535; Langman p. 505; LS 17809-17814; Rehder 1: 215; Saccardo
1: 110; Tucker 1: 484.
Baccarini, P., Bull. Soc. bot. Ital. 1913(2/3): 13 (b. 20 Aug. 1844, d. 18 Dec 1912).
Chiovenda, E., Nuovo Giorn. bot. ital. 31: 307. 1924 (herb. at TO; d. 28 Dec 1912).

HEADING: MICHELI, M.

Cufodontis, G., C. R. AETFAT 4: 244. 1962 (coll. Erythr.).
Sayre, G., Bryologist 80: 513. 1977 (bryoph. TO).

Micheli, Marc (1844-1902), Swiss botanist and landowner at Geneva; pupil of Hofmeister
and Sachs; later collaborator of Alphonse de Candolle; burgomaster of Jussy; owner of the
<em>Jardin du Crest</em>(Jussy), maintained as a private botanical garden for plant introduction and
agricultural experiments. (<em>M. Mich.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: G (rd. 1904); includes the herbarium of F. S. Alioth (Basel).
Micheli's library was dispersed after his death; his botanical correspondence was given to G
in 1938.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 486; BM 3: 1305-1306; Bossert p. 266; CSP 8:
400, 10: 804, 17: 230; Dawson p. 760?; Herder p. 466 [index]; Hortus 3: 1199 ("Micheli,
M."); IH 2: 535; Jackson p. 3, 372, 373; Kew 3: 676; Langman p. 505; Lasègue p. 21, 341;
LS 17815; Morren ed. 10, p. 110; MW p. 321, suppl. p. 228; Rehder 5: 571; TL-2/1: 978,
1592; Tucker 1: 484; Zander ed. 10, p. 692, ed. 11, p. 789.
André, E., Rev. Hort. 74: 342-344. 1902 (portr.).
Anon., Bot. Jahrb. 32 (Beibl. 72): 4. 1903 (d.); Bot. Not. 1903: 34 (d. 10 Jul 1902, err.);J. de
	Genève 1 Jul 1902 (fide Alph. de Candolle 1902); J. Bot., Morot, Bull. bibl. 16: lxxxviii.
	1902 (d. 29 Jun 1902).

	(biogr.; most complete bibl.).

Micheli, Pier' Antonio (Pietro Antonio) (1679-1737), Italian botanist, "oculatissimus
Michelius" (L.), curator of the botanical garden of Firenze, "father of cryptogamy",
founder of the Società botanica fiorentina; botanist to the grand duke of Tuscany. (<em>P.
Mich.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM, MANUSCRIPTS</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: FI; the herbarium (30.000 specimens) contains plants
collected by Micheli himself as well as by Petiver, Scheuchzer and Sherard. See Parlatore
(1874). Further material at BM-SL, CR, OXF. – Micheli's manuscripts are also at FI.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2(1): 150; Ainsworth p. 345 [index]; Backer p. 369;
Barnhart 2: 486; BM 3: 1306; Bossert p. 266; Clokie p. 24; Dryander 1: 197, 241, 3: 35, 111,
644; DSB 9: 368-369; DTS 1: 189-190; Frank 3(Anh.): 65; GR p. 535; Hawksworth p. 184,
196; Hegi 7: 559; Herder p. 83, 154; Hortus 3: 1199 ("Micheli, P."); HU 480; IH 1 (ed. 6):
362, 2: 535; Jackson p. 13, 31, 433; Kelly p. 149; Kew 3: 676; Krempelh. 2: 20-27; Lasègue
21, 341; LS 17816-17817; Maiwald p. 151, 196; Moebius p. 96, 97, 108, 112, 115, 118, 136,
277; MW p. 321; NI 1363; Plesch p. 335-336; PR 6201-6203, 7950, 9104, 10440 (ed. 1:
6914-6916); Rehder 5: 571; Saccardo 1: 110. 2: 73, cron. xxvi-xxvii; SO add. 2521a*;
Stevenson p. 1251; TL-1/843; TL-2/4455; Tucker 1: 484.

	Polyporus, Clathrus, Aspergillus</em>...).

<em>Micheliopsis</em>Hsuan Keng (1955); <em>Paramichelia</em>Hu (1940). <em>Note</em>: <em>Neomichelia</em> O. Penzig &amp; P.
A. Saccardo (1901) is dedicated to Pietro Antonio Michiel [sic] (1510-1576), Venetian
patrician, connoisseur and collector of plants, one of the founders of the Hortus in Padova.
Whether Saccardo's "journal" <em>Michelia</em>,Commentarium Mycologicum. Padua. Vol. 1-2.
1877-1882 is also dedicated to our author is not known with certainty.

5973. <em>Relazione dell'erba</em>detta da' botanici <em>Orobanche</em>e volgarmente succiamele, fiamma, e
mal d'occhio. Che da molti anni in quà si è soprammodo propagata quasi per tutta la
Toscana. Nella quale si dimostra con brevità, qual sia la vera origine di detta erba; perchè
danneggi i legumi; e il modo di estirparla ... in Firenze (Nella Stamp, di S.A.R. per li
Tartini, e Franchi ...) 1723. Oct. (<em>Relaz. Orobanche</em>).

<em>Orig. ed</em>.: 1723, p. [1]-47. <em>Copy</em>: FI.
<em>Post-linnaean extract</em>: 1754, p. [1]-34. <em>Copy</em>: FI. – <em>Compendia della relazione</em>del celebre botanico
	Pierantonio Micheli <em>intorno all'erba Orobanche</em>detta volgarmente Succiamele contenento
	l'unico e vero modo di estiparla ... in Firenze (appresso Andrea Bonducci ...) 1754.

5974. <em>Nova plantarum genera</em>juxta Tournefortii mcthodum disposita/Quibus plantae
mdcccc recensentur, scilicet fere mcccc nondum observatae, reliquae suis sedibus restitutae;
quarum vero figuram exhibere visum fuit, eae ad dl aeneis tabulis cviii. graphice expressae

PAGE: 468
HEADING: MICHELI, P. A.

sunt; adnotationibus, atque observationibus, praecipue fungorum, mucorum, affiniumque
plantarum sationem, ortum, &amp; incrementum spectantibus, interdum adjectis ... Floren-
tiae (Typis Bernardi Paperinii, ...) 179. Folio (in sets of two). (<em>Nov. pl. gen.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1729, p. [i-xxiv], 1-234, <em>pl</em>. <em>1-108</em>(uncol. copp.). <em>Copies</em>: FI, G, HU, NY, Stevenson,
	Teyler, US, USDA; IDC 6068. – Sixty plates for this volume are at BM. – Micheli's own

Migula, Emil Friedrich August Walther (1863-1938), German botanist; Dr. phil.
Breslau 1888; lecturer, from 1893 professor of botany at the Technical University of
Karlsruhe (1888-1904) and at the Forestry School of Eisenach (1904-1915). (<em>Mig</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: JE (Algae, lichenes). Exsiccatae: (1) <em>Kryptogamae</em> (<em>Cryptogamae</em>)
<em>Germaniae, Austriae et Helvetiae exsiccatae</em> fasc. 1-62, 1500 nos., 1902-1933, details see GR, IH
and Sayre (1969).
(2) <em>Characeae exsiccatae</em> fasc. 1-6, nos. 1-150, 1892-1901. Co-authors, P. Sydow (1851-1925),
L. J. Wahlstedt (1836-1917), details see IH and Sayre (1969).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 488; BJI 1:40, 2: 117; BM 3: 1309-1310, 7: 840;
CSP 17: 237; De Toni 1: lxxxv, 4: xxxix; DTS 1: 191; GR p. 32; <em>pl</em>. [<em>15</em>], cat. p. 68;
Hawksworth p. 184, 196; Hirsch p. 199; IH 1 (ed. 6); 362, 2: 537; Kelly p. 149; Kew 3: 680;

PAGE: 475
HEADING: MIGULA (1898)

KR p. 502; LS 36989-36993, suppl. 18429-18446; Moebius p. 70, 85, 86, 364; MW p. 322;
Nordstedt p. 23, suppl. p. 11, 18; SBC p. 127 ("Mig."); Stevenson p. 1251.
Anon., Bot. Centralbl. 57: 159. 1894 (prof. bot. Karlsruhe); Bot. Jahrb. 18 (Beibl. 44): 41.
	1894 (ord. prof. Karlsruhe), 37 (Beibl. 84): 3. 1906 (ord. prof. bot. Eisenach); Mycol.

	(app. Eisenach); Ósterr. bot. Z. 44: 80. 1894 (ord. prof. Karlsruhe).
Christiansen, W. &amp; W., Bot. Schrifttum Schlesw.-Holst. 318 [index]. 1936.
Hedge, I. C. &amp; J. M. Lamond, Index coll. Edinb. herb. 110. 1970 (exsicc.).
Kneucker, A., Allg. bot. Z. 11: 20. 1905 (to Eisenach as prof. of botany).

6004. <em>Lebermoose und Torfmoose</em> ein Hilfsbuch zum Erkennen, Bestimmen, Sammeln, Unter-
suchen und Präparieren der am häufigsten vorkommenden Formen ... Stuttgart (Ge-
schäftsstelle des Mikrokosmos: Franckh'sche Verlagshandlung) 1932. Oct. (<em>Leberm. Torfm.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1932 (Hedwigia 20 Dec 1933; Nat. Nov. Jan 1933), p. [1]-48, <em>pl. 1-8</em> (<em>uncol</em>.). <em>Copies</em>: B,
	MO.

Mik, Josef (1839-1900), Moravian botanist and dipterologist; studied at the Olmütz
gymnasium 1850-1857; at the University of Vienna 1857-1861; high school teacher at Görz
1861-1865 at Linz 1865-1867, at Freistadt 1867-1871; from 1871-1899 professor at the
academic gymnasium in Wien and school inspector; Schulrath 1894; Franz Joseph Order
1899. (<em>Mik</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 5(2): 454; Barnhart 2: 488; BM 3: 1310; Bossert p. 266;
CSP 4: 384, 8: 402, 10: 808, 12: 508, 17: 238-239; DTS 1: xxi, 191; Futák-Domin p. 395;
Klášterský p. 127; PR 6216; Rehder 1: 441; Saccardo 2: 73.
Anon., Bot. Centralbl. 84: 208. 1900 (d. 15 (err.) Oct 1900); Bot. Not. 1901: 114 (d.);
	Entomol. Nachr. 26: 363. 1900 (obit., d. 13 Oct 1900); Leopoldina 36: 180. 1900 (d. 13
	Oct 1900); Österr. bot. Z. 50: 419. 1900 (d. 13 Oct 1900); Verh. zool. bot. Ges. Wien 50:
	462. 1900 (d. 13 Oct 1900); Mitt. naturw. Ver. Troppau 6: 245-246. 1900 (obit., portr.;
	from "Insectenbörse" nr. 45); Zool. Anz. 23: 680. 1900 (d.).
Brauer, F., Wiener entom. Zeit. 20: 1-7. 1901 (obit., portr., bibl. additional to Mik 1891).
Carpenter, M. M., Amer. Midl. Natural. 33(1): 69. 1945 (biogr. refs.).
Gilbert, J., Comp. biogr. lit. deceased entom. 257-258. 1977 (biogr. refs).
Mik, J., Wiener entom. Zeit. 1891: 65-96 (bibl.).
Osten Sacken, C. R., Record of my life work in entomology 164-180. 1903 (on Mik's
	opposition to O. S. system of Diptera).
Papavero, N., Essays hist. neotrop. dipterol. 2: 326-327. 1975.
Verrall, G. H., Trans. entom. Soc. London, Proc. 1: xliv-xlv. 1900.
Wittrock, V. B., Acta Horti Berg. 3(3): 69. 1905.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Mik published a <em>Herbarium für Schüler</em>, sowie Pflanzen-Etiquetten zur Anlegung von
Schüler-Herbarien. Wien (A. Pichler's Witwe und Sohn) 1886 (reissued 1889, 1890); ed. 2
1892 (see e.g. J., Österr. bot. Z. 37: 109. 1887). We failed to locate a copy of Mik, <em>Beitrag zu
einer Phanerogamenflora von Freistadt</em>, 1871, facsimile ed. 1942 (with notes by J. Rohrhofer; see
E. Janchen, Cat. fl. austr. 1: 20. 1956).

6005. <em>Flora der Umgebung von Olmütz</em>. Eine systematische Aufzählung der urn Olmütz
wildwachsenden, und im Freien kultivirten phanerogamischen Pflanzen, nebst einem
Schlüssel zur Bestimmung der Gattungen in analytischer Anordnung. Von Joseph Mik,
Candidat für das Gymnasial-Lehramt zu Wien, mit einem Vorworte von Karl B. Heller [<em>fl</em>.
1860]. Professor ... Theresianischen Akademie zu Wien. Olmütz (Verlag von Eduard
Hölzel) 1860. Oct. (<em>Fl. Olmütz</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Jun-Dec 1860 (p. [vi]: Mai 1860), p. [i*-ix*], [i]-lxiv, [1]-148, [1-8, index]. <em>Copy</em>: B.
<em>Ref</em>.: Schlechtendal, D. F. L. von, Bot. Zeit. 19: 91-92. 5 Apr 1891 (rev.).

Mikan, Johann Christian (1769-1844), Bohemian (Czech) botanist and entomologist;
Dr. med. Praha 1793; professor of natural history Praha 1800-1831; travelled in Brazil with
Pohl 1817-1819. (<em>J. C Mikan</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: W; dupl. BR, PR, PRC. – The collections of the Austrian explorers
of Brazil, Mikan, Pohl, Natterer and Schott were originally deposited at the Brazilian
natural history museum "in der Johannisgasse im Graf Harrachischen Hause", under the
responsibility of the "Hofnaturalienkabinett". The collections were later moved to the
"Naturhistorisches Hofmuseum," now W. (see e.g. Flora 5(2): 465-468. 1822).

HEADING: MIKAN, J. C.

<sm>ICONOGRAPHY</sm>: J. C. Mikan's unpublished iconography of the Bohemian flora is at the
Library of Charles University, Prague. The drawings are by F. Čepelka (9) ańd by F. Seidel

6006. <em>Delectus florae et faunae brasiliensis</em> jussu et auspiciis Francisci I Austriae imperatoris
investigatae. Auctore J. C. Mikan ... Vindobonae [Wien] (sumtibus auctoris, typis
Antonii Strauss) 1820[-1825]. Broadsheet (<em>Del. fl. faun. bras.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: In four parts, p. [1-52], <em>24 col. pl. Copies</em>: FI, G, MO, NY; IDC 6069. – Twelve of the 24
	unnumbered plates are botanical; the numbers are those assigned by Stearn (1956); nos.
	<em>1</em> and <em>7</em> as well as the analysis of no. <em>2</em> are by Ferd. Bauer; nos. <em>2, 9, 14</em> are by Buchberger
	(from living plants in Brazil), nos. <em>19, 20, 21</em> are by Satory. Each part contained 6 plates
	accompanied by 6 lvs. of text. The cover of the NY copy gives the contents of the 4 parts;
	this cover is dated 1823 (not 1825). Even so it is likely that fasc. 1, appeared only in 1825.
	(see e.g. Stearn 1956).

Mikan, Joseph Gottfried (1743-1814), Bohemian (Czech) botanist at Praha; founder
and director of the botanical garden in Smichow (Praha) 1775-1811; father of J. C. Mikan.
(<em>J. G. Mikan</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 372; Barnhart 2: 488; BM 3: 1310; Dryander 3:

	tät in Prag. Prag 3-4, 7, 9. 1899, Österr. bot. Z. 49(2): 42. 1899.
Wittrock, V. B., Acta Horti Berg. 3(2): 84, 186. 1903 (b. 3 Sep 1743, d. 7 Aug 1814).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Kanimia</em> G. Gardner (1847, anagram); <em>Mikania</em> Willdenow (1803, <em>nom. cons.</em>);
<em>Mikaniopsis</em> Milne-Redhead (1956). – We could not establish with certainty the derivation
of <em>Mikania</em> F. W. Schmidt (1795, <em>nom. rej.</em>).

6007. <em>Catalogus plantarum omnium</em> juxta systematis vegetabilium Caroli a Linné editionem
novissimam decimam tertiam in usum horti botanici pragensis. Pragae (in officina Wolf-
gangi Gerle) 1776. Oct. (<em>Cat. pl. omn.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1776, p. [i]-viii, [1]-403, [index, err. 404-424]. <em>Copies</em>: FI, MO, NY, USDA.

Miki, Shigeru (1901-1974), Japanese palaeobotanist and botanist at Kagawa and Osaka;
described <em>Metasequoia</em>. (<em>Miki</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: OSA. – Palaeobotanical collections and preparations at Dept.
Biology, Osaka City University.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Andrews p. 303; Barnhart 2: 488; Bossert p. 266; Hirsch p.
199; Hortus 3: 1200 ("Miki"); Kew 3: 680; MW p. 322, suppl.p. 229-230; Roon p. 78; SK 8:
lxvi; Zander ed. 10, p. 692, ed 11, p. 789.
Anon., Taxon 23: 890. 1974.
Ewan, J. et al., Short hist. bot. U.S. 123. 1969.

Mikutowicz, Johann Mattias (1872-1951), Baltic German botanist in Livonia. (<em>Mi-
kut</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: RIGA, H. – Exsiccatae: <em>Bryotheca baltica</em>, fasc. 1-14, nos. 1-700, Riga,
1908-1914, sets at B, BM, C, E, FH, H, RIG (Number of copies: 30).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 488; Hirsch p. 199; IH 2: 538; SBC p. 127
("Mik."); Urban-Berl. p. 308.
Dörfler, J., Botaniker-Adressbuch 130. 1896 ("Handschuhmacher").
Hedge, I. C. &amp; J. M. Lamond, Index coll. Edinb. herb. 110. 1970 (coll. E).
Sayre, G., Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19(2): 232-233. 1971; Bryologist 80: 514. 1977.
Szymkiewicz, D., Bibl. Fl. Polsk. 54, 106. 1925.

Milani, Giovanni Battista (1858-?), Italian botanist; high school teacher at the lyceum
of Salerno, later id. at Avellino. (<em>Milani</em>).

HEADING: MILANI

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.
