Nadeaud ... Paris (F. Savy, ...) 1873. Oct. (<em>Énum. pl. Tahiti</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Jan-Jul 1873 (p. v: 2 Mai 1872), p. [i*], [i]-v, [7]-86. <em>Copis</em>: G, L, NY.
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Bull. Soc. bot. France 20(bibl.): 26-27. Aug. 1873.

Nádvornik, Joseph (Josef) (1906-1977), Czechoslovak lichenologist and high school
teacher (from 1925-1966) at Uzhgorod, Hlinsko and Praha. (<em>Nádv</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm>and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BRA (lichen herbarium, 11,000). <em>Exsiccatae</em>: (1) <em>Caliceae exsiccatae</em>,
dec. 1-5, nos. 1-54, Praha 1935-1951. Sets at BM, FH, H, M, UPS, W; (2) <em>Lichenes exsiccati</em>,
nos. 1-30, Praha 1954-1959, set at UPS; (3) <em>Physciaceae exsiccati</em>, dec. 1-3, nos. 1-33, Praha
1943-1945. Set at FH, M, UPS, UPSV.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm>and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: GR p. 665-666, <em>pl</em>. [<em>25</em>], cat. p. 68; IH 2: (in press); SBC p.
128.
Anon., Rev. bryol. lichénol. 10: 111, 117. 1937, 19: 110-111. 1950, 21: 195. 1952, 25: 406.
	1956; Taxon 25: 506. 1977.
Cernohorský, Zd., Preslia 50: 189-191. 1978 (portr., obit., bibl., b. 13 Feb 1906, d. 8 Jul
	1977); Int. Lichenol. Newsl. 10(2): 9. 1977.
Gyelnik, V. K., Ann. Hist. Nat. Mus. Natl. Hung., Bot. 31: 56. 1938.
Hawksworth, D. L. &amp; M. R. D. Seaward, Lichenol. Brit. Isles 1568-1975. 125. 1977.
Laundon, J. R., Lichenologist 11: 15. 1979.
Sayre, G., Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19(1): 150-151. 1969.

Nägeli, Carl Wilhelm [von], [Naegeli] (1817-1891), Swiss-born botanist; Dr. phil.
Zürich 1840; Dr. med. h.c. Freiburg 1854; habil. 1842; professor of botany at Zürich 1848-
1852; at Freiburg i.Br. 1852-1855; at the ETH Zürich 1855-1857; at München 1857-1891.
(<em>Näg</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm>and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Algae herbarium at M (r. 1933, via herb. F. J. E. Correns), other
material at BM, CGE, DBN, E, G, HBG, L (herb. Kützing), M (Lich. rd 1892), MANCH,
MJG, ZT. <em>Hieracia</em> e.g. at BM and G; see also A. Peter, <em>Hieracia naegeliana</em>.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm>and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 5: 752, 12(1): 248; Ainsworth p. 21, 117, 121, 274, 301,
325, 345; Barnhart 2: 534; BJI 1: 42; BM 3: 1388-1389, 7: 892; Bossert p. 280; Cesati p. 280-
282, Saggio p. 54; Collander hist. p. 64, 65; CSP 4: 565-566, 8: 479, 10: 896-897, 12: 531, 17:
443; De Toni 1: xc, 2: lxxxiv; DSB 9: 600-602 (bibl.); DTS 1: 209-210; Frank 3(Anh.): 70;
GR p. 633, cat. p. 68; Hegi 6(2): 1225; Herder p. 468; IH 1 (ed. 6): 362, 2: (in press);
Jackson p. 70, 71, 75, 76, 83, 92, 156, 166, 172, 220; Kew 4: 102; KR 1: 242, 256, 2: 310, 3:
99; Krempelh. 2: 310; LS 18749-18764; Moebius p. 454 [index]; Morren ed. 2, p. 9, ed. 10,
p. 18; NAF ser. 2. 6: 70, 8: 48; Nordstedt p. 24, suppl. p. 12; PR 1947, 1948, 4775, 6597-
6609, 8227 (ed. 1: 7369-7371); Rehder 1: 34, 245, 5: 605-606; SBC p. 128; TL-2/see indexes;
Tucker 1: 510.

	Wiss. Wien 41: 187-189. 1891 (obit.); Bonplandia 3: 176. 1855 (to ETH-Zürich), 5: 172.
	1857 (to München), 8: 126. 1860, 10: 213. 1862.; Bot. Centralbl. 5: 224. 1881 (foreign

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Naegelia</em>L. Rabenhorst (1844); <em>Naegelia</em>Regel (1847); <em>Naegeliellia</em>Correns
(1893). <em>Note</em>: The derivations for <em>Naegelia</em> P. F. Reinsch (1878) and <em>Naegelia</em> Zollinger et
Moritzi (1846) were not given by the authors. <em>Naegeliella</em>Schroeter (1893) is a substitute
name for <em>Naegelia</em>P. F. Reinsch.

Nägeli, Otto (1871-1938), Swiss botanist and physician; habil. int. med. Zurich 1900;
professor of medicine at Tübingen 1912-1918; id. at Zürich 1918 (from 1921 as ord. prof.).
(<em>O. Näg.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 535; BFM 1006, 1007, 1271; BJI 2: 122; BL 2:
582, 583, 591, 694; BM 3: 1389; Hirsch p. 209; Kew 4: 102; Rehder 1: 438.

Nakai, Takenoshin [Takenosin] (1882-1952), Japanese botanist; Ph. D. Tokyo Univ.
1907; Dr. Sci. Tokyo 1914; from 1908-1947 assistant, lecturer (1917), assistant professor
(1922) and professor of botany (1927) at the University of Tokyo; from 1943-1945 director

HEADING: NAKAI (1915)

of the Buitenzorg (now Bogor) Botanical Gardens in occupied Java; from 1947 director of

HEADING: NASH

Padua; practicing physician and director of the orphanage at Venetia and director of the
cholera hospital at S. Alviso. (<em>Nardo</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Museo civico di storia naturale, Venetia (algae).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 538; BM 3: 1392-1393; Bossert p. 281; Cesati p.
284-293, saggio p. 54-55; CSP 4: 569-571, 8:481, 10: 898-899, 12: 532; De Toni 1: xc; Frank
3(Anh.): 70; Kew 4: 109; LS 18773; PR 6612 (ed. 1: 7380); Saccardo 1: 116, 2: 77, 156-157.
Anon., Ber. senckenb. naturf. Ges. 1877-78: 10. 1878; Bonplandia 3: 33. 1855 (Head
	physician of the central orphanage and practicing physician at Venice; cogn. Leopoldi-
	na: Penada).
Behn, W. F. G., Leopoldina 14: 17. 1878.
Gray, S. F., Nat. arr. Brit. pl. 1: 694. 1821 (epon.).
Koster, J. Th., Taxon 18: 555. 1969.
Müller, R. H. W. and R. Zaunick, Friedr. Traug. Kützing 102, 290. 1960.
Pirona, G. A., Atti Ist. Veneto Sci. Lett. Arti 4: 785-850. 1878 (biogr., b. 4 Mar 1802, d. 7
	Apr 1877, bibl.).
Wittrock, V. B., Acta Horti Berg. 3(2): 164. 1903.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Nardoa</em> O. Kuntze (1903), <em>orth. var.</em> of <em>Nardia</em> S. F. Gray (1821, "<em>Nardius</em>", <em>orth.
reg.</em>), corr. Carrington (1870, <em>nom</em>. et <em>orth. cons.</em>). <em>Note</em>: <em>Nardoa</em> Zanardina (1844) is very likely
also named for this author. <em>Narda</em> Vellozo (1825) was named "in memoriam Antonii Nardi
operum Hernandesii Collectoris."

6636. <em>Considerazioni generali sulle alghe</em> loro caratteri, classificazione composizione chimica e
applicazioni alla medicina, all'arti, all'agricoltura ec. seguite da brevi cenni storici sui
progressi dell'algologia e da due articoli riguardanti la formazione degli algari vivi e secchi,
ec. e da un' appendice sulle Alighe lette al veneto ateneo il giorno 3 agosta 1835 da Gio.
Domenico D.r Nardo ... Venezia (dai tipi di Giuseppe Antonelli ...) 1835. Oct. (in fours). (<em>Consid. alg.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Sep-Dec 1835 (read 3 Aug 1835), p. [3]-46, [1, index]. <em>Copies</em>: FH, G. – Title on cover:
	"<em>Delle alghe</em> e dei loro usi nell'agricoltura, nella medicina e nelli arti."

Nascher, Friedrich Wilhelm (1702-1764), fictitious German botanist, stated to have
resided in Havana and to have travelled in South America. (<em>Nascher</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: One of the fictitious botanists listed by Barnhart (J. New York Bot. Gard. 20: 176-
177. 1919) from Appleton's Cyclopaedia of American biography (4: 478-479. 1888). Some
of the equally fictitious book-titles are: "Neueste Geschichte und Beschreibung des Brod-
baums" 1758 (n.b. the bread-fruit tree was first introduced into tropical America in 1793),
"Flora cubana" 2 vols., Leipzig 1758.
Conde, J. A., Historia de la botánica en Cuba 52. 1958 (accepts "Freidrich W. Nascher" as
	having existed and cites his <em>Flora cubana</em>).

Nash, George Valentine (1864-1921), American botanist and horticulturist; at the New
York Botanical Garden from its initiation as collector (1896), curator of plantations (1899)
and head gardener (1900); collected extensively in Florida and the West Indies. (<em>Nash</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: NY (over 11.000); further material in many herbaria (large sets at
K, MICH and US). – <em>Exsiccatae</em>: <em>Plants of Florida</em>, for details see e.g. Stevenson (1971). Sets
at BPI, F, FH, MTMG, ND, NY, RSA.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 538; Blunt p. 257, 258; BM 3: 1393, 7: 895;
Bossert p. 282; CSP 17: 451; Hortus 3: 1200 ("Nash"); IH 2: (in press); Langman p. 535;
Lenley p. 365; LS 37327, suppl. 19674; MW p. 350-351; NW p. 53; Pennell p. 615; PH 164,
450, 937; Rehder 5: 607; TL-2/779, 781; Tucker 1: 511; Urban-Berl. p. 279, 289, 377, 378;
Zander ed. 10, p. 696, ed. 11, p. 794.
Anon., Bot. Soc. Amer., Publ. 82: 105-106. 1922 (obit, notice); Torreya 21: 104, 1921, 22:
	34. 1922.
Barnhart, J. H., J. New York Bot. Gard. 26: 149 (footnote) 1925.

Nathorst, Alfred Gabriel (1850-1921), Swedish palaeobotanist; Dr. phil. Lund 1874;
lecturer at Lund 1874-1879; with the Swedish geological survey 1879-1884; from 1885-
1917 professor and director of the palaeobotanical division of the Naturhistoriska Museum.
(<em>Nath</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: (incl. fossil coll.): S and S-PA; other material at C, CGE, FI, GB,
LD, LY. – Nathorst's correspondence is at the Library of the Royal Academy of Sciences,
Stockholm.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Andrews p. 306-307; Barnhart 2: 539; BJI 2: 42, 2: 122-123;
BL 2: 458, 513, 694; BM 3: 1394-1396, 7: 896-897; Bossert p. 282; Collander hist. p. 86, 87,
94; CSP 8: 482, 10: 900-901, 12: 532-533, 17: 456-458; DSB 9: 617-618; Frank 3(Anh.): 70;
Herder p. 468; IH 2: (in press); Jackson p. 188, 498; Kew 4: 111; Kleppa p. 328; KR p. 519-
530 (main bibl.); Lenley p. 306; LS 37327; Morren ed. 10, p. 103; PH 132; Quenstedt p.
309; Rehder 5: 607; SO 885, 1029, 1030, 1031, 1082, 1083, 1387a, 1410, 1411, 2924; Tucker
1: 511; Zander ed. 10, p. 696, ed. 11, p. 794.
Andersson, G., Ymer, Stockholm 41: 47-55. 1921 (obit.).

	Riksmus.); 41: 191. 1890 (corr. memb. Danz. naturf. Ges.); Bot. Jahrb. 6 (Beibl. 12): 2.
	1885; Bot. Not. 1871: 15(to Spitsb.), 1883: 115; 1884: 138, 1897: 44, 1898: 167 (polar
	exp.), 1912: 148 (Wahlberg medal); 1917: 304 (retirement), 1921: 21 (obit.). 1931: 160

Nattras, Roland Marshall (1895-x), British plant pathology; Univ. Lond. B.Sc. 1921
(<em>Nattras</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: IMI; Kenyan material also in EA.

Naudin, Charles Victor (1815-1899), French botanist and horticulturist; Dr. sci. Paris
1842; botanist at the Muséum d'Histoire naturelle 1845 (aide-naturaliste 1854); owner of a
private experimental garden at Collioure 1869-1878; from 1878 director of the botanical
garden of the Villa Thuret at Antibes; early plant hybridiser. (<em>Naudin</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: material at A, G, K, P.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 390; Barnhart 2: 539; BM 3: 1402; Bossert p. 282;

press); Jackson p. 136; Kew 4: 116; Langman p. 535-536; Lasègue p. 102, 296; Lenley p.

Nawaschin, Sergius Gawrilowitsch [Navashin, Sergei, Gavrilovich] (1857-1930),
Russian botanist (cytologist); lecturer at St. Petersburg 1888-1894; from 1894-1915 direc-
tor of the botanical garden at Kiew; from 1915-1923 at Tiflis; from 1923 at Moscow as head
of the Timiriazev Inst., from 1929 at the Gytological Laboratory of the Academy of
Sciences, Detskoje Selo nr. Leningrad. (<em>Nawaschin</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: LE, inch material from Java; some Russian mosses at B.

512; Urban-Berl. p. 309.

Necker, Noel Joseph de (1730-1793), French-born botanist and historiographer; later
"kurpfälzischer Botaniker" in Mannheim (<em>Neck</em>.).

PAGE: 702
HEADING: NECKER

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. Some mosses perhaps in B-Bridel (fide Sayre 1977).

<sm>NAME</sm> and <sm>NATIONALITY</sm>: Necker was born in Lille on 25 Dec 1730 and baptised Natalis
Martinus Joseph, in French Noël Martin Joseph; sec MD p. ii and E. Leclair Bull. Soc.
Études Prov. Cambrai 10: 184-189. 1897.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 23: 368-376; AG 5(1): 781; Ainsworth p. 32, 65, 312,
345; BM 3: 1406, 7: 905; Bossert p. 283; Dryander 3: 27, 33, 48, 145, 156, 221, 224, 311;

p. 468; Hortus 3: 1200 ("Neck."); IF suppl. 1: 132; Jackson p. 152; Kew; 4: 121; Krempelh.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Neckeria</em> Scopoli (1777, <em>nom. rej.</em>), <em>Neckera</em> J. Hedwig (1801, <em>nom. cons.</em>) and
<em>Neckeriai</em>. F. Gmelin (1791, <em>nom. rej.</em>) very likely commemorate Necker. <em>Note</em>: The following
genera were derived from <em>Neckera</em> J.Hedwig: <em>Metaneckera</em> W. C. Steere (1967); <em>Neckeradel-
phus</em> Lazarenko (1941); <em>Neckeradelphus</em> W. C. Steere (1941) and <em>Neckeropsis</em> Reichardt
(1870). <em>Neckia</em> Korthals (1848) was named in honor of Jacob van Neck (1564-1638) Dutch
admiral who was one of the first to travel to Southeast Asia. <em>Dicneckeria</em> Vellozo (1825) is
dedicated "in memoriam D. Dienecker", whose identity could not be established.

6665. Natalis Josephi de Necker <em>Deliciae gallo-belgicae</em> silvestres, seu tractatus generalis
plantarum gallo-belgicarum ad genera relatarum, cum differentiis specifieis, nominibus
trivialibus, pharmaceuticis, locis natalibus, proprietatibus virtualibus ex observatione,
chemiac legibus, auctoribus praeclaris cum animadversionibus secundum principia linnae-
ana ... Argentorati [Strasbourg] (Venditur apud Jacob. Francisc. Leroux. Bibliop. Ex
prelo Jonae Lorenzii, typographi 1768. Oct. (<em>Delic. gallo-belg.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1768, p. [i]-xxiv, [1]-288, [i], [289]-568, index sign. Nn5-Rr1,2 <em>pl</em>. (uncol.), in 2 vols.
	with consecutive pagination. <em>Copies</em>: G, M; IDC 5145.

PAGE: 703
HEADING: NECKER (1790)

<em>Reissue</em>: 1773, p. [i]-xxiv, [1]-288, [i], [289]-568, index as in orig. ed., <em>2 pl</em>. (id.). <em>Copies</em>: BR,
	FI.
<em>Note</em>: Unlike those in the <em>Elementa</em>, the generic names published in the <em>Deliciae</em> must be taken
into account for botanical nomenclature. A certain number of them are pre-linnaean
names taken up here for the first time, others are orthographic variants of names previously
and validly published by other authors. In general these variants are of no importance.
Necker used here also Linnaean binomials as specific names.

6666. N. J. de Necker ... <em>Methodus muscorum</em> per classes, ordines, genera ac species cum
synonymis, nominibus trivialibus, locis natalibus, observationibus digestorum, aeneisque

	pamphlet is by Remi Willemet (1735-1807) but the text on p. 1-3 (Willemetia hieracioi-

	between 1777 and 1790. Dryander 3: 308 mentions a. <em>plate</em> in addition to the text for
	P. 1-3.

6670. Nat. Jos. de Necker, ... <em>Elementa botanica</em> genera genuina, species naturales omnium
vegetabilium detectorum eorumque characteres diagnosticos ac peculiares exhibentia,
secundum systema omologium seu naturale, evulgata. Cum tabulis separatis tomus primus
[-tertius] Neowedae ad Rhenum [Neuwied] (apud Societatem Typographicam) 1790, 3
vols. (<em>Elem. bot.</em>).

<em>Orig. issue</em>: Apr(?) 1790 (For date see ST p. 74-75). <em>Copies</em>: BR, G(2), M, MO, US; IDC 244.
	<em>1</em>: [i], [iii, frontisp. portr. author], [v]-xxxii, [1]-389.

	<em>3</em>: [i, iii-iv], [1]-456, [457, err.], <em>pl. i-x</em>(as <em>xi</em>), <em>xi-xiii, xiii</em>[<em>bis</em>], <em>xiv, xiv</em>[<em>bis</em>], <em>xv-xli, xli</em>[<em>bis</em>],
	<em>xlii-xlv, xlv</em>[<em>bis</em>], <em>xlv</em>[<em>bis a</em>], <em>lii, lii</em>[<em>bis</em>], <em>liii, liii</em>[<em>bis</em>], <em>liv, liv</em>[<em>bis</em>] (in all <em>63 pl</em>.). (uncol.
	copp.).

	3 vols. – Collation MO copy as above but lacking the plates.

	Jos. de Necker, ... <em>Elementa botanica</em>... evulgata. Tribus voluminibus divisa, cum 63

	burg] apud Amand Koenig 1791." Oct. – For the separate issues of the <em>Corollarium</em> and
	the <em>Phytozool. philos</em>, see below.

PAGE: 704
HEADING: NECKER (1790)

	<em>2</em>: [i], [1]-460.
	<em>3</em>: [i], [1]-456; <em>Corollarium</em> p. [i], [1]-29. [30-31, note]; <em>Phytozool. philos</em>.: [1], [1]-78. [1
	err.]; <em>Plates</em>: <em>i-xi, xi</em>[<em>bis</em>], <em>xii-xli, xli</em>[<em>bis</em>]. <em>xlii-xlv</em>, [<em>xlvbis, ter], xlvi-lii, lii</em>[<em>bis</em>], <em>liii, liii</em>[<em>bis</em>],
	<em>liv-liv</em>[bis] (uncol. copp.).
<em>Editio secunda</em>: 1808. <em>Copy</em>: MO. – "Nat. Jos. de Nccker, ... <em>Elementa bolanica</em>... evulgata.
	Cum tabulis scparatis. Tomus primus [-tertius]. Editio secunda. Moguntiae [Mainz]
	1808. Apud F. Kupferberg." Oct.
	<em>1</em>: [i]-xxxii, [1]-389.
	<em>2</em>: [i-iii], [1]-460.
	<em>3</em>: [i-iii], [1]-456, <em>pl. i-xi, xi</em>[<em>bis</em>], <em>xii-xiii, xiii</em>[<em>bis</em>], <em>xiv-xli, xli</em>[<em>bis</em>], <em>xlii-xlv, xlv</em>[<em>bis</em>], <em>xlvi-lii,
	lii</em>[<em>bis</em>], <em>liii. liii</em>[<em>bis</em>], <em>liv</em>(uncol. copp.).

<em>Note</em>: The original edition was published at the same time as the <em>Corollarium</em> and the
<em>Phytozoologie philosophique</em>. The three publications were sold together but were also obtaina-
ble separately. The nomenclatural status of Necker's <em>species nalurales</em> (in fact genera) is dealt
with by ICBN Art. 20.4(b). Since Necker designated this category as "species," the
monomial names (which are in many cases the generic names of previous authors) are to be
regarded as unitary designations of species and hence to be regarded as not validly
published. For taxonomic purposes Necker's categories have the following equivalents,
however: <em>proles</em> =species, <em>species naluralis</em> = genus, <em>species composila</em> = family or order, <em>genus
genuinus</em> = classis. – For a discussion on the status of these name of "species naturales" see
Mansfeld 1958, Proskauer (1958, 1959), Bullock 1959, Dandy and Ross 1958, ST p. 74-75
and Willmott (1935). – For a critical and enlightening commentary see the review of the
1791 "edition'in GGA 1791: 1644. 13 Oct.
<em>Note</em>: J. E. Dandy prepared a list of Necker's names as used in his <em>Elemenla</em> with their present
nomenclatural equivalents. Copies of this typescript are in various libraries (BM, US,
FAS). The compilers of the <em>Index nominum genericorum</em> (<em>planlarum</em>) (1979) made ample use of
this list which was made available to them for this purpose by its author.

6671. Nat. Jos. de Necker, ... <em>Corollarium</em>ad Philos. botanicam Linnaei spectans, generis,
speciei naturalis &amp;c., vegetabilium omnium detectorum; fructuum diversorum aliarumque
fructificationis partium definitiones expletas, continens, cum tabulis separatis. Neowedae
ad Rhenum (apud Societatem Typographycam [sic]) 1790. Oct. (<em>Corollarium</em>).

<em>Orig. ed</em>.: Apr(?) 1790 (see <em>Elem. bol.</em>) p. [1]-29, [30-31]. <em>Copies</em>: BR, MO, US; IDC 6092.
<em>Neuwied/Strassburg ed</em>.: 1790, p. [1]-29, [30-31]. <em>Copy</em>: G. – "Neowedae ad Rhenum, apud
	Societatem Typographicam) et Argentorati [Strassburg] (apud Amand. König, Biblio-
	polam). 1790. Oct. –Also included in USDA copy <em>of Elem. bol.</em> 1791 ed.
<em>Note</em>: Some of the copies of the <em>Corollarium</em> are accompanied by the <em>63 plates</em> of the <em>Elemenla</em>.

6672. <em>Phytozoologie philosophique</em>, dans laquelle on démontre comment le nombre des genres
&amp; des espèces, concernant les animaux &amp; les végétaux, a été limité &amp; fixé par la nature; avec
les moyens de donner l'histoire la plus complette &amp; la plus parfaite de ces corps organisés
différens, selon la découverte du systême naturel, par Noel Joseph de Necker, ... À
Neuwied sur le Rhin, (chez la Société typographique), et à Strasbourg) chez Amand
König, Libraire) 1790. Oct. (<em>Phytozool. philos.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Apr(?) 1790 (see <em>Elem. bol</em>), frontisp. portr. author, p. [i-iv], [1]-16, [1]-78, [1,
	errata]. <em>Copies</em>: G, M, MO; IDC 245. – The set of pages [1]-16 (with a bibliography of
	Necker on p. 11-16) may also occur in the <em>Elem. bol.</em> The <em>Elemenla bolanica plaies</em> are bound
	with the G copy of the <em>Phytozoologie</em>.

Nectoux, Hipolyte (Hippolyte) (17..-18..), French botanist who accompanied Napoleon
to Egypt. (<em>Nectoux</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Egyptian material at MPU (main set), K and FI. It is possible that
the Nectoux who collected in the Dominican Republic and Haiti in 1788 (material at
MPU; further material at B, E, FI and P) is identical with Hypolyte Nectoux.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 542; BM 3: 1406; Dryander 3: 613; IH 2: (in
press); PR 6639 (ed. 1: 7413); Rehder 2: 342; Tucker 1: 512; Urban-Berl. p. 378.
MacPhail, I., Cat. Redout. 66(no.33). 1963.

PAGE: 705
HEADING: NEES

Steinberg, C. H., Webbia 32(1): 32. 1977.
Urban, I., Symb. ant. 3: 91-92. 1902 (West India Nectoux identical with H. Nectoux?).
Vallot, Bull. Soc. bot. France 29: 185. 1882.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Nectouxia</em> Kunth (1818); <em>Netouxia</em> G. Don (1838, <em>orth. var.</em>).

6673. <em>Voyage dans la Haute Égypte</em>, au dessus des cataractes; avec des observations sur les
diverses espèces de séné qui sont répandues dans le commerce ... à Paris (Chez Garnery,...
Madame Nyon, ... de l'Imprimerie de Didot Jeune) 1808. Qu. (in twos). (<em>Voy. Haute</em>
<em>Égypte</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1808, p. [i*-iv*], [i]-xii, [1]-22, [1, err.], <em>pl. 1-4</em> (<em>3</em> by H. J. Redouté, <em>1</em> by P. J
	Redouté; col. stipple engr.). <em>Copy</em>: G.

Née, Isidore Charles Sigismond (1784-1837), fictitious botanist said to have explored
South America. (<em>XYZZY.</em>)

<sm>NOTE</sm>: One of the fictitious botanists appearing in Appleton's Cyclopaedia of American
Biography (4: 486. 1888). Barnhart (J. New York Bot. Gard. 20: 177. 1919) points out that
the name is obviously compounded from those of Carl Sigismund Kunth (1788-1850) and
Louis Née; the author is stated to have published a <em>Flora mexicana</em> (2 vols., Paris 1827) and
various treatises on mexican hieroglyphs.

Née, Luis (17..-18..), French botanist, later naturalized Spaniard; on the Malaspina
expedition in La Descubierta and La Atrevida, 1789-1794 (<em>Née</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: MA (10.000); duplicates e.g. in B, C, DS, F, FI, KIEL, MPU and
NY.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 5(1): 188; Barnhart 2: 542; Colmeiro 1: cxc; Colmeiro
penins. p. 48-49, 183; CSP 4: 582-583; Hortus 3: 1200 ("Née"); IH 2: (in press); Langman
p. 537; Lasègue p. 348, 451, 505; PR alph.; Rehder 5: 611; SK 1: 382, xxviii, 5: cccvii, 8:
lxviii; Urban-Berl. p. 309; Zander ed. 10, p. 696, ed. 11, p. 794.
Brewer, W. H., <em>in</em> S. Watson, Botany Calif. 2: 553. 1880.
Cavanilles, A. J., Icon. 5: i-iii. 1799.
Granel de Solignac, L. &amp; L. Bertrand, Naturalia Monsp. 18: 276. 1967 (pl. MPU).
Hall, N., Botanists of the Eucalypts 100-101. 1978.

Kühnel, Thad. Haenke 275. index. 1960.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Neea</em> Ruiz et Pavon (1794); <em>Neeaea</em> Poeppig et Endlicher (1838, <em>orth. var.</em>); <em>Neeania</em>
Rafinesque (1814, <em>orth. var.</em>).

Nees von Esenbeck, Christian Gottfried Daniel (1776-1858), German nature-
philosopher, physician and botanist; Dr. med. Giessen, 1800; physician at Sickershausen
1802; president of the "Leopoldina" 1818-1858; professor of botany at Erlangen (1818-
1819), Bonn (1819-1830) and Breslau (1831-1851), formally dismissed 1851. (<em>Nees</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Nees' herbarium which numbered some 80.000 sheets was split up

PAGE: 706
HEADING: NEES

before his death. The "Glumaceae" (Graminae, Cyperaceae, Restionaceae, Juncaceae)
including practically all his types of the <em>Synopsis glumacearum</em> were acquired by B (9559
specimens, now destroyed) in 1855. A number of Nees' Cyperaceae, however, are in the
Lindley herbarium at CGE. The fungi, lichens and hepaticae are at STR. Most of the
Musci were also at B (some preserved in herb. Bridel). A set of 2718 specimens was acquired
by LE followed by a further set in 1857/8. Other lots are at M (phanerogams) and CGE
(grasses, Cyperac. Acanth.), and GZU (Acanth., Bombac., Buettner., Laurac., Piperac.,
Solanac.); L (bryoph., myxophyta, fungi), E (bryoph., fungi), HBG (grasses), GE (some
grasses), PC (hepat.), S (hepat.),W (hepat.),G (bryoph.); further material at BM, BR, K,
PC, PR, TAES, UPS, and WRSL. Some private papers are in the municipal archives of
Wroclaw (formerly Breslau).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: The splitting up of Nees' herbarium and the sale of his library became necessary
because Nees lost his professorship at Breslau in January 1851. The official reason given for
the dismissal was moral turpitude and social misbehaviour ("Beamte welche sich ... durch
wiederträchtige Aufführung verächtlich machen, sollen ihres Amtes entzetzt werden"
Preuss. allg. Landrath 363(20)11). This referred to the circumstance that Nees, who had
obtained a separation but no divorce from his second wife, had lived eleven years in a free
relationship with his third companion. The underlying reason, however, for this belated
and at the time unusual puritanism, must be sought in Nees' public attitude during the
1848-1851 disturbances at Breslau university and especially his activity in the so-called
christ-katholische Bewegung, led by Johannes Ronge and Johann Cserski, a religious
element in the 1848 movement of spiritual and material emancipation of the lesser
privileged. See Wunschmann (in ADB), Winkler (1921) and Proskauer (in DSB) for
reviews of these turbulent affairs.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 23: 368-376; AG 2(1): 113-114, 2(2): 458; Ainsworth
p. 345 [index]; Backer p. 391; Barnhart 2: 542; BM 3: 1407-1408; Bossert p. 283; CSP 4:
583-585, 12: 534; DSB 10: 11-14 (bibl.; many sec. refs.!); De Toni I: xc-xci; DTS 1: 211;
Frank 3(Anh.): 70-71; GR p. 34, <em>pl</em>. [<em>15</em>], cat. p. 68; Hawksworth p. 184, 196; Hegi 5(1): 51;

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Esenbeckia</em> S. E. Bridel (1827); <em>Esenbeckia</em> Kunth (1825); <em>Indoneesiella</em> Sreemadha-
ven (1968); <em>Neesenbeckia</em> Levyns (1947); <em>Neesiella</em> Sehiffner (1893); <em>Neesiella</em> Sreemadhaven
(1967); <em>Neesiochloa</em> Pilger (1940); <em>Neesiocyphus</em> Grolle (1964). <em>Note</em>: <em>Esembeckia</em> J. Barbosa
Rodrigues (1883) is probably an <em>orth. var.</em> of <em>Esenbeckia</em> Kunth. The author of <em>Neesiella</em>
Kirschstein (1935) and <em>Myconeesia</em> Kirsehstein (1936) did not indicate for which Nees von
Esenbeck the genera were named.

6675. <em>Das System der Pilze und Schwämme</em>. Ein Versuch von Dr. C. G. Nees von Esenbeck, ...
Mit 44 nach der Natur ausgemalten Kupfertafeln, uns einige Tabellen. Würzburg (in der
Stahelschen Buchhandlung). 1<sm>816[-181</sm>7]. Qu. (<em>Syst. Pilze</em>).

<em>Orig. ed</em>.: 1816-1817, p. [i-ii; t.p. 1816], engr. t.p. (also dated 1816), [iii]-xxxviii [as
	"xxxvi"], [1-2], [1]-329, [330-331, err.], <em>pl. 1-28, 29a, 29b, 30-36, 36b, 37-44</em> (handcol.
	copp. by J. Sturm. <em>Copies</em>: BR, USDA. – Appeared in three parts of which the contents
	are not known to us. Sheet 42 was at any rate published in 1817. Part 1 of text and plates
	became available between 20 Mar 1816 (preface) and 12 Mai 1816, when Nees sent a
	copy to Goethe (see Schmid no. 1616). Part 3 of the plates contained <em>pl. 28-44.</em>
<em>1817 ed</em>.: 1817 (printed and engr. t.p.'s dated 1817, text on t.p. "mit sechsundvierzig..."), p.
	[i]-xxxviii, [1-2], [1]-334, ["234"], [i, iii], 1-86, [1, err.], <em>pl. 1-28, 29a, 29b, 30-36, 36b, 37</em>-
	<em>44. Copies</em>: G, H, Stevenson, US; IDC 6093. – "Mit sechsundvierzig Kupfertafeln und
	einigen Tabellen. Würzburg (id.) 1817. Qu. – The Stevenson copy has an undated cover
	of the "Dritte und letzte Lieferung" for the plates, indicating that it contained pl.
	"xxviii-xlvi [sic, for xliv]."
<em>Ref</em>.: Schmid, G., Goethe und die Naturwissenschaften 1940, no. 1616.
	Junk, W., Rara 1: 43. 1900-1913.

edendam commendat Chr. Godofred. Nees von Esenbeck ... Erlangae, 1818. Qu. (<em>Syn. Aster. herb.</em>).

6678. <em>De plantis nonnullis e mycetoidearum regno</em> tum nuper detectis, tum minus cognitis

<em>Co-author</em>: Theodor Friedrich Ludwig Nees von Esenbeck (1787-1837).
<em>Publ</em>.:1818 (in journal; reprint presented to Regensb. bot. Ges. 2 Jul 1818), p. [1]-36, <em>pl. 1-2</em>

6679. <em>Handbuch der Botanik</em>. Von Dr. C. G. Nees von Esenbeck ... Nürnberg (bei Johann
Leonhard Schrag) 1820-1821, 2 vols. Oct. (<em>Handb. Bot.</em>).

<em>1</em>: 1820 (Flora rev. 7 Dec 1820), p. [ii*], [i]-xxx, [1]-725, 1 chart.
<em>2</em>: 1821 (p. 691: Mar 1821), p. [ii*], [i]-vi, [1]-691.
<em>Copy</em>: G. – p. [ii*] alternative t.p. "<em>Handbuch der Naturgeschichte</em> zum Gebrauch bei Vorlesun-
gen von Dr. G. H. Schubert. Vierter Theil". Gotthilf Heinrich von Schubert 1780-1860). –
This handbook, dealing extensively with plant morphology from the highly speculative
points of view of the "Naturphilosophie" was dedicated to Goethe and contained an early
elaboration of the poet's "Metamorphosenlehre." Nees' Handbook was severely criticised
later, when experimental and observational botany gained the upper hand, by M. J.
Schleiden in his "Schellings und Hegels Verhältniss zur Wissenschaft," Leipzig 1844 (see
e.g. Fitting 1952).
<em>Ref</em>.: X., Flora 3: 703-714. 7 Dec 1820 (rev. dated Sep 1820, has the first 30 sheets, i.e. 480
	p.).
	Nees v. Esenbeck, C. G., Flora 4: 257-264. 7 Mai 1821 (reply to review by J. B. Wilbrand
	in Jenaer allg. Litt. Z., Int. Bl. 1821(17): 136).

6680. <em>Horae physicae berolinenses</em> collectae ex symbolis virorum doctorum H. Linkii, C. Asm.
Rudolphi et W.Fr. Klugii, professorum berolinensium, C. G. Neesii ab Esenbeck, profes-
soris bonnensis, Fr. Ottonis, Horti botanici regii berolinensis inspectoris, Adalb. a Chamis-
so, philosophiae doctoris, Fr. Hornschuchii, botanices demonstratoris Gryphici, D. a.
Schlechtendal, medicinae doctoris, et C. G. Ehrenbergii, medicinae doctoris. Edi curavit
Dr. Christianus Godof. Nees ab Esenbeck. Cum tabulis aeneis xxvii. Bonnae [Bonn]
(sumtibus Adolphi Marcus) 1820. Fol. (<em>Horae phys, berol</em>.).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1-8 Feb 1820 (fide Nees in Flora 3: 236. 21 Apr 1820), p. [i-xii], [1]-123, [125-128,
	indexes, err.], <em>pl. 1-27</em> (copp., nos. <em>1, 11-13 17-20</em> col., <em>5, 6, 15, 27</em> partly col., others uncol.;
	artists C. G. Ehrenberg, I. Sturm, F. Guimpel, C. Müller). <em>Copies</em>: BR, FI, H, Teyler;
	IDC 6094.

	[1]-7, <em>pl. 1</em>, by Johann Heinrich Friedrich Link (1767-1851) (<em>de Algis aquat</em>.).
	[9]-14, <em>pl 2</em>, by Karl Asmund Rudolphi (1771-1832) (<em>Adnot. helminth.</em>).
	[15]-26, <em>pl. 3-4</em>, by Johann Christoph Friedrich Klug (1775-1856) (<em>Proscopia</em>, insect.).
	[27]-38, by Johann Friedrich Wilhelm Otto (1743-1814) (<em>Pl. rar. hort. Berol.</em>).
	[39-54], <em>pl. 5-11</em>, by C. G. Nees von Esenbeck (<em>Syll. obs. bot.</em>).
	[55]-68, <em>pl. 12-13</em>, by Christian Friedrich Hornschuch (1793-1850) (<em>Musci frond. exot.</em>).
	[69]-76, <em>pl. 14-16</em>, by Ludolf Adelbert von Chamisso (1781-1838) (<em>Pl. Romanyoff.</em>).

Nees von Esenbeck, Theodor Friedrich Ludwig (1787-1837), German botanist;
pharmaceutical assistant at Basel 1811-1816, at Hanau 1816-1817; inspector of the Leiden
botanical garden 1817-1819; Dr. phil. Erlangen 1818; garden inspector and lecturer at
Bonn University 1819; professor of pharmacy ib. (1822 extraord., 1827 ord.), co-director of
the botanic garden 1833; brother of C. G. Nees von Esenbeck. (<em>T. Nees</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BHU (originally in the herbarium of the Naturf. Ges. Rheinl.
Westfalen; see Wirtgen 1907; this herbarium was later transferred to B but ended up in
BHU). Some other material at B, BR and JE.

1408; Bossert p. 283; CSP 4: 585-586, 8: 486, 12: 534; DU 216; Frank 3(Anh.): 71; GR p. 35,
cat. p. 68; Hawksworth p. 184; Herder p. 468 [index]; IH 2: (in press); Jackson p. 115, 162,

6701. <em>Handbuch der medicinisch-pharmaceutischen Botanik</em>. Nach den natürlichen Familien des
Gewächsrciches bearbeitet von Dr. Fr. Ludw. Nees v. Esenbeck und Dr. Carl Heinrich

	(idem). – Even though it is likely (in view of the editor's practice to do so for his authors)
	that the reprints are actually preprints, we have no indication that this was indeed the
	case. We must therefore accept the year of publication of the journal volume as the year
	of publication of this paper.

6704. <em>Genera plantarum florae germanicae</em>iconibus et descriptionibus illustrata ... Bonnae
(sumtibus Henry &amp; Cohen) [1833-]1835-1860. Oct. 31 fasc. (<em>Gen. fl. germ.</em>).

<em>Authors</em>: Th. Nees, fasc. 1-16 (nos. 1-320).
	Frodolin Carl Leopold Spenner (1798-1841), fasc. 17-21 (nos. 321-420).
	Aloys Putterlick (1810-1845), fasc. 22-24 (nos. 421-480).
	Stephan Ladislaus Endlicher (1804-1849) co-author with Putterlick of 22-24.
	Carl Wilhelm Bischof (1825-?), fasc. 26 (nos. 501-520).
	Johann Xaver Robert Caspary (1818-1887), fasc. 27 (nos. 521-540).
	Adalbert Carl Friedrich Hellwig Conrad Schnizlein (1814-1868), fasc. 25, 28, 31 (nos.
	481-500, 541-560, 601-620).
	Dietrich Brandis (1824-1907), fasc. 29, 30 (nos. 561-600).
<em>Publ</em>.: <em>620</em>[NI: <em>622</em>] <em>pl</em>. in 31 parts with an average of 20 plates. The plates were to be bound
	in systematic order in accordance with a new numbering introduced in the <em>Conspecti</em>
	provided with the title pages and other preface matter for six volumes. These six volumes
	are made up of fascicles 1-22 with some additions (<em>8 pl</em>.) from fascicles 23-24. From
	fascicle 23-31 no attempt was made to prescribe a binding which would differ from the
	original order of issue. Our information is obviously incomplete. The only copy bound in
	the order of issue and with the nos 1-24 (undated!) in original covers seen by us is at NY,

PAGE: 715
HEADING: NEGER

	which has a second set bound in the prescribed systematic order. Other copies (seen: B,
	BR, G, MICH, MO, US) show various mixtures of binding.

	tus).

<em>First announcement</em>(by Nees and publishers Henry et Cohen): Flora 15(2) Int. Bl. 10-12. 1832
(dated Mai 1832); fasc. 1 presented to Regensb. bot. Ges. 8 Mai 1833 (<em>pl. 1-20</em>), Flora 16:
302. 1833, reviewed 3: 166-170. 1833. Not all fascicles were announced by Flora: the dates
for parts 1-24, as far as cited below stem from notices in Flora or from dated preface pages.

Neger, Franz Wilhelm (1868-1923), German forest botanist and mycologist; Dr. phil.
München 1892; high school teacher at Weihenstephan 1892-1893; with the Chilean
boundary commission 1893-1897; curator of the herbarium at München 1894-1902;
professor of botany at the forestry college of Eisenach 1902-1905, id. at Tharandt nr.
Dresden 1905-1920; director of the botanical institute and botanical garden of the Tech-
nisch Hochschule, Dresden 1920-1923. (<em>Neger</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Uredinae at B, BR, BRU and C; bryophytes at S, lichens at L,

PAGE: 716
HEADING: NEGER

phanerogams at L, M (r. 1902, 1200, orig.?) and W. – See Sydow, H. et P., <em>Uredineen</em>, fasc.
23a for <em>Uredineae austro-americanae</em>by Neger. The latter also published a series of <em>Forstschädli-
che Pilze</em>, Lief. 1-7, 1916-1920, nos. 1-175.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Bamhart 2: 542; BFM 2608, 3147; BJI 1: 42, 2: 123; BM 3:
1409; Bossert p. 283; CSP 17: 468; Hortus 3: 1200 ("Neger"); IH ed. 2: (in press); Kelly p.
161; Kew 4: 124; KR p. 535; LS 18853-18876, 37351-37373, LS suppl.<sm>19731-19757</sm>;
Moebius p. 364; Rehder 2: 26, 5: 612; Stevenson p. 1252; Tucker 1: 514; Urban-Berl. p. 279,
309, 378.

Neill, Patrick (1776-1851), Scottish publisher and botanist at Edinburgh; founder and
longtime secretary of the Caledonian Horticultural Society and Wernerian Society. (<em>Neill</em>).

Neilreich, August (1803-1871), Austrian botanist; in various positions with Vienna law
courts from 1828-1856, ultimately as Civilgerichtsrath; from 1857 (retirement because of
tuberculosis) devoting himself entirely to botany; Dr. phil. h.c. Wien 1865. (<em>Neilr</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: W; further material at BR and FI. – Library also at W.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 1: 231, 4: 297, 5(2): 419, 12(2): 735; BFM 919, 920, 921;
BM 3: 1410; Bossert p. 284; CSP 4: 588, 8: 487, 12: 535; DTS 1: 211; Frank 3(Anh.): 71;
Futák-Domin p. 414; Hegi 6(1): 18, 205, 6(2): 1294; Herder p. 167, 192; Hortus 3: 1200
("Neilr."); IH 2: (in press); Jackson p. 118, 263, 264; Kanitz p. 146 (no. 235); Kew 4: 126;
Langman p. 538; Maiwald p. 155; PR 6667-6671 (ed. 1: 7449); Rehder 5: 612; Saccardo 2:
126; TL-1/921; TL-2/2270, 3503, see Kanitz, A; Tucker 1: 514; WU 20: 143-146.
Anon., Bot. Not. 1872: 26 (d.); Flora 54: 198, 238. 1871; J. Bot. 9: 288. 1871; Österr. bot. Z.
	11: 24. 1861 (member Leopoldina), 17: 28. 1867, 21: 181-182. 1871 (obit., died of
	tuberculosis, herb. to W, library to Zool.-bot. Ges.); Verh. bot. Ver. Brand. 12: xlvii.
	1870 (d. 1 Jun 1871).

Nelmes, Ernest (1895-1959), British botanist; associated with Kew as gardener, herba-
rium assistant and librarian from 1921-1958; specialist on <em>Carex</em>. (<em>Nelmes</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: K; further material at BH and NY.

Nelson, Aven (1859-1952), American botanist, plant collector and educator at the
University of Wyoming, as professor of biology from 1887; founder of the Rocky Mountain
herbarium (RM); Dr. phil. Denver 1904; president of the University of Wyoming 1917-
1922. (<em>A. Nels.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: RM; duplicates in many herbaria. Nelson issued various irregular
sets of <em>Plants from the Rocky Mountain Herbarium</em>, see e.g. Stevenson (1971).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 544; BJI 1: 162, 164, 223, 310; BM 3: 1410, 7:
908; Bossert p. 284; CSP 17: 478; GR p. 234-235; Hirsch p. 211; Hortus 3: 1200 ("A.
Nels."); IH 2: (in press); Kew 4: 127-128; Langman p. 538; Lenley p. 307; LS 18882, 37374,
suppl. 19779-19780; NAF 28B(2): 348, ser. 2. 5: 250; NW p. 53; Pennell p. 615;. PH 203,
239, 444; Plesch p. 347; Rehder 5: 612; Stevenson p. 1252; TL-2/1253; Tucker 1: 514;
Urban-Berl. p. 279, 309, 378; Zander ed. 10, p. 697, ed. 11. p. 795.
Anon., Amer. men Sci. ed. 1: 232. 1906, ed. 2: 342, 1910, ed. 3: 502. 1921, ed. 5: 818. 1933,
	ed. 6: 1036. 1938, ed. 7: 1292. 1944, ed. 8: 1804, 1949; Laramie Republican 16 Jun 1904
	(Dr. h.c. Denver; portr.; copies: MO, FAS); Science 115: 643. 1952 (d.); Who's who in
	America 1906-1907: 1299.

Nelson, David (x-1789), British gardener, collector and explorer on the voyage of the
"Resolution" and the "Discovery" 1776-1780 (Capt. Cook's third voyage); from 1780-
1787 gardener at Kew; on the "Bounty" 1787-1789; escaped with Bligh from the mutiny
but died on Timor. (<em>D. Nels.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM. – Some Hawaiian material also at MO; further material at E.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 391; Barnhart 2: 544; BB p. 227; Bret. p. 152;
Dawson p. 450, 526, 632, 799, 825, 870, 885; Desmond p. 461; IH 2: (in press); SK 1: 382-
383 (itin.), 5: cccvii, 8: lxviii; TL-2/see J. Cook.
Anderson, A. W., The coming of the flowers 143-149. 1950.
Anon., Gard. Chron. 1881(2): 267.
Bailey, F. P., Proc. R. Soc. Queensland 8(2): 18. 1891.

Nendtvich, Carl Maximilian von Cserkut (Károli Miksa) (1811-1892), Hungarian
botanist, Dr. med. Budapest 1836; connected from 1839(?) with the Joseps-Industrieschule
(later: the Budapest Polytechnic) from 1850 as professor; also connected with Budapest
University. (<em>Nendtv</em>.).

6742. Dissertatio inauguralis historico-naturalis exhibens <em>Enumerationem plantarum in terri-
torio quinque ecclesiensi</em> sponte crescentium praemisso tractatu generali de natura geognostica
montium, deque situ climate et vegetatione ejusdem regionis quam consensu ... conscripsit

fysisk-mathematiska fakultetens vid Kejserl. Alexanders Universitetet i Finland samtycke
och under inseende af William Nylander, ... for licentiatgrad till offentlig granskning
utgifves af Johan Hugo Emmerik Nervander, ... i historisk-filologiska lärosalen den 2 Mars
1859, p.v.t.f.m. Helsingfors (J. C. Frenckell &amp; Son) 1859. Oct. (<em>Bidr. Finl. bryol.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 2 Mar 1859, p. [i]-xvi, [1]-95. <em>Copies</em>: H(2), MO-Steere, NY.

Nessel, Hermann (1877-1949), German botanist and gardener; originally assistant at the

HEADING: NESSEL

Institute for Plant Physiology of Berlin University; subsequently in charge of the University
of Giessen Botanical Garden; specialist on Lycopodiaceac. (<em>Nessel</em>).

Nestler, Chrétien Géofroy [Christian Géofroy] (1778-1832), Alsatian botanist of Ger-
man origin; studied with L. C. Richard at Paris; army pharmacist 1806-1810; from 1813
assistant to Villars; professor of botany and pharmacy at Strasbourg 1817-1832. (<em>Nestl</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: MPU (crypt.; through Roumeguère); further material at BP, E, E-
GL, FI, G-DC, KIEL, PC. – See Mougeot for the <em>Stirpes cryplogamae vogeso-rhenanae</em> (15 fasc.,
index, Bruyères 1810-1860).

<sm>NAME</sm>: Margadant (MD p. 191) checked the christian names (Chrétien Géofroy, sic) in the
Archives of the Département du Bas-Rhin at Strasbourg. The names are usually given in
German (Christian Gottfried).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 6(1): 780, 12(1): 212; Barnhart 2: 545; BM 3: 1412;
CSP 4: 590; DTS 1: 212; Frank 3(Anh.): 71; GR p. 291, cat. p. 68; Hawksworth p. 184; Hegi
4(2): 865, 5(2): 1348, 6(2): 1222; Herder p. 156, 342; Hortus 3: 1200 ("Nestl."); IH 2: (in
press); Jackson p. 141; Kew 4: 129; Langman p. 539; Lasègue p. 289; MD p. 191; Moebius
p. 282; Nordstedt p. 35; PR 6674-6676 (ed. 1: 7434-7436); Rehder 1: 45, 5: 613; RS p. 121;
SBC p. 128; Stevenson p. 1252; TL-1/922; TL-2/see J. E. Duby; Tucker 1: 514; Urban-Berl.
p. 262, 309; Zander ed. 10, p. 697; ed. 11, p. 795.
Anon., Ann. Chém. Phys. Paris 52: 221. 1833; Flora 15: 671. 1832 (d. 2 Oct 1832).

6745. <em>Monographia de Potentilla</em> praemissis nonnullis observationibus circa familiam rosa-
cearum, auctore C. G. Nestler, ... Parisiis et Argentorati [Paris, Strasbourg] (apud
Treuttel et Wurtz, typis Didot Jun ...) 1816. Qu. (<em>Monogr. Potentilla</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Jun 1816, p. [i*], [i]-iv, [5]-80, chart, <em>pl. 1, I bis, 2-11</em> (uncol.; L. G. Richard, Poiteau,
	de Straus). <em>Copies</em>: BR, FI, G, H, L, MICH, MO, USDA; IDC 5482.

PAGE: 729
HEADING: NETTO

<em>Thesis issue</em>: Jun 1816, p. [i]-iv, [5]-91, <em>pl. 1, I bis, 2-8. Copies</em>: HU, P (Bibl. Centr.). –
	"<em>Commentatio botanico-medica de Potentilla</em>, necnon de plantis huicce generi affinibus et in
	usum medicum tractis, quam pro gradu doctoris medicinae rite obtinendo inclytae
	Faculta tis medicae Parisiensis examini submittit et die sexto mensis junii tueri conabitur,
	C. G. Nestler ..." Parisiis (ex typis Didot junioris, ...) 1816. Qu. – We have no
	information indicating that the regular issue (<em>Monogr. Potentilla</em>) was either earlier or
	later than the thesis issue (defended on 6 Jun 1816; published on that day or possibly
	earlier?).

Newberry, John Strong (1822-1892), American botanist and palaeontologist; trained as
a physician at Western Reserve College and Cleveland Medical College (M.D. 1848); in
Paris 1849-1850; practicing medicine in Cleveland 1851-1855; surgeon and geologist on
various transcontinental exploring expeditions into the American West; professor of Geolo-
gy at Columbia College 1866-1892; LL.D.h.c. Columbia 1867; chief geologist to the
Geological Survey of Ohio 1869-1872. (<em>Newb</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: <sm>U</sm>S; further material in F, K and NY (Ives exp.). Palaeobotanical
material at NY (incl. leaf collection; largest set), and US (inf. K. Niklas). Some fossils are
also in the Ohio State Geological Museum, Columbus, Ohio. – NY has a mss. Plants of
Summit Co., Ohio (inf. R. Stuckey, P. K. Holmgren).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Andrews p. 308-309; Barnhart 2: 548; BJI 1: 43; BM 3:
1426-1427; Bossert p. 285; CSP 4: 597-598, 8: 492-493, 10: 915-916, 12: 537, 17: 502-503;
De Toni 2: lxxxv; Herder p. 225; Hortus 3: 1200 ("Newb."); IH 2: (in press); Kew 4: 136;
Lenley p. 313-314; Langman p. 539; ME 1: 214, 3: 630; Merrill p. 480, 541, 707; Morren ed.
10, p. 127; Pennell p. 544; PH p. 506 [index]; Quenstedt p. 312; Rehder 5: 617; TL-1/139;
TL-2/516, see Hollick, C. A.; Tucker 1: 517-518.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Newberrya</em> Torrey (1864).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: It is not possible to give here even an approximately complete list of the publications
on and by Newberry. Reference is made to the biography by N. L. Britton (1893), to the

PAGE: 734
HEADING: NEWBERRY

study by Waller (1943), as well as to CSP 17: 502 and to White (1909) for bibliographical
references.
A. G., Nature 47: 276-277. 1893 (obit.).
Andrews, H. N., The fossil hunters 192-196. 1980.
Anon., Bot. Centralbl.53: 128, 272. 1893 (d.); Bot. Not. 1893: 39; Engin. mining J. 17 Dec
	1892 (portr.); J. New York Bot. Gard. 2: 151. 1901 (coll. of fossil plants was begun by
	Newberry at Columbia, transferred to NY on 3 Mai 1901), 3: 27. 1902, 9: 214-216. 1908;
	Nat. Nov. 15: 51. 1893 (d.).
Armstrong, C., Ohio Natural. 1(8): 36-37. 1901.
Barnhart, J. H., Mem. Torrey bot. Club 17: 16-17. 1918 (on N. as president of the Torrey
	bot. Club).

Cantab 1842; Curate Bluntisham, Hunts, 1845; id. Camberton, Cambr. 1846; later living

6779. <em>A compleat herbal</em> of the late James Newton, M. D. containing the prints and the
English names of several thousand trees, plants, shrubs, flowers, exotics, &amp;c. All curiously
engraved on copper-plates. London (printed by E. Cave at St. John's Gate; and sold by Mr.
Watson, ...) 1752. (<em>Compl. herbal</em>).

<em>Ed. 1</em>: 1752, posthumously, by the author's son; <em>pl. 1</em> = portr. of author as frontisp., p. [i -
	xix], <em>pl. 2-176</em> (uncol. copp.). <em>Copies</em>: L, USDA. – Further copies et BM-Bloomsb., BM
	and Roy. Hort. Soc. (fide Henrey).
<em>Ed. 2</em>: 1798, p. [i-xvii], <em>pl. 1-176</em> (incl. frontisp. portr. author). <em>Copy</em>: G.–A simple re-issue. –
	"... exotics, &amp;c. Many of which are not to be found in the herbals of either Gerard,
	Johnson or Parkinson. Curiously engraved on 176 copper-plates. A new editon."
	London (printed for Lackington, Allen, &amp; Co. ...) 1798.
<em>Ed. 6</em>: 1802, p. [i-xvii], <em>pl. 1-176</em> (id.). <em>Copies</em>: BM-Bloomsb., BM (fide Henrey).
<em>New ed</em>.: 1805, p. [i-xvi], <em>pl. 1-176</em> (id.). <em>Copy</em>: BR. – London (Printed by J. D. Dewick, ... for
	Lackington, Allen and Co. ... 1805.
<em>A new herbal</em>: 1808, 257 p., n.v.
The second and third "editons" are simple re-issues of the pre-linnaean original and are
therefore not to be taken into consideration for purposes of nomenclature. For further
details see Henrey.

1925; Ph. D. Bristol 1925. (<em>L. Newton</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

Nicholls, William Henrey (1885-1951), Australian bookbinder, orchidologist, propaga-
tor and gardener at the Footscray (Melbourne) municipal gardens. (<em>Nicholls</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: MEL.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Hortus 3: 1200 ("Nicholls"); IH 2: (in press); Kew 4: 141.
Stafleu, F. A., Taxon 19: 639-640. 1970.

PAGE: 740
HEADING: NICHOLLS

Willis, J. H., Vict. Natural. 66: 104. 1949, 67:24.1-242. 1951 (obit., portr., b. 23 Jul 1885, d.
	10 Mar 1951).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: N. contributed nearly a hundred orchidologieal papers to the <em>Victorian Naturalist</em> and
other journals. He started an iconography of Australian orchids in 1923. Publication of his
<em>Orchids of Australia</em> (in 20 parts of 24 plates each) was started at Melbourne in 1951 but the
book ran only to four such parts (1951-1958) and was then discontinued for lack of sales.
The full set of 476 water-colours was published on 26 November 1969 in a single volume
<em>Orchids of Australia</em> (see Stafleu 1970 and HR).

Nichols, George Elwood (1882-1939), American bryologist and ecologist; Dr. phil. Yale
1909; with Yale from 1904 as assistant, instructor (1909), ass. professor (1915), assoc.
professor (1924), Eaton professor of botany 1926-1939. (<em>Nichols</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: YU: much material also at MICH.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 2; BM 7: 922; Bossert p. 286; GR p. 235; Hirsch

Nicotra, Leopoldo (1846-1940), Italian physician and botanist, professor of botany and
curator of the botanical garden of Sassari 1892-1900; professor of botany at Messina 1900-

6797. <em>Sislema fondamentale della botanica</em>. Esposto per servire ai corsi d'istruzione superiore ...

<em>Publ</em>.: Jan-Feb 1908 (Nat. Nov. Mar(2) 1908), p. [i]-viii, [1]-319, [1, err.], <em>2 pl</em>.

Niebuhr, Carsten (1733-1815), Holstein-born Danish botanist; studied in Göttingen
1757-1761; with Forsskål on a Danish expedition to Arabia 1761-1763, India, Persia and
Turkey 1763-1767; in Copenhagen until 1778; subsequently administrator at Ditmarsken,
ultimately at Melsdorf. (<em>Niebuhr</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: The plants on the Expedition to Arabia were collected by Forsskål
(q.v.) and are at C.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 395; Barnhart 3: 4; BM 3: 1433; Bossert p. 286;
CSP 4: 620; DSB 10: 117; Herder p. 55; KR p. 539; Lasègue p. 426; NI (alph.); PR (ed. 1:
7496); Rehder 5: 619; TL-1/370-371; TL-2/1819-1820; Tucker 1: 519.
Blatter, E., Rec. bot. Surv. India 8: 460-461. 1933.
Christensen, C., Naturforskeren Pehr Forsskål 121-122, 145-146, 162-163. 1918 (letters N.
	to Forsskål.); Danske bot. hist. 1: 120, 122, 152. 1924, 2: 91-92. 1924.
Embacher, F., Lexikon Reisen 217. 1882.
Fischer-Benzon, R. J. D. von, <em>in</em> P. Prahl, Krit. Fl. Schleswig-Holst. 2: 39-40. 1890.
Fries, Th. M., Bref Skrifv. Linné 1(2): 270. 1908.
Hansen, T., Det lykkelige Arabien, en dansk ekspedition 1761-1767. Gyldendal, Kjøbn-
	havn 1962, re-issued 1976, 381 p.
Hornemann, J., Nat. Tidskr. 1: 573-574. 1837.
Hulth, J. M., Bref Skrifv. Linné 2(1): 427 [index]. 1916.
Jessen, K. F. W., Bot. Gegenw. Vorz. 300. 1884.
Niebuhr, B. G., Kieler Blätter 3: 1-86. 1816 (fide Spjeldnaes in DSB); Beschreibung von
	Arabien, Kopenhagen 1772 (for translations of and additional travelogues by N. see BM
	3: 1433); Reisebeschreibung nach Arabien, Kopenhagen 1774-1778, Hamburg 1837, 3
	vols., reprint with introduction by D. Henze, Graz 1968, ISBN 3-201-00201-1; Beschrei-
	bung von Arabien, Kopenhagen 1772, reprint with introduction by D. Henze, Graz,
	1969, ISBN 3-201-00200-3.

	1815).

Wittrock, V. B., Acta Horti Berg. 3(2): 103. 1903.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Nicbuhr edited P. Forsskål's <em>Flora aegyptiaco-arabica</em> (TL-2/1819) and
<em>Icones rerum naturalium</em>(TL-2/1820).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Niebuhria</em>A. P. de Candolle (1824), <em>Niebuhria</em>Necker ex J. Britton (1901) and
<em>Niebuhria</em>Scopoli (1777) were probably all named for this author.

Niedenzu, Franz Josef (1857-1937), German botanist; Dr. phil. Breslau 1889; assistant
at the Botanical Garden, Breslau 1886-1889; id. Berlin-Dahlem 1889-1892; professor of
mathematics and natural history at the Braunsberg (E. Prussia) Lyceum Hosianum 1892-
1926; Geh. Regierungsrat 1913. (<em>Nied</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B. – Duplicates at NY (reference collection, incl. fragments of types).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 395; Barnhart 3: 4; BFM 8; BJI 1: 43, 2: 124; BM
3; 1433-1434, 7: 924-925; Bossert p. 286; CSP 17: 524; Hirsch p. 214; Hortus 3: 1200
("Niedenzu"); IH 2: (in press); Kew 4: 144; Langman p. 540-541; LS 18936; MW p. 355;
Rehder 5: 619; TL-2/1711, 1713, 1949; Tucker 1: 519; Zander ed. 10, p. 697, ed. 11, p. 795;
Zep.-Tim. p. 88.

HEADING: NIEDENZU

(b) <em>Tamaricaceae</em>, 21: 282-289. 1925.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Niedenzua</em> Pax (1894).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Niedenzu was a longtime professor at the Braunsberg <em>Lyceum Hosianum</em>, a roman
catholic college for theology and philosophy, educating clergymen for E. Prussia. The
college went back to a seminary founded 1579 by bishop Stanislaus Hosius. Niedenzu
founded its botanical garden in 1893 and was Rector of this Lyceum (later Staatliche
Akademie zu Braunsberg) 1902-1905, 1920-1923, and retired in 1926.

Niessl von Mayendorf, Gustav (1839-1919), Austrian naturalist and botanist; 1857-
1865 geometrist at Wien; from 1865-1906 professor of geodesy and astronomy at the
University of Brno (Brünn); from 1906 again in Wien. (<em>Niessl</em>).

Nieuwland, Julius [Aloysius] Arthur, C. S. C. (1878-1936), Belgian-born American
botanist, chemist and roman catholic priest; studied at Notre Dame and Catholic Universi-
ty (Washington), (Dr. phil. 1904); ordained 1903 (congr. Holy Cross), Dr. Sci. Notre
Dame 1911; teaching at that University from 1904-1920. (<em>Nieuwl</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: ND (Nieuwland herbarium); further material at MO, MT, NY,
US.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 5; Bossert p. 287; Hawksworth p. 184; Hortus 3:

128; SO 496b; Tucker 1: 520; Zander ed. 10, p. 697, ed. 11, p. 795.
Anon., Amer. men sci. ed. 2: 346. 1910, ed.3: 508. 1921, ed.5: 827. 1933; Amer. Midl.
	Natural. 17(4): ii-x. 1936 (bibl., portr.); Fern J. 26(3): 110. 29 Oct 1936.

	Notre Dame, Ind. 1937.
Crovello, T. J., Amer. Midl. Natural. 100(2): 257-260. 1978 (portr., vol. dedicated to N on

<sm>NAME</sm>: Aloysius was a name taken at confirmation but never used by N; Julius was his
baptismal name; Arthur his preferred name (see Barnhart 3: 5). – C. S. C. stands for
Congregation of the Holy Cross.

["Midland Naturalist"], 2 [Amer. Midl. Natural.]-15, 1909-1934.

Nilsson, Lars Albert (called himself Albert) (1860-1906), Swedish botanist; Dr. phil.
Uppsala 1888; curator of the Brazilian collections at S 1889-1890; lecturer at the Stockholm

(1886) and professor (1902) of botany at Lund; from 1889 connected with Svalöv experi-

6844. <em>Se Virgilio ha veramente descritto il limone</em> o Citrus Medica de' botanici nel libro secondo

Noë, Friedrich Wilhelm (18..-1858), German botanist and pharmacist in Fiume (1831-
1844); director of the botanical garden in Constantinople; participated in the boundary
Commission of Turkey and Persia. (<em>Noë</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Plants from the Near East and the Balkan Peninsula in many
herbaria; important set at G; plants from Dalmatia in PAD, GOET and OXF.

Noehden, Heinrich Adolph [August] (1775-1804), German botanist at Göttingen.

London 3: 1-19. 1822) and contributed to Sowerby and Smith, English botany.

Nördlinger, Herman [von] (1818-1897), German forestry botanist; studied at Tübingen
1838-1840; studied forestry in Hohenheim 1841, Bebenhausen 1841-1842, Stuttgart 1842
and Nancy 1842-1843; professor of forestry at Grand-Jouan, Loire-inf. 1843-1845, at
Hohenheim 1845-1852; after 1855 at Hohenheim and Tübingen as administrator and
professor. (<em>Nördl</em>.)

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. – N published <em>Querschnitte von Holzarten</em>, 11 vols.,
Stuttgart 1856-1888, 1100 plates (actually sections of wood) in boxes. Set at HH. (See e.g.
C. Sanio, Bot. Centralbl. 39: 153-159. 1889, abstract vol. 11).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 10; BM 3: 1440; CSP 4: 640; Herder p. 381, 392,
432; Hortus 3: 1200 ("Noerdl."); Jackson p. 207, 299; Kew 4: 154; LS 2: 19060; Moebius p.
398; Morren ed. 10, p. 21; NI 1449; PR 6730-6731; Ratzeburg p. 379-380; Rehder 5: 622-
623; Tucker 1: 521.
Anon., Bot. Centrabl. 69: 416. 1897 (d.); Bot. Jahrb. 23 (Beibl. 57): 60. 1897 (d.); Bot. Not.

Noll, Fritz (1858-1908), German botanist; Dr. phil. Heidelberg 1883 (with Pfitzer),
assistant Heidelberg 1882-1886; assistant with J. Sachs at Würzburg 1887-1889; assistant
and lecturer with Strasburger at Bonn 1889-1894; lecturer and professor (1897, 1898) of
botany at the agriculture college of Poppelsdorf 1894-1908; professor of botany at Halle
1907-1908; prominent plant physiologist. (<em>Noll</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Not te be confused with [his father?] the Frankfurt naturalist (mainly zoologist)
Friedrich Carl Noll 1832-1893 who published e.g. a short treatise on plants from the Rhine
valley, and, the treatment of <em>Das Pflanzenreich</em> in Schilling, <em>Grundriss Naturgeschichte der drei
Reiche, ed.</em>14, 1884, 287 p. (Ausgabe A, Linn. Syst.) and 314p. Ausg. B, nat. Syst.), ed. 15,
1895.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 10; BM 3: 1441; CSP 17: 554-555; De Toni 1:
xci, 4: xlii; Kew 4: 155; Moebius p. 454 [index]; Morren ed. 10, p. 25; NI (alph.); Rehder 5:
624; Tucker 1: 522.
Anon., Bot. Centralbl. 32: 255. 1887 (habil. Würzburg), 40: 40, 304. 1889 (lecturer Bonn),
	69: 416. 1897 (extra ord. prof), 74: 96. 1898 (ord. prof. bot. Poppelsdorf), 105: 160. 1907
	(to Halle), 108: 160. 1908 (d.); Bot. Jahrb. 23 (Beibl. 57): 60. 1897, 25 (Beibl. 60): 55, 40
	(Beibl. 92): 46. 1908, 43 (Beibl. 98): 57. 1909; Nat. Nov. 11: 535. 1889 (habil. Bonn), 19:
	55. 1897 (Titularprofessor"), 20: 241. 1897 (regular professor), 29: 385. 1907 (to Halle),
	30:389. 1908 (d.); Österr. bot. Z. 39: 420. 1889 (appointment Bonn [not as professor but
	as Privatdozent or lecturer]; 58: 327. 1908 (d.); Torreya 8(8): 207. 1908.

Noll, Henry R. (fl. 1852), American botanist (<em>H. Noll</em>).

6853. <em>Flora of Pennsylvania</em>,and botanist's pocket manual, comprising a glossary of botani-
cal terms, analytical tables, and the natural orders, illustrated by a flora of Pennsylvania,
which embraces descriptions of more than nine-tenths of the indigenous flowering plants of
the northern United States ... Philadelphia (Lippincott, Grambo, and Company) Lewis-

6854. <em>The botanical class-book</em> and flora of Pennsylvania, designed for seminaries of learning
and private classes. in two parts. Part i. – Structural and physiological botany. Part ii. –

Nolte, Ernst Ferdinand (1791-1875), German botanist; Dr. med. Göttingen 1817; in
Denmark with Hornemann 1824-1826; professor of botany at Kiel University from 1826-
1873; Dr. h.c. Kiel 1867.(<em>Nolle</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: KIEL (destroyed); in part also at BM; other material at B, C, Fl,
HAL, KIEL, MW, WRSL. <em>Exsiccatae</em>: see Hansen, L., <em>Herbarium der Schleswig-Holstein-
Lauenburgischen Flora</em>, 1823-1862, identifications by Nolte. – Manuscripts at KIEL, see
Prahl (1895). Further manuscripts and letters to e.g. Hornemann (213), Schouw (45), J.
Vahl (12), J. Lange (3) are at C. – Library dispersed.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 1: 299; BM 3: 1441; Frank 3 (Anh.): 72; Herder p. 186,
284; Jackson p. 305; Kew 4: 155; MD p. 192; Morren ed. 2, p. 7; PR 6734-6735 (ed. 1: 7562-
7563); Rehder 5: 624; TL-2/see Flüggé, J., see Hansen, L.; Urban-Berl. p.267.
Anon., Bot. Not. 1876: 29 (d. 15 Feb 1875 [probably incorrect]); Bot. Zeit. 33: 128, 312.
	1875 (death; herb. for sale); Flora 58: 96, 192. 1875 (id.); Bull. Soc. bot. France 22

Nonne, Johann Philipp (1729-1772), German botanist at Erfurt. (<em>Nonne</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

Frank 3(Anh.): 72; Hegi 5(3): 2205; Kew 4: 156; LS 37464; PR 6737-6738 (ed. 1: 7564-

Zuchold, E. A., Jahresb. nat. Ver. Halle 5: 44. 1853.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Nonea</em> [sic] Medikus (1789) was probably named for him. <em>Nonnea</em> H. G. L.
Reichenbach (1831, <em>orth. var</em>.).

	a follow-up by Planer of Nonne's <em>Flora</em> of 1763.

Nordenskiöld, [Nils] Adolph Erik [von] (1832-1901), Finnish-born Swedish explorer,
geographer and geologist; e.g. leader of the Vega-Expedition (1878-1880) which discover-
ed the Northeastern passage around N. Asia (<em>Nordenskiöld</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: The plants on the Vega-Expedition were mostly collected by the
other members of the Vega party (Sven Berggren, 1837-1917; Frans Reinhold Kjellmann,
1846-1907). Some bryophytes collected by N are at H; other material is at K; his plant
fossils are at S-PA. The manuscripts and letters are at the Royal Swedish Academy of
Sciences, some letters in Helsinki University Library.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BM 3: 1442-1443 (q.v. e.g. for travelogues and geological
publications), 7: 933; Kleppa p. 290; Nordstedt p. 24; Saelan p. 343-344; TL-2/3695, see F.
R. Kjellmann.
Andrews, H. N., The fossil hunters 264-266. 1980.

PAGE: 766
HEADING: NORDENSKÖLD

6859. <em>Den andra Dicksonska expeditionen till Grönland</em>dess inre isöken och dess ost-kust utförd
år 1883 under befäl af A. E. Nordenskiöld. Stockholm (F. &amp; G. Beijers Förlag) [1885]. Oct. (<em>Andr. Dicks. exped</em>.).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1885, p. [i]-xi, [1]-546, 5 maps. <em>Copy</em>: FI. – Botany on p. 183-184, 191-192, 195, 264-

<em>Note</em>: Nordenskiöld's main description of the Vega Expedition, <em>Vega färd kring Asien och
	Europa</em>,Stockholm 1880-1881, 2 vols, also contains many botanical notes; for a list see
	Saelan p. 343. For bibl. details see Hulth 1902.

Nordhagen, Rolf (1894-1979), Norwegian botanist, especially geobotanist; Dr. phil. Oslo
1922; assistant at the Oslo botanic garden 1915-1920; at Oslo university 1920-1925;
professor of botany Bergen 1925-1946; idem at Oslo 1946-1964. (<em>Nordh</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BG and O; further material at C.

Nordmann, Alexander [Davidovic] von (1803-1866), Finnish botanist; Dr. phil. Turku
1827; high school teacher and director of the botanic garden at Odessa; professor of natural
history (1849) and of zoology (1852) in Helsinki. (<em>Nordm</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: LE; further important sets at GOET, H and MW.

p. 379.

	Helsinki.

Nordstedt, Carl Fredrik Otto ["Otto"] (1838-1924), Swedish phycologist of indepen-
dent means; med. fil. kand. Lund 1861; amanuensis at the Lund botanical institute 1878-
1886; curator at id. 1886-1909; Dr. phil. h.c. Lund 1881; Prof. id. 1903. (<em>Nordst</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: LD; important collections also at S; further material at B, BP, BR,
C, F, FI, GB, H (Bryoph.), L, LD, MANCH, MPU, MW, PI, S, WELT, WRSL. –
<em>Exsiccatae</em>: (1) with Lars Johan Wahlstedt (1836-1917): <em>Characeae scandinaviae exisiccatae</em> fasc.
1-3, nos. 1-120, 1871-1874, sets at B, BM, C, CGE, FH, H, K, L, LD, LE, MPU, NY, O,
OXF, S, W. (Bot. Not. 1871: 37, 1872: 29, 1874: 42; see Sayre 1969). (2) with Wittrock, V.
B., (q.v.) and G. Lagerheim, <em>Algae aquae dulcis exsiccatae</em>, fasc. 1-35, 1877-1903.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BL 2: 513, 553, 696; BM 3: 1446, 7: 936; Bossert p. 289;
Cesati, saggio p. 56-57; Clokie p. 218; CSP 8: 515-516, 10:938, 12: 540-541, 17: 559-560; De
Toni 1: xci-xciii, 4: xlii, lx; DTS 1: 213, xxii; Herder p. 469; IH 1 (ed. 6): 362, 2: (in press);
Jackson p. 335; Kew 4: 158; Kleppa p. 328 [index]; KR p. 547-552 (main bibl.); Lenley p.
315; LS 2: 19082; Morren ed. 2, p. 31, ed. 10, p. 105; MW p. 358; NAF 11(1) 91, ser. 2. 3: 40,
6: 71, 8: 49; Nordstedt p. 24-25, suppl. p. 12; PR 6740; Rehder 5: 624-625; Saccardo 1: 118:
SO 223, 2787a, 3505, 3515; TL-2/202, 717, 1705, see Elfving, F. E. V., Gomont, M. A.,
Hauck, F.; TR 955; Urban-Berl. p. 267, 272, 280.

<sm>MEMORIAL ISSUE</sm>: The Jubileumsskrift of <em>Botaniska Notiser</em> 1933 (Häfte 1-3) was dedicated to
the memory of Nordstedt; and it contains four papers on Nordstedt (Simmons, Gertz,
Hintze, Hasslow).

<em>Collector</em>: Sven Berggren (1837-1917).

	Sällsk.: Hedwigia Nov 1878), p. [i], [1]-24, <em>pl. 1-2</em> (with text; uncol. liths. auct.). <em>Copies</em>:
	BR, FH, H, NY. – Preprinted or reprinted from Minneskr. Lund, Fysiogr. Sällsk. 3 Oct
	1878, no. 7.

<em>Publ</em>.: 1909, p. [1]-2. <em>Copy</em>: FAS. – Proposal to accept as starting points for the nomenclature
	of Desmidiaceae: Ralfs 1848, and for Oedogoniaceae: Hirn 1900 (as now incorporated in
	ICBN 13. 1(g).).

6871. <em>Förteckning öfver Skandinaviens växter</em> utgifven af Lunds botaniska Förening. 3. <em>Alger</em>.
(Tryckt som manuskript). Lund (C. W. K. Gleerup) 1912. Oct. (<em>Fört. Skand. växt., Alger</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1912, p. [1]-77, [78, err.]. <em>Copies</em>: FAS, LD. – Note by O. Almborn: Manuscript
	delivered by N. to Lund botanical Society on 13 Apr 1912 (minutes council society);
	1000 copies were ordered to be printed (id. 27 Apr 1912). Tryckt som manuskript
	("printed as manuscript") means that the author did not definitely accept the nomencla-
	ture used. This would mean that new combinations and changes of rank are not validly
	published. [This would also explain the fact that Nordstedt's name is not mentioned in
	the publication itself, F. A. S.]. Copies of the book were still available from the Botanical
	Museum, Lund Dec 1979.

6872. <em>Prima loca plantarum suecicarum</em> första litteraturuppgift om de i Sverige funna vilda
eller fövildade kärlväxterna ... Lund (Berlingska Boktryckeriet) 1920. Oct. (<em>Prima loca pl.
suec</em>.).

<em>Publ</em>.: 7 Dec 1920 (as supplement to Bot. Not. 1920), p. [i]-iv. 1-95. <em>Copies</em>: BR, MO, NY. –
	Addenda, Bot. Not. 1921: 282.

Norman, George (1824-1882), British diatomologist and entomologist in Yorkshire. (<em>G.

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: AWH and BM (155 slides); letters in Walker-Arnott corr. at BM.

Noroña, Francisco (Noronha, François; also err. Fernando) (ca. 1748-1788), Spanish
physician and botanist who travelled to the Philippines and Java 1786-1787. (<em>Noroña</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: G, P. – For Noroña's drawings, <em>Icones plantarum javanicarum</em>, at the

literature: SK 1: 387-389.

Norrlin, Johan Petter [Peter] (1842-1917), Finnish botanist; Dr. phil. Helsinki 1879,
lecturer (1871) and professor (1879) of botany at Helsinki University until 1903; in Algeria
1877-1878; taxonomist (<em>Hieracium</em>; lichens) and phytogeographer ("father of Finnish
phytogeography"). (<em>Norrl</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: H. – <em>Exsiccatae</em> (see Collander p. 644-645 and Sayre (1969)):
(1) <em>Herbarium pilosellarum fenniae</em>, fasc. 1-2, nos. 1-200, 1884-1894, sets at B, H, P, WRSL.
(2) <em>Hieracia exsiccata</em>, fasc. 1-13, 1888-1912. Set at H.
(3) With William Nylander (1822-1899), <em>Herbarium lichenum fenniae</em>, fasc. 1-9, nos. 1-450,
1875-1882, sets at B, BM, C, FH, FR, G, H, HSI, LD, LE, M, MOD, MTMG, O, PC, S,
TUR, W, WU. – Continued by K. Linkola (1888-1942) and Edvard Vainio (1858-1929),
nos. 451-807, 1924, see under Vainio.
Manuscripts: 134 letters to Nylander at H; further mss. also at H.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 14; BJI 2: 125; BL 2: 74, 75, 95, 96, 696; BM 3:
1447, 7: 937; Bossert p. 289; Collander p. 374-375 (further biogr. refs), 644-645 (exsicc.),
hist. p. 156(ind.);CSP 8: 517, 10: 939, 17: 563; GR p. 611, <em>pl</em>.[<em>41</em>], cat. p. 69; Hawksworth
p. 185; Herder p. 469; IH 1 (ed. 6): 362, 2: (in press); Jackson p. 329; KR p. 556; LS 19104-
19108, suppl. 20219; Morren ed. 10, p. 97; Saelan p. 348-352, 576-577; SBC p. 128; TR 957-
963; Urban-Berl. p. 289, 379.

	(stipendium for travel), 1880: 29 (extraord. prof. bot. Dec. 1879), 1917: 35 (b 6 Sep
	1842, d. 17 Jan 1917); Generalreg. Bot. Not. 1839-1938 p. 110-111. 1939.

Norton, John Bitting Smith (1872-1966), American botanist, mycologist, pathologist
and horticulturalist; B.S. and M.S. Kansas State College of Agriculture (now Kansas State
University), Manhattan (1896, 1900) under the direction of A. S. Hitchcock, assistant
professor at Kansas State (1894-1896); botanical assistant, Missouri Botanical Garden

PAGE: 776
HEADING: NORTON

(1896-1901): professor of botany, Maryland Agricultural College (now University of
Maryland), College Park (1901-1942); professor emeritus (1942-1966). (<em>Norton</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: KSC (1896-1901), MO (1896-1901), MARY (1901-1946); further
material, especially Poaceae, at US, general material at US-DC.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 14, Bossert p. 289; CSP 17: 565; Hirsch p. 216;
Hortus 3: 1200 ("J. B. S. Norton"); IH 1(ed.6): 362, 2: (in press); Kelly p. 161; Kew 4: 162;
Langman p. 543; LS 19110-19116, 19113 err., 37468-37482, suppl. 20223-20234; NW p.
54; Pennell p. 615; Rehder 5: 625; Stevenson p. 1252; Tucker 1: 523.
Anon., Amer. men. sci. 235. 1906.

	1898; transcript of mss at KSU; by Jesse Baker Norton).
Barnhart, J. H., North Amer. fl. 7: 1080. 1940.

Niedenzu, Bot. Centralbl. Beih. 7(5): 353-355. 1898.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: (1): Not to be confused with Jesse Baker Norton (x-1938), who studied also at Kansas

(2). The greater part of the treatment of J. B. S. Norton was kindly provided by J. L. Reveal.

(Deutschbrod, Havlíckåv Brod) 1874-1886, later at Jicín (Jitschin). (<em>J. Novák</em>).

Nuttall, Lawrence William (1857-1933), American mine-owner, botanist and plant
collector at Nuttallburg, Fayette County, West Virginia; in San Diego from 1927. (<em>L.
Nutt</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: PAC, WVA; other material BPI, CUP, F, MICH, NY, SD.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 17; BL 1: 168, 221, 311; BM 7: 944; Bossert p.
290; CSP 17: 576; GR p. 235; IH 2: (in press); Kew 4: 169; Lenley p. 316; Pennell p. 615;
Rehder 5: 628; Stevenson p. 1253.
Boone, W., Hist. bot. W. Virginia 194 [index]. 1865.
Core, E. L., Castanea 17: 157-164. 1952 (biogr., portr., b. 17 Sep 1857, d. 16 Oct 1933).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Millspaugh, C. F. &amp; L. W. Nuttall, Flora of Santa Catalina Island, Jan
1923, Field Mus. Bot. 5, see under Millspaugh.
(2) Millspaugh, C. F. &amp; L. W. Nuttall, <em>Flora of West Virginia</em>, Field Columbia Mus. Bot. 1 (2)
69-276. Jan 1896.

Nuttall, Thomas (1786-1859), British naturalist; pioneer scientific explorer of the United
States 1808-1841, at Philadelphia 1808-1810, to St. Louis and up the Missouri 1810-1812,
in England 1812-1815, mainly Philadelphia 1815-1818, to the U.S. Southwest 1818-1820,
at Philadelphia 1820-1822, at Cambridge, Mass. 1823-1834, to the Far West and around
Cape Horn 1834-1836, at Philadelphia 1836-1842; in England from 1841 except for a visit
to Philadelphia 1847-1848. (<em>Nutt</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: The Nuttall herbarium (5.750 species, acquired 1860) is at BM.
However it would appear that up to the publication of the "Genera ... in 1818 he kept few
or no specimens for himself, presenting a complete series of his plants to the Academy of
Natural Sciences (PH) so that there repose his early types" (Pennell 1936). Further Nuttall
specimens are found in CGE, DUKE, DWC, E, F, FI, G, GH, K, LIV, MANCH, MO,
NY, OXF.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 1: 403, 3: 219, 6(2): 117; Backer p. 400; Barnhart 3: 17;
BB p. 231-232; BM 3: 1456, 7: 944; Bossert p. 290; CSP 4: 650-651, 8: 521, 12: 543, 17: 576;
DAB 13: 596-597; Desmond p. 469; DNB 41: 276-277; DSB 10: 163-165. 1974 (bibl.); Frank
3(Anh.): 72; GR p. 278, cat. p. 69; Herder p. 117, 141, 225; Hortus 3: 1200 ("Nutt."); IH
1(ed. 6): 362, 2: (in press); Jackson p. 68, 354, 360; Kew 4: 169; Krempelh. 3: 82, 211;
Langman p. 545; Lasègue p. 331, 346, 349, 464, 505; Lenley p. 465; LS 19154-19155; ME 1:
215-216, 3: 632 [index], 737; MW p. 359; NAF 28B(2): 348-349, ser. 2. 2: 167, 5: 250; NI
1458; Pennell p. 615; PH p. 507 [index]; PR 6772-6774 (ed.1: 7580-7584); RS p. 121; SK 1:
ccv; Stevenson p. 1253; TL-1/377, 842, 925-931; TL-2/325, 910, 3560, see E. M. Durand;
Tucker 1: 524-525; Urban-Berl. p. 379; Zander ed. 10, p. 697, ed. 11, p. 795.

6930. <em>The North American Sylva</em>; or, a description of the forest trees of the United States,
Canada, and Nova Scotia, not described in the work of F. Andrew Michaux, and
containing all the forest trees discovered in the Rocky Mountains, the Territory of Oregon,
down to the shores of the Pacific and into the confines of California, as well as in various
parts of the United States. Illustrated by 122 fine plates. By Thomas Nuttall, ... in three
volumes. Vol. I. [II, III.] being the fourth [fifth, sixth] volume of Michaux and Nuttall's
North American Sylva. Philadelphia [1: J. Dobson, ...; 2: Townsend Ward ...; 3: Smith &amp;

Nyárády, Erasmus Julius (1881-1966), Roumanian (Transylvanian) botanist; studied
at Budapest; from 1922 at Cluj. (<em>Nyár</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: CL; also in CLA, CLCB; further material at A, BP, DBN, E, GB,
GH, W.

	Natura, Biol., Romania 18(5): 91-92. 1966 (obit.); Taxon 15: 332. 1966.

Váczy, C., Taxon 16: 425-430. 1967 (bibl.).

Nylander, Fredrik (1820-1880), Finnish botanist and physician; Dr. phil. Helsinki 1844;
M. D. Helsinki 1853; from 1865 town surgeon of Oulu; brother of William Nylander. (<em>F.
Nyl.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: H; further material at C and E.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 3: 725, 726; Barnhart 3: 18; BM 3: 1457; CSP 4: 651;

6937. <em>Eriophori monographia auctore Fredrico</em>Nylander Helsingforsiae [Helsinki] (ex offici-
na typographica A. W. Gröndahl) 1852. Qu. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1852, p. [1]-23. <em>Copies</em>: <em>B-S</em>, MICH, MO. – Reprinted and to be cited from Acta Soc.
	Sci. fenn. 3(1): 1-23. 1852.

Nylander, William (1822-1899), Finnish lichenologist; M. D. Helsinki 1847; to Paris at
the Muséum d'Histoire naturelle (1848); first professor of botany at the University of
Helsinki 1857-1863; from 1863-1899 again in Paris. (<em>Nyl</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: H (51.000 lichens); library, notebooks and miscellaneous papers
also at H. Many types also at BM, PC and S. Correspondence at Helsinki University
Library. –<em>Exsiccatae</em>(see also Sayre 1969):
(1) <em>Herbarium lichenum parisiensium</em>,fasc. 1-3, nos. 1-150, Paris 1855-1857, sets at BM, C, E,
FH, G, H, PC, S, W (20 sets issued). Fasc. 3 issued Dec 1857 (T. Ahti).
(2) <em>Lichenes mont-dorienses</em>,fasc. 1-3, nos. 1-111, Paris 1856, sets at DUKE, E, H.
(3) <em>Lichenes pyrenaeorum orientalium</em>,nos. 1-78, sets at BM, FH, H, KIEL, MSTR.
(4) with N. I. Fellman, <em>Lichenes arctici collecti aestate 1863 in Lapponia orientali</em>,nos. 1-224,
Helsinki 1865.
(5) See J. P. Norrlin for <em>Herbarium lichenum fenniae</em>.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 3: 726; Ainsworth p. 97, 305; Barnhart 3: 18; BL 2: 63,
70, 84, 697; BM 3: 1457-1458, 7: 945; Bossert p. 290; Collander p. 380, hist. p. 156 [index];
CSP 4: 651-653, 8: 521-522, 10: 943-944, 17: 576-577; De Toni 1: xciii, 2: lxxxvii; DSB 10:
165-166; DTS 1: 214; Frank 3(Ann.): 72; GR p. 611, <em>pl</em>. [<em>4</em>], cat. p. 69; Hawksworth p. 185,
196; Herder p. 469; IH 1(ed. 6): 362, 2: (in press); Jackson p. 160-161, 290, 329, 332, 338,
349, 351, 369, 395, 402; Kelly p. 161-162, 255; Kew 4: 171-172; KR p. 559-560; Krempelh.
1: 457, 468-604, 2: 311, 315, 414-417, 659, 3: 203-229; Lenley p. 316; LS 19158-19389,
37489-37490; Moebius p. 109, 110; Morren ed. 10, p. 36; MW p. 359; PFC 1: xlix; PR 6777-
6784; Saccardo 1: 118, 2: 78; Saelan p. 355-379, 577 (bibl.); SBC p. 128; Stevenson p. 1253;
TL-2/253, 1853, 1897, 2456, 3109, 3112, see N. I. Fellmann, see Kihlman, A. O.; TR 971-
1033; Tucker 1: 525; Urban-Berl. p. 272.
A., <em>in</em> J. Morot, J. Bot. Bull. bibl. 13(5): li-lii. 1899.
Ahti, T., Introduction to William Nylander's collected lichenological papers 1 (in press),
	(biogr., bibl., descr. herbarium.) (The manuscript of this introduction was available to
	us for the preparation of our treatment of Nylander).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: (1) For a review of the exotic lichens described by Nylander, see A. M. Hue, Lich.
exot. 1892, see TL-2/3112.
(2) For a recent introduction by T. Ahti to N's life and works, with annotated bibliography
and a description of his herbarium see vol. 1 of William Nylander's collected lichenological
papers (see below TL-2/6979) in press. The manuscript of Dr. Ahti's introduction and
bibliography were kindly made available to us for the preparation of the present treatment.

Nyman, Carl Fredrik (1820-1893), Swedish botanist; med. fil. kand. Uppsala 1840;
curator ("amanuens") at the botanical dept. of Naturhistoriska Riksmuseum 1855-1889.
(<em>Nym</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: S; duplicates in many herbaria. – The original herbarium was small
(acquired at Sw. Cr. 500, fide KR); B. Nordenstam informs us that the collection consists of
occasional specimens only. – 30 Letters to S. O. Lindberg at University Library Helsinki.

1: xciii; DTS 1: 214-215; Frank 3(Anh.): 72; Herder p. 169; Hortus 3: 1201 ("Nym."); IH 2:
(in press); Jackson p. 43, 226, 336; Kew 4: 172; KR p. 560-562; Lenley p. 3; Morren ed. 2, p.

79, cron. xxviii; SK 1: ccv; TL-1/932, 1182; Tucker 1: 525; Urban-Berl. p. 289, 309, 379;
Zander ed. 10, p. 697, ed. 11, p. 795.

	(journey Sicily) 1853: 175 (back in Sweden after a year in Vienna); 1893: 136 (b. 14 Aug
	1820, d. 26 Apr 1893); Leopoldina 29: 109-110. 1893 (d.); Generalreg. Bot. Not. 1839-
	1938, p. 64-65, 111. 1939; Österr. bot. Z. 43: 268. 1893 (d.); Verh. bot. Ver. Brandenburg
	35: lxxviii, 1894 (d.).

Nyman, Erik Olof August (1866-1900), Swedish botanist; Dr. phil. Uppsala 1896;
travelled in Java and New Guinea, 1897-1900. (<em>E. Nym.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: UPS. – For Indonesian collections see SK 1 and Sayre (1975).

Oborný, Adolf (1840-1924), Moravian botanist; studied at the technical college of Brünn
(Brno); assistant at the Staatsrealschule 1866; teachers examination Wien (1870; "sup-

Oeder, George Christian [von Oldenburg] (1728-1791), German botanist; Dr. med.
Göttingen 1749; to Denmark 1752; royal professor of botany at Kjøbenhavn 1754-1770;

HEADING: OEDER

various times in Norway between 1755-1760; from 1773 in Oldenburg as regional governor
